NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the School for the Quarter ended March 31, 1950.

Principal

Dated April 12, 1950

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Indian Agent

Dated at this 19

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, pasting it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading “Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter.”

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the “Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter” by the “Total number of days in quarter”.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the “Average attendance of pupils during quarter” by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payments be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days attendance of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading “Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter”.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the “Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter” by the “Total number of days in quarter”.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the “Average attendance of pupils during quarter” by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will any grant be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days attended by pupils during the quarter on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading “Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter”.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the “Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter” by the “Total number of days in quarter”.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the “Average attendance of pupils during quarter” by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

Charge I. A.
Indian Industrial School

at Qu'Appelle

Dec 23 1907

Sir,

I beg to state that why the building for the girls was put up by the Dept of Public Works, the hot air furnaces were placed by the contractor which are too small, unfit for gall coal and had to be supplemented by stoves. The furnaces are of an old pattern with small flues, too narrow to take away the smoke and gas of gall coal. Up to last year we could procure anthracite coal from the West, but now it is impossible. Consequently, being having insufficient heat, the gas is often escaping into the room through the hot air registers, and we had several explosions that happily had no other consequences than to blow the door open. This inconvenience can be avoided by purchasing Pennsylvania coal, but it cannot be always procured and presently costs $13.50 or the station and $16.50 at the school beside the loss in transport. These new furnaces would cost about $350.00.

I am your obedient servant,

J. Hugonard

OTTAWA, 28th January, 1904

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Rev. Father Hugonnard, Principal of Qu'Appelle Industrial school, forwards under date the 18th inst., a long report on the destruction of the main building of this institution by fire on the 4th instant.

The Principal was absent at the time of the fire and did not learn of the catastrophe until he reached Winnipeg on his way from Ottawa.

The fire started in the lamp room and though apparently accidental it must have resulted from carelessness in allowing the boys to have access to this room in the middle of the day when there was no work to be done there. I am surprised that a place of this description, where about 150 lamps were locked after and kept with a supply of coal oil and other inflammable matter, should ever have been allowed to be placed in the position shown on the sketch enclosed by Father Hugonnard.

After the fire was discovered everything possible seems to have been done to put it out but with the start it had obtained they were unsuccessful and the whole building, with its valuable contents was destroyed entailing an estimated loss of $70,000.

The pupils and staff have been provided for temporarily, but if this school is to be kept on, new buildings will have to be put up at once. Father
Hugonnard says that he had about 170 of the pupils still on hand out of a total enrollment of 225 at the time of the fire, which was the number provided for by the Department.

To replace this school will entail a heavy expense and the Principal asks that $50,000.00 be at once included in the Supplementary Estimates to rebuild and furnish with the most necessary equipment.

With the difficulty experienced in obtaining pupils for industrial schools and the problematical results of their training while in such institutions, it is a question whether it is advisable to re-establish this school on the same lines as formerly, and also whether a smaller institution would not meet the requirements. In either case I consider that it would be better not to have all the work carried on in one building, as there will always be danger from fire in connection with these schools.

The plans submitted by the Rev. Father Hugonard for the proposed new Boarding School at Qu'Appelle show the main building and two wings connected with the said main building with passages 50 feet long, in the basement and first floors. The main building is 120 ft. X 50 ft. and 51 ft. high from the ridge of the roof to the floor of the basement. The plans of the basement and three floors are furnished, but only the front view of the main building.

The specifications throughout are practically satisfactory for the purpose of executing the work by days' labour, under the superintendence of a foreman, or architect.

If the work should be let by contract, the specifications would require to be drawn out in more detail, especially under the headings of hardware, painting, heating, plumbing, water supply and lighting.

I have discussed the plans and specifications with Father Hugonard, and drew his attention to the following points:-

The distance apart of joists is omitted; should be 16 inch centres.

There is no reference to the belfry in the specifications.

The posts marked on the plan 10 X 10 are not specified. They may be made smaller, but not less than 8 X 8. The beams are not specified.

Centre walls should be constructed in the basement, instead of piers to carry the basement floor joists.
joists, and these should be 2 X 10 instead of 2 X 6.

The stairs throughout the three buildings should not in any case be less than 4 feet wide.

The Vice Principal and the Sisters' bedrooms in the dormitories appear to be very narrow. Their width should be increased if convenient.

The idea of putting a safe inside of the chimneys, in order that space around them may be used for ventilation purposes, is certainly a good one. The air space, however, should be considerably greater. Father Hugonard explained that they would place ventilation pipes from the chimneys to the different dormitories and classrooms, which appear on the plans to have no ventilation provided. The plan proposed by the Rev. Gentleman would appear to be satisfactory.

No drainage from the building, or disposal of sewerage are specified. I discussed both these questions with Father Hugonard.

The heights of the different ceilings are specified to be, commencing at the basement, 9 - 10 - 12 and 10 feet respectively. The chapel from the floor to the top of the arch is 19 feet high. These heights cannot be very well increased, without adding considerably to the cost of the building, and I think they are sufficient for ventilation, and also any great height would increase the cost of heating. It is noted that the height of the building as shown on the plan does not correspond with the height of the stories as specified.

I may add that should it be decided to let the work by contract, several more plans will be required of sections and front and end views of the different buildings.
Water tanks should be specified and their positions shown on the plans.

Sir,

With reference to my letter asking for a grant to rebuild the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, I beg to state why it should be maintained as it is, although the policy of the Department is to establish boarding schools in future rather than industrial schools.

The Qu'Appelle Industrial School was established by an order in council in 1884 and 666 acres of land given by late Archbishop Tache of that location. It has been always a credit to the Department and has received the praises of the public in the press and otherwise.

The location is as good as can be found anywhere and has been often admired by visitors. Its proximity to the surrounding reserves has made the recruiting easier than for other schools situated on the Road lines or near towns. It has been the first, the largest and likely the best Industrial school and seems destined to be continued rather than any other.

Around Qu'Appelle, some day schools and a boarding school were closed to send the children to Qu'Appelle School.

Sir:—

I beg to acknowledge your letter of the 21st ultimo enclosing copy of letter from Mr. W. R. Tucker of Moose Woods on the subject of Industrial Schools, requesting from me a report on the said letter.

With reference to the three ex-pupils of Regina Industrial School referred to in that letter I beg to call your attention to the fact that Lucy Little Crow only attended our School one year, Becky White Cap one month and Sam Buffalo seven months. Mr. Tucker seems to be taking a good deal for granted when he assumes, as apparently he does, that these three pupils in the short periods during which they attended our School, caught consumption here. If his implied opinion that the other Industrial Schools are responsible for all these cases of consumption rests upon as slim basis as this, I do not think the letter deserves to be considered very seriously. Of course, I am not in a position to say that Becky White Cap in one month and Sam Buffalo in seven months did not contract consumption in this School.

As for the marriage of Lucy Little Crow; she was sixteen years of age when she came to this School, only stayed one year and consequently the School can hardly be expected to have made a very profound impression on her character. And as for her marriage to a strange Indian on her return to the Reserve and the Indian's elopement with another young woman, I should say that the responsibility for such misfortunes or irregularities should certainly rest upon the Missionary and Agent in
charge of the Reserve where these things happened rather than on the School where she spent so short a period. Mr. Tucker does not say, however, that Lucy has misbehaved. I find that the late Principal apparently did what he could to make an impression during her residence here, as it appears that she got two floggings and other punishment, but it certainly seems absurd to hold the School responsible for the conduct of the pupil who came in at the age of sixteen and spent only one year in the institution.

Regarding Sam Buffalo I am credibly informed that he died of hemorrhage on his way home after having obtained leave of absence to visit his parents. Here again, considerable is taken for granted when Mr. Tucker makes the statement that he died of consumption.

Speaking generally for our School in connection with the spread of consumption all I can say is that every possible precaution is taken to prevent contagion or the development of the disease and after visiting quite a large number of Day and Boarding Schools, as well as several Industrial Schools, I have no hesitation in saying that I believe the precautions taken in this direction in Industrial Schools are certainly more effective than in the majority of the Boarding Schools. In our School we not only watch the pupils carefully to detect the first indications of disease, but every boy and girl in the institution is weighed in their night dress once a month and a record of such weights, together with height and chest measurements is kept in a book provided for the purpose. The Matron and Assistant-Principal, who make these weights and measurements, turn in to me a record each month of all losses.
in weight since the previous month. The condition and habits, appetite &c. of those who have lost in weight are carefully noted, and steps taken by means of alteration of diet, fresh-air tent treatment and change of work, to prevent further loss and bring about recovery. If there is any suspicion of disease the Doctor's attention is called on the occasion of his next visit, when he makes a careful examination and if necessary prescribes medical treatment.

By these precautions and good circulation maintained in the main building and dormitories and the use of four large tents, (two for boys and two for girls,) I am satisfied that we are not only providing more favorable conditions for our pupils than most Day or Boarding Schools, but conditions very much superior to those existing in their homes on the Reserves.

In spite of all these precautions, of course, it is true that from time to time cases of consumption develop in the School. Where there is any suitable home to which to send the pupil we ask leave of your office to send the pupil home. There are cases, however, in which it is impossible to send the pupils home because of their family circumstances, but in all cases where they are retained in the School they are kept separated as far as possible from contact with the other pupils and every precaution taken to prevent contagion.

I must say that I am very much surprised at Mr. Tucker's statement that they have only had one death from consumption in ten years except those who brought the disease from the Industrial Schools. Either Mr. Tucker is laying a heavy account to the charge of the Industrial Schools, and as we have pointed out on a very slim foundation, or they have had a much lower mortality on his reserve than in all the reserves with which I
am familiar. Two years ago this summer I had the promise of two pupils from Okanaise Reserve who were to be brought to the School the following Christmas. Before Christmas time came one of them had taken sick and on that account neither of the girls was brought. Before spring the sick one died of consumption and subsequently the other sister was reported as having contracted the disease. Last autumn two pupils were promised me from Pipestone Reserve and I was lamenting that owing to inability to get to the Reserve late in the fall the pupils were not secured. This summer, however, I found that both these children had died of consumption on the Reserve. These children had never been at any School and I am not aware that they had any contact with any pupils who had been at school.

I have seen in my predecessor's correspondence a letter from the Commissioner's office in answer to a report made by the late Mr. McLeod on this subject, in which he had made a comparison of the mortality in this Industrial School with the mortality of children on the Reserves; and apparently in the opinion of the Commissioner a good case had been made out in favor of the Industrial Schools from a health standpoint.

Regarding sending children home from the Industrial Schools with consumption, since apparently that is the disease Mr. Tucker has reference to, it is an easy matter for Mr. Tucker to call it "a crime." There are others who consider it a wrong policy to retain them in the School after they have contracted the disease. I am somewhat at a loss to know therefore, how a policy can be adopted that will suit all parties. In the majority of cases parents pledge us to send their children home in case of sickness, and there seems to be no choice in the matter.
As for the spread of the disease on the Reserve that is a matter, the responsibility for which I think, rests with the authorities on the Reserve.

I know it is a commonly accepted view that the Indians were free from consumption until their contact with white men and the sending of their children to the schools. On the other hand I was told lately by Dr. Bell of Winnipeg, an eminent authority on bacteriology, that in all cases scrofula pus contains the germs of tuberculosis and I am informed by those who have had most accurate knowledge with reference to Indians that they had scrofula before the contact with white people. If this is a fact and Dr. Bell's contention is correct, we can hardly blame contact with white men for consumption among the Indians.

In conclusion I must say that Mr. Tucker's letter, written as he asserts to prejudice the case of re-building the Qu'Appelle School, seems to me decidedly ungenerous and contains rather extravagant charges against Industrial Schools with a very slim basis. It seems most unfortunate that in the Indian service there should be men with a disposition to lay such serious and ill-founded charges at the door of sister institutions.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Mr. Tucker blames Eddie Whitecap for the death of three others of the family. The Whitecap family appears to be one of many where the whole of the children are Tubercular. There are many such where not a child has been to a non-reservation school. The chances are that this family would have gone in that way had Eddie not been at an Industrial School.

It is unfortunate that 4 out of the 7 who attended industrial schools have died of Consumption, but according to Mr. Tucker there has been four others who have died in the same time of the same disease. It is a great mistake to blame Industrial Schools for the introduction of consumption to reserve life. The Indian died of consumption long before we had Industrial schools and if all the Industrial schools were closed he will still die of the same disease and it is probable that there is none other he needs to fear so much. And the best way to overcome the difficulty is to give him all the education possible, for whatever objection can be raised against the education of the red boy applies with equal force against educating a black boy, a green boy, or a white boy.

I agree with Mr. Tucker that no child with a contagious disease should be sent back to the reserve to spread the contagion. But what are we to do with those who develop consumption in an Industrial School? They should not be kept where there is danger of contaminating the whole school. If there is a home for the child to go to on the reserve, it is certainly the best solution before us at present. I have a case on my hands at present where there is no home to go to and I do not propose to send her to die as a pauper on the reserve, for such cases there ought to be something provided and that at the earliest possible date.

The fact that four out of the seven who went from the Moosewoods Reserve have died suggests something re the policy of securing pupils for Industrial Schools.
Many of those who labor on the reserve for the education of the Indian are in the same boat with Mr. Tucker who are against sending children off the reserve of course they always have an exception in cases of special character, such as poor orphan with no one to take care of it, or unmanageable individuals that the reserve is well without. From such unpromising material recruits are easily obtained, hence they frequently find their way into Industrial Schools. It is such children who usually go back to the reserve life, and the industrial school is blamed for making them rogues. One fact is carefully forgotten viz., that if a child is a rogue before it goes to school it will very likely be one when it returns only it will be a different kind of a rogue.

I would not say what Mr. Tucker implies viz., do away with the Industrial Schools. We have more of them at present than the Indian appreciates or at least more than can be properly filled with children of the right standard, under the present method of securing pupil and maintaining the schools. There ought to be some policy whereby only the best children morally, mentally and physically are allowed to attend these Industrial Schools.

The Indian in the Body Politic is no problem but the Indian on a reserve is a problem, and there must be a non-reservation school through which the Indian boy and girl may find a way from the filth and pauperism of the ordinary reserve life. Close up this door and all other doors of escape, keep the red man huddled on the reserve, continue to give him rations and treaty and the filth and pauperism will continue to the end of the chapter. Better far to burn the ration house, commute with him for his treaty, and in every possible way, labor toward the destruction of the reservation life. The process may be slow, and the time long, but never until then will this vexed and difficult problem be solved.

Yours Respectfully,

In this district the Dept has done away with Boarding Schools and Day Schools on Standing Buffalo's, Pasqua, Pianot the Assiniboins and Poor Man's Reserves sending the children to Qu'Appelle and Regina Industrial Schools. The future progress and civilization of the Indian children is largely dependent on an environment of civilized and industrial life, not usually found on the Reserves and nowhere should conditions more conducive to the desired end.
and be found than in Industrial Schools situated off the Reserves in prosperous agricultural districts—

In Boarding Schools on or near the Reserves, the children are usually so much in contact with their relations that they retain much of the old tribal superstitions and mode of thought and hear the lamentations of their elders for the good old days, when there was no Indian Agent or Farm Instructor to bother them about work, and when they did not have to till the land, make hay, or feed cattle, but could steal horses, fight, hunt buffalo, feast and dance. It has been frequently been remarked by persons competent and in a position to judge and also stands to reason, that as a general rule pupils educated away from the Reserves and only seeing their relatives for a limited period each year have more progressive ideas and are more ambitious than those permanently residing on the Reserves.

I understand that the objections to Industrial Schools are the cost of maintaining them, the difficulty of recruiting and the uselessness of the Indians learning trades.

As to cost—the Qu'Appelle Industrial has always cost less than the Industrial Schools in the United States, where it would be natural to expect the minimum cost as many of the schools are larger, freight rates and the cost of every thing except beef and flour is lower and there are better opportunities for disposing of surplus products.

This school has a record of being the least expensive of similar schools in the N.W.T., I believe.

As regards recruiting, this is certainly difficult, but if the Department enforced the law as regards Indian children attending school, I am confident there would be no difficulty in maintaining our number complete under the present circumstances we seldom fall short of 225. Our success in keeping up our attendance is largely due to the central location of this school with regards to the surrounding reserves, the school being on a main road from the reserves to another and near the bridge crossing the Qu'Appelle River.

After the Indians of Canada passed under the British Crown which became responsible for
for their welfare, the representatives of the Crown often urged the Government to continue the industrial training commenced by the Jesuit Fathers, as may be seen in the official documents in the Indian Department at Ottawa.

The mistake often made in judging Industrial Schools is that too much is expected from the first generation. Pupils frequently return to Reserves where little or no interest is taken in them and have to struggle along as best they can; whereas an interest has been taken in graduates as a rule do well. Indians are indolent, careless of the future and easily influenced by their surroundings. Unless graduates are properly handled immediately on their return to the Reserve they are apt to retrograde more or less and the schools are to blame. We have many graduates who having been properly handled on leaving school, particularly at File Hills are becoming large and successful farmers.

I contend that an Industrial School conveniently located for the Reserves and properly managed does much more efficient work than Boarding Schools; which are again much better than Day Schools, and I would point out further that with the rapid settlement in this district increasing opportunities for earning a living by following their trades will be offered to graduates wishing to do so.

Fort Qu'Appelle, Assiniboia, 16th January, 1905

Ref. your letter, No. 118575 of the 4th January, 1905.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of above date and number re the rebuilding of the Qu'Appelle school.

I have made enquiries regarding cement blocks and from what I have been able to gather, I do not feel justified in recommending the use of same in the construction of this school. There seems to be a great difference of opinion as to whether buildings made of this material will not crack or absorb moisture.

Some of the buildings I have examined were cracking and I am told this is accounted for by the fact that the proportions were not properly mixed. Whether this is the case or not it convinced me that there would be a risk in putting up a building of such material. I find that the cost of a building built of this material would be slightly more than one of brick veneer.

On making inquiries I find that the lumber required for this school can be purchased locally to good advantage. Both dealers at Balcarres, D.H. Macdonald and the Imperial Lumber Co. will sell lumber at a very low cost. The main quantity (dimensions and common)

In my opinion it would not be advisable to ask the principal to confine his purchases to one of the parties mentioned as he has been dealing with both firms in the past and has received good satisfaction and besides there will be times that a certain class of material will be required that one might have and the other would.

The Deputy Supt. General,-

On examination of the plans and specifications of the proposed Qu'Appelle Indian Industrial school for the purpose of making estimate of cost and reporting on same, I find that the plans and specifications are in a very incomplete state, and it would be impossible to make an accurate estimate, without additional elevations and sections of main building and front and side elevations, and section drawings of smaller buildings, as well as some of the detail drawings, and a complete specification covering every portion of the work.

The heights of the ceilings in specifications do not agree with the elevation, and the windows are not at the correct heights to allow for proper lighting of class rooms, and in many ways the plans and specifications are at variance.

The chimneys for boiler and heating apparatus are not of sufficient capacity to ensure efficient results.

The cost of a solid brick building would not be any greater than a veneered building, it would also be much safer in case of fire, and more durable and substantial.

I would recommend that complete plans, specifications and details be prepared (using the present plans as a basis) by your Department, before starting the work either by day labour or contract, as properly prepared plans, etc., cost less than alterations, and are more satisfactory.

With correct plans the Superintendent will be in a position to keep a check on the work. There will be fewer alterations and less room for litigation.

As no estimates are passed through this office for the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, I beg to submit the following and request that an appropriation be made to carry out the work next year.

For the last five years the question of putting another storey on the passage connecting the main building with the girls' building has been promised. This has been brought to the Department's attention on several occasions, the last time on the occasion of the visit of the Minister I was told to place an amount in the Estimates and I am doing so now.

The necessity for a sleeping verandah is great and medical officers who have visited this institution as well as local men have been pressing for this for a long time. It will take about $6000.00 to do the work.

I also ask that an amount of $2000.00 be placed in the estimates to keep the school in repair. An Institution of this kind requires a certain amount to keep the building up.

I would ask also that $5000.00 be placed in the estimates to replace some old ramshackle buildings that disfigure the premises. These are used as blacksmith and carpenter shop. Twelve years ago I intended to replace these buildings but for good reasons this never was done. I would be glad if this item would be authorized.

I patrolled this p.m., to Lebret Indian School, with private auto, in connection with the above fire, and interviewed the principal of this institution regarding same. It appears that about 7:00 p.m. on the last night, three Indians, as follows, who belonged to Regina Reserve, Saskatchewan from Regina Reserve, and Sasqua, and Indian visiting on Sasqua Reserve, but originally from Sasqua Reserve, were apparently in the yard left in the dark, lighting a fire for their comfort, whereupon some of the other Indians were alleged to have lit a match, and probably have dropped same before it was fully out, with the supposed result that some little time afterwards it was noticed from the school that fire was issuing from this building.

The principal asked me if my investigation was at the request of the Indian Commissioner? I informed him, that it was not, complaining that the investigation would be expected of me by my Department.

The damage done amounts to the burning of a pig pen and wheat granary, also a quantity of wheat will be spoiled etc. I was also informed that a part of this building had been torn down prior to the fire, so stock was burnt.

Two large new hip roofed barns have recently been completed immediately west of these old buildings.

The principal explained that his opinion was that the fire was purely accidental, as the three of the Indians were there and fought the fire, and he is satisfied that there was no intent on the part of the fire to carry or extend, which latter, as he was not able to proceed to Lebret until this date.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith final progress certificate amounting to $2,502.30 in connection with the erection of the new barns at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. You will note that there is an item of $210.30 for extras, and a summary of the extras is attached to the certificate with explanations.

In submitting the final estimates on these buildings I may say that I find them much more elaborate than there is any necessity for their being. In the first place four times as much money has been spent on concrete than was necessary and this necessitated an additional expenditure of $1500.00. I believe that fifty feet of concrete was all that was required for the two buildings whereas we have put in two hundred and nine feet.

The walls are fourteen inches thick, nine inches is the standard thickness; the walls go down five feet into the ground, one foot would have been ample - all stables in this country are built on these lines. The ventilating shafts are of iron, these could have been made of wood as most shafts are and a saving of several hundreds of dollars would have been effected here. The horse barn is double floored, a single flooring of plank would have been sufficient.

We could have had accommodation for the same number of stock and had better barns than you will find on

Dear Sir:

You will no doubt recall your conversation with the writer regarding the storage battery in your school at Fort Qu'Appelle, which I looked over in company with our Winnipeg representative Mr. Strong, when in the West.

This battery while not in the very best condition, seems to be answering the purpose for the time being and as we discussed it is not necessary to spend money on it until it starts to fail. We had hoped when we put it in there that it would give you three years service and are prepared to protect you on this basis. In the event of failure within the three year period, we shall be willing to credit you with a proportionate amount to the length of service lost on a new battery of the Demi Plante type of cell, which we discussed during our conversation.

An ordinary battery plate is a lead frame work into which is pasted the active material, which gives the discharge, but will with each discharge, gradually disintegrate until there is no active material left and the battery has absolutely no capacity. The demi plate type of plate is solid lead with the exception of a thin film of active material pasted to the outside, which carries on the discharge until the solid lead portion of the plate has become active, which will do the work thereafter. They are usually capable of giving three times the life of the pasted plate and we could give you the names and addresses of many installations which have been in for ten years and are still doing excellent work. The initial cost, of course, is somewhat greater, but based on so much per year for battery service is by far the most economical battery to buy.
Today a replacement of the same cells as you have would cost you approximately $1380.00 F.O.B. Regina, while we can put in a set of demi plante cells for $1547.00 F.O.B. Regina, with sales tax extra.

While you do not need a replacement at the present time, we ask you to keep this quotation before you and bear it in mind when the time comes to renew the cells which you are now using as we feel that you cannot do better than purchase a demi plante type of cell, which we are recommending.

Yours faithfully,

Hart Battery Co. Limited,
C.V.Edwards,
Sales Manager.

Report on the above school for the month of Sept.

There are five school rooms; boys are large and bright and well ventilated. Junior room has three small windows and from fifty to sixty children in this room. Girls senior room is large but poorly lighted; Intermediate is bright but would be better with windows that would open from top.

Dormitories for boys, which is one, has hundred and five beds in, there are two for girls, one for junior and one for the senior. Advised that these be well ventilated and the beds to be well aired. Would be better to have accommodation for extra sister to sleep with these children in case of fire, as now there is only one.

Baths: There is great difficulty in bathing these children especially girls, as the hot water has to be carried from kitchen, and can only get that on Saturdays. There are two bath tubs in senior girl's dormitory, while little ones have two downstairs. Would be better, when there are so many if they had hot water and more bath tubs. Boys have spray bath, but this does not clean them properly.

Toilets are fairly clean, some have odor, especially boys as boys are careless. Have difficulty with girls' toilet downstairs blocking.

Florence M. Colvin,
Travelling Nurse.

The Principal has made repeated requests for the construction of a Carpenter Shop. I would say that a new reason in favour of this plan has been added this year by the request of the Principals assembled at Convention at Duck Lake, viz.: that some young men be sent to Qu'Appelle School in order to perfect their knowledge of engineering and carpentering. Above all the importance of the School calls for the erection of such a building.

ADDITION TO COW STABLE.

The extensive farming operations carried on at Qu'Appelle School necessitate a certain number of outbuildings. A couple of years ago a cow and horse stables were built but prove inadequate for the quantity of cattle. The Principal had protested in due time against the dimensions of those stables but to no avail. In his requests for last year's estimates, asked for the enlarging of the cow barn and he reiterates the same request for the same reasons. For my part, having examined the situation, I take the liberty of urging action from the Department.

SILOS.

Two silos are needed at Qu'Appelle and I believe the Department will not fail to add same to the outbuildings at Qu'Appelle School.

I beg to recall to the attention of the Department the excellent results of Rev. Fr. Leonard's administration at Qu'Appelle and think that such should be partially recognized by including his requests in the list of Estimates.

Sir:

I beg to attach herewith the Estimates for requirements at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School for the fiscal year 1928-29, and would recommend that they be approved.

I would point out that this is a very large institution and in the past I feel that we have been more or less neglecting the upkeep, and this should not continue. This year I have had the exterior of the building re-painted. It would have been better had it been painted two years ago. The money which we are now asking for is to do inside work.

With regard to the laundry, this is one of the most unsanitary and inadequate laundries we have at any of our schools in Western Canada. It was built at a time when the Department did not indulge in modern laundry machinery. The building is not fit for a laundry and I am asking for a new building, with equipment.

Buildings.

I went through the buildings and find that they have reached a state now where it will be necessary to provide a considerable sum each year to keep them in proper repair. I found on going through the main building that the floor in the dining-room has settled.
Inspector Murison's report on Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

from 2½ to 3 inches all the way along the front. It was impossible to estimate on the cost of putting this floor back into position, as it will be necessary to take up a portion of the floor to ascertain the cause. I am of the opinion that the floor joists have rotted. The same remarks would apply to the boys' building which is settling. I noted that the stairways were considerably out of level, and here, as in the other building, it will require close examination to ascertain the cause. I found the main building in a clean and tidy condition, also the girls' building. The boys' building, however, was not so neat, excepting the dormitory, which presented a very nice appearance. The classroom floors were untidy in the boys' department, but this could be understood, as it would be almost impossible to keep them clean owing to the muddy condition of the yards. I found their playroom and their lavatory in a dirty condition, and there is no question that there has been neglect in supervising the boys during the hours of recreation. The supporting posts in the playroom are all hacked with knives, and the walls, within and without, have been written on. In the boys' lavatory the seats of the toilets have been wrenched off, one bowl is missing and another has been broken, (I found out that this had been done deliberately by a boy, with a bar of iron), and there was an accumulation of dirt on the wash basins and urinals which, in my opinion, is the result of neglect for months past. I expressed my disapproval of these conditions very strongly to the Principal, and also to the senior boys in their classroom, in the presence

of the Principal and the teacher, and I trust that my visit will have the effect of bringing about a better state of affairs in this department. The girls' classrooms are situated in the attic of the girls' building. The lighting, as has already been reported by the Provincial School Inspectors, is poor. It has been proposed to double up a number of these windows, and the wall has been opened for an examination as to how best to do this. I am of the opinion that increased lighting could be better obtained through the roof. Possibly it might be less expensive, and it would not have the effect of weakening the building in any way. The Sisters pointed out that two of their bedrooms, as well as the chapel, had never been painted since the building was put up.

Fire Protection.

Fire hose connected with the water system are provided on each floor, as well as a number of fire extinguishers. I examined the hose and found it in very good condition. The fire extinguishers, according to the cards attached, had been re-charged last Fall. Fire escapes are provided, in the shape of iron stairways, with the exception of the escapes from the girls' classrooms and the gymnasium. They have skeleton ladders provided for these rooms which I think are impractical, but as these rooms are only occupied during the daytime it is questionable if the occasion will ever arise necessitating the use of these fire escapes.
Inspector Murison's report on Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

I noted that a considerable amount of necessary repair work had been done during the winter months. The Principal was authorized by the Department to expend $300.00, and I noted that only very necessary repairs were being made, and the money is being carefully expended.

The plank walk from the girls' building to the Ice House is in an unsafe condition. The Principal states that he will replace this with a new one at an early date. The storage facilities in the Ice House are not satisfactory. The meat has to be suspended from the ceiling away from the walls to protect it from rats. I noted that the picket fence around the girls' playground required repairing.

Laundry.

The space in the washroom is limited. A coal bin and vertical steam boiler are located in this room, and when the boiler is being fired the coal dust makes it difficult to keep things clean. A separate room for the boiler and fuel would seem advisable, and their removal would provide additional needed space in the laundry room.

Shoe Shop.

It was noted that the floor in the Shoe Shop was in poor repair. Very useful work is done in this department. All the shoes for the pupils are made here, and are also kept in repair. This affects a saving.

Bake Shop.

This is a brick building, and it was noted that the walls have cracked and have been strengthened by placing 15 horizontal rods through the building. The brick in the ceiling of the oven is falling down, and

will have to be repaired at once, as it is getting worse all the time. The chimney from this oven does not appear to be high enough. The Baker stated that it smokes badly, and appearances would bear this out.

Work Shop.

The old work shop and coal sheds are in a dilapidated condition. I am informed that they will be replaced during the coming summer. This will add greatly to the appearance of the place.

The horse and cow barns are good buildings. A silo has been built between the two barns. It was tried out this winter for the first time and has proven very satisfactory. The cow barn provides accommodation for 24 cows, and a calf pen. They have 23 milch cows, 1 bull, and 21 head of young stock. A shed is provided for the young stock. They should have at least 35 milch cows at an institution of this size, and in order to accommodate this number it would be necessary to extend the barn at least 30 feet. At the time of my visit they were milking 14 cows, which is not a sufficient number to provide milk for approximately 250 persons. They should have at least 35 in order to keep at least 20 milking steadily.

Farm and Garden.

There are 900 acres of land in connection with this school. The farm lands are situated from three to six miles away. Of this, about 500 acres are under cultivation, viz:- 375 acres which were sown to grain, roots and vegetables, -and 125-
Inspector Murison's report on Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

and 125 acres under summerfallow. They had 200 acres of wheat, which averaged 17½ bushels per acre, 95 acres of oats averaging a little over 23 bushels per acre, and 55 acres of barley, averaging 10 bushels to the acre. They had 12 acres of fodder crop, consisting of beets, sunflowers, and corn, all of which were a good yield. The garden was a success last year, and provided sufficient roots and vegetables for the use of the school, as well as a considerable surplus for sale.

Live Stock.

The live stock consists of 23 cows, 1 bull, 21 head of young stock, 26 horses, 20 hogs, 35 young pigs, and about 100 poultry. I may say that the cattle are all Holstein.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to enclose herewith a report on the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, which was recently inspected by Mr. Murison.

The out buildings at this school are in a sad state of repair. You will notice that I have asked for $1,000.00 in the Estimates for repairs to the buildings; I hope this has been allowed.

I would draw your attention to the Inspector's remarks regarding the playroom and lavatory in the boys' department. This condition has almost always existed; it is impossible to keep this up to the standard in which it should be kept. The joists in the main building have apparently rotted away. This will necessitate considerable expenditure and I doubt whether the $1,000.00 asked for will be sufficient.

With reference to the laundry, I have asked that $2,000.00 be allowed to put a decent laundry in this school, as the present one is far from what it should be.

I note that some money has been spent during the winter in doing minor repairs about the buildings. This is the first intimation I have had that this money was authorized and that the work was being carried on. The walk leading to the ice house is reported to be unsafe; in fact, all the walks are unsafe. I would draw your attention to the Inspector's remarks regarding the storage facilities not being satisfactory. I have also asked for $1500.00 to put this right.

Sir:

I wish to refer to your letter of the 2nd instant and to earlier correspondence concerning requirements at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. I am pleased to inform you that funds are available for the erection of three workshops at this school. The shops in question are blacksmithing, tinsmithing and carpentry. In some of the letters it has been suggested that one building be erected to house these various shops, but I shall ask you to do whatever you find is most advisable. $5,000 may be expended for this purpose. There is also available $2,100 for the miscellaneous painting and other improvements and repairs mentioned in your letter of October 24th, last. This work also may be proceeded with when timely. Please be guided by general instructions in the Deputy Superintendent General's letter of the 28th instant.

Sir:—

I beg to inform you that I was at the Qu'Appelle School last week. This is the first visit that has been made to this institution by me since last Fall. I find that the plumbing throughout the building is in a very bad state of repair and requires a general overhauling. The pipes under the floors are leaking, in other places the pipes are corroded, the lavatories are out of order and in fact I would say that the whole plumbing system is far from what it should be. In looking up the Estimates I see that there is an item of $1000.00 to look after unforeseen repairs at this school. When this item was inserted it was not meant for the repairing of plumbing, but I should be glad to have your authority to send a man to this school at once to put the plumbing in shape before any further damage is done. I anticipate difficulty in getting a plumber at this time of year, as everybody is very busy. We may, however, be able to get someone if this authority is received at once.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have not yet had any official instructions from the Department regarding the new laundry which is so very badly needed at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. An item was placed in the Estimates to provide for this, and, as you know, there is no place in the West where the need for a laundry is greater than at this institution. Before your visit to the school, complaints were made by the Indians to the effect that their children were contracting colds and sickness by working in the present laundry, and while this may be an exaggeration, the fact remains that it is really not fit for people to work in, especially in the wintertime.

There has been an amount of $4000.00 allowed for a Farmer's residence at the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, which is not needed this year, and probably a saving will also be effected at other points and I hope that it will be possible to find funds with which to supply this laundry.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,

Dear Sir:

The hot water service system in the Lebret Indian School. Having made a thorough canvass of the situation, we find that there are three separate units which means three jackets, 3 tanks and three fires to look after and even when working at their full capacity, which is very seldom, they are totally inadequate to supply sufficient hot water. The jacket heaters are done now and will require to be replaced also two of the tanks. The life of these jacket heaters will be about one year, in fact in most cases similar they are stopped up with alkali in six months continuous service.

We would recommend the installing of a small low pressure boiler and placing same in the central boiler room, from there hook up the present three units with a supply main to each unit from the hot water tank. This tank also should be placed in the central boiler room. The tank and mains should be covered with asbestos air shell pipe covering.

The tank would be 42x8 feet with a manhole and galvanized coil.

The advantage of this installation would be the elimination of future repairs such as jacket heaters and range boilers. The steam boiler for this job should last for twenty five years. There would be no alkali accumulation in the boiler as it is a closed system. The coil in the tank would have to be cleaned of scale once or twice a year dependent upon the amount of hot water heated.

The cost of a #924 steam low pressure boiler will be three hundred and sixty ($360.00) dollars.

Hot water pressure tank 42x10' with hot water coil and manhole two hundred and sixty seven ($267.00) dollars.

Time and material for installation of above.

Yours truly,

PAULIN & SWAYZE
Per E.P. Paulin

Dear sir:

We went to Lebret and checked over the wiring of the fire gongs in the Indian School. The present wires are bare in many spots, and in very poor condition throughout. We would advise putting steel covered B.X. wire and installing 12 new fire call stations. All call stations and bell outlets would terminate in steel boxes, making it as near fire proof as possible.

This work would be done in the same manner as other Indian schools; that is, there are twelve fire call stations controlling six bells. The annunciator at present installed would be done away with, and a fire call station putting in a call would ring all six bells.

The price for this work would be two Hundred and seventy-two dollars and fifty Cents ($272.50).

Trusting this is the information you desired, we beg to remain,

Yours very truly,

SASKATCHEWAN POWER COMMISSION

Regina, Sask.
17th October, 1929.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir,

When in Lebret on October 8th, I inspected wiring and general layout of distribution at the Indian School. The attached sketch and photos show the arrangement of poles and services on their property.

The wiring round the grounds connecting the various buildings was put up a number of years ago for the old plant. It is not suitable for the new service of light and power to be supplied by the Montreal Eng. Co., and constitutes a bad fire hazard. Some of the buildings have the service wires running through the window frames and others through BX cable with no protection where passing into buildings. Messrs. Willis and Hall Electrical Contractors, who are now working at the school have installed a new 3 phase 10 H.P. motor in the laundry and they requested an inspection by the Power Commission as they did not see their way clear to connect up motor to the existing wires in the grounds, without adding to the general confusion of wiring. No conduit fitting in end of pipe to root cellar.

Changes that should be made.

The Montreal Eng. Co. are putting in a new pole in position shown in sketch. This pole will have a cabinet on it containing four pole switch, 3 blades fused and the necessary meter to control all the buildings of the Indian School.

A proper entrance switch and conduit entrance should be placed at every point where wires enter the school buildings and connected up to the central pole where the main switch will be installed.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) Arthur Townsend.
Chief Inspector.

Sir:

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith Regina Voucher #6494 amounting to $3014.43 in favour of Messrs. Paulin and Swayze for material and labour in connection with the construction of a new laundry at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School. This involved the enlarging of the old laundry, the replacing of the existing machinery in many cases, and a general over-hauling of the plumbing and electrical work. It is connected with the main building by a long passage which was set on concrete, and the building is now in first-class shape.

With this account we are well under the $6000.00 authorized. There may be some odds and ends that will have to be supplied later on. However, I do not look to see the amount authorized exceeded.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

In submitting our report upon the nature of the work done at the Lebret Indian School, I wish to call to your attention the main items of which the bill is composed:

- Laundry, as per bill ........................................ $3675.53
- Steam Boiler & Heat Water Tank for
  installing domestic hot water heating ................. 627.00
- 3 New Steam Coils in Dryer .................................. 212.00
- Installing new high pressure, steam boiler,
  replacing old one ........................................... 115.90
- 2 New Roll Rim Sinks in main Dining Room .............. 42.20
- 2 New Bath Tubs complete with traps,
  combination Cox., Waste & overflows .................... 84.00
- Kenney Flushometers Valves .................................. 207.00
- Galvanized water pipe ....................................... 242.50
- Self closing Basin Cox ....................................... 752.00
- 20 sacks Asbestos ............................................. 70.00
- Asbestos pipe covering ...................................... 75.00
- Add for estimate percentage of labour .................... 350.00

Total ................................................................. $3691.43

When you deduct the main items in the account from the total bill, there is a balance of $3615.42 for material labour and expenses upon the whole of the repairs as per our statement. It would be most difficult to say just what part of the whole work that we have just completed could have been left undone. We have been careful to see that the work as far as we have gone has been well and thoroughly done. As such amount that profitably be expended upon this school in bringing the heating up to standard efficiency and we would be pleased at any time to submit a layout of the requirements. There has been no material used unnecessarily in making repairs.

To specially mention the changing of the domestic hot water system where now, as you know, four jacket heaters at various places in the building, which meant four fires to look after, each heating say thirty to forty gallons of water. Any one of them the size that might be installed in an ordinary private residence.

One can easily visualize what happens when 75 boys, more or less, are ready for a shower; they would not get more than started before the hot water would be all used. The same thing applies to the other parts of the building where these small jacket heaters were installed. I am convinced-

Indian Affairs. (RC 10, Volume 6328, file 660-5, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES

CANADA
convinced that a considerable saving in the amount of coal would be effected, in the use of the new system over the four jacket heaters formerly used if same had been fired continuously to produce the same amount of hot water as the new system. As now installed a small fire carrying one lb. of steam or even less, will supply an abundance of hot water for kitchen and all other purposes. Although a satisfactory domestic hot water system has been installed and will supply all the hot water required, it remains to be seen just what service the school will get from it, as it would appear to be of far greater importance to the management to save a few tons of coal rather than have the pupils well supplied with hot water.

As soon as the new domestic hot water system was put into operation and the new taps installed, there was a considerable decrease in the number of times the pumps were working.

Referring to the sanitary conditions of the plumbing when we began the repairs of overhauling the Boys' Lavatory off the playroom was positively filthy and in a most unsanitary condition. The sewer was stopped at several points which necessitated breaking up the concrete floor and clearing drain, also putting in suitable floor drains and cleanouts. The twelve lavatory basins were considerably damaged, in some cases torn off the wall. The taps and traps were ruined; two urinals were not working; not a seat on any of the eight closet bowls; flushometer not operating properly. Such unwholesome conditions are very demoralizing upon the students.

In the main building the sewers were stopped or very nearly so and overflowing in different parts of the building below the floor. A prime condition for starting an epidemic of almost any kind.

A thorough job had been made of clearing all sewer pipes and stopping leaks and such other repairs as was necessary for the safety of the occupants and the proper venting and wasting of all sewer lines.

The utter lack of any system or management of any kind is directly responsible for these deplorable conditions.

The part of the building in charge of the Sisters, however, is wholesome and well looked after, especially considering the conditions under which they are working.

The engineer appears to be a competent man, but the multiplicity of his duties absolutely prohibits his being able to properly do one third of the work allotted to him.

Trusting the above has made the various matters clearer, we are,

Yours very truly,

PAULIN & STAYZE.
EXCERPT FROM INSPECTOR MURISON'S REPORT ON QUI'APPELLE SCHOOL DATED APRIL 26th, 1928.

The classroom floors were untidy in the boys' department, but this could be understood, as it would be almost impossible to keep them clean owing to the muddy condition of the yards. I found their playroom and their lavatory in a dirty condition, and there is no question that there has been neglect in supervising the boys during the hours of recreation. The supporting posts in the playroom are all hacked with knives, and the walls, within and without, have been written on. In the boys' lavatory the seats of the toilets have been wrenched off, one bowl is missing and another has been broken, (I found out that this had been done deliberately by a boy, with a bar of iron), and there was an accumulation of dirt on the wash basins and urinals which, in my opinion, is the result of neglect for months past. I expressed my disapproval of these conditions very strongly to the Principal, and also to the senior boys in their classroom, in the presence of the Principal and the teacher, and I trust that my visit will have the effect of bringing about a better state of affairs in this department.

REGINA, SASK., Dec. 19th, 1929

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith Regina Voucher No. 6498 for $6009.80 in favour of Messrs. Paulin & Swayze, Regina, the bulk of which is for overhauling and repairs to the plumbing system at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School.

Included in this account is a new steam boiler, $627.00, leaving the cost for labour and repairs $5,382.80. This is a heavy expense and according to Messrs. Paulin & Swayze there is still much that could be done. You will notice from the report signed by this firm, copy of which is attached, the manner in which the plumbing has been neglected, and the condition in which the plumbers found it, which, of course, goes to show that the Principal has neglected to have the repairs attended to at the proper time, and proves conclusively that he is not competent to take charge of an institution of this kind.

Of course, this matter has been taken up with the Department on various occasions, and I merely refer to it again because I think it is too bad that we have to be drilling at this man all the time, not only to look after his plumbing, but everything else about the place. Bearing out what Messrs. Paulin & Swayze say about the condition of the plumbing, I am enclosing an excerpt from Inspector Murison's report.

Ottawa, April 29th., 1930.

Dear Sir,

Will you please refer to Regina voucher No. 6495 in favor of Messrs. Paulin & Swayze, Regina, forwarded under cover of your letter of the 19th December 1929, File 314-11A, for work done at the Qu'Appelle Residential School. On page 10 of the invoice dated Nov. 20th, 1929, the item for 10 ft. 2" D.H. soil pipe @ .50¢ was extended at $10.00, and the amount was changed to $5.00 and the difference deducted on page 22. As the $10.00 amount appears to have been a typographical error and does not affect the total of the page, an underpayment of $5.00 is indicated. I therefore enclose a cheque for $5.00 in favour of Paulin and Swayze to cover the short payment.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, No. 114-0-1, in connection with Inspector Hamilton's report on the Lebret School.

I immediately took steps to have the windows measured for screens, and wired you yesterday as follows:

"Cost of screen windows and doors for Lebret School will be approximately four hundred and fifty dollars. At present there are only about one dozen screens altogether on the buildings. May I have your authority by wire to incur this expenditure?"

If authority is granted by the Department to have the screens made, the price I quoted was received from the Western Manufacturing Co. They will be painted green, ready to put on, and are really good substantial screens, something that should last for years. I could have got them to make up cheaper screens than this, but considered that a flimsy screen made out of 3/8 material is not of much account.

I have also made arrangements for the automatic flushers, and the steps leading up to the windows of the fire escapes. The steps were included in the cost of the window screens.

Mr. Hamilton mentioned in his report that one of the bowls in the boys' toilet was out of commission and cracked. The Principal drew my attention to the fact that there are two bowls broken, and these should be replaced. I shall be glad to receive your authority to do this.

Yours very truly,

Sir:-

I beg to forward herewith an Estimate for the Cu'Appelle Industrial School for the fiscal year 1931-32.

The matter of additional stabling accommodation for milch cows has been brought before me, and I have placed an amount of $4000.00 in the Estimate to provide for a barn to accommodate 35 head of cows and young stock. This cannot well be put off for another year.

I find that the roof of the school building is in a very bad state of repair, in fact the rafters are rotting away around the dormer windows at several points. This means that the whole roof will have to be repaired, and it may be necessary to undertake this work before the amount asked for in the Estimates has been made available. When this is done the school roof and framing should all be re-painted. The total cost will be in the neighborhood of $4000.00, which is the amount I have asked for. This cannot wait another year.

At an institution of this size there are always certain unforeseen repairs during the course of the year which have to be attended to, and I have placed the usual amount of $2500.00 in the Estimate to cover this.

The fire alarm is in good working order, although the battery is poor and will not retain its charge. A new battery should be provided. Fire extinguishers are placed throughout the building, also fire axes. The four large red painted Pyrene fire extinguishers, supplied some three years ago, are leaking and useless. The materia in the cases does not stand up and they appear to rust through around the bottoms. Four new ones are needed. Fire drill is observed regularly and all fire escapes are in good condition. No doors or windows are locked leading to the escapes. This school, as the Department is aware, is one of the older buildings, but all fire apparatus is in good condition and the arrangements for fire escapes are splendid. A night watchman is kept.

The furnace rooms are small. In two of these rooms the smoke pipes leading from the furnace is almost burned through in places and should be renewed. A fire might easily be started should the pipes take fire and in places they are almost as thin as brown paper.

The laundry is well equipped and is operated one day a week. The grates in the upright boiler are burned out and at present pieces of pipe are being used. A new grate should be provided.

Sir:

I beg to forward herewith Estimates for the Qu'Appelle Residential School at Lebret. Being unable to find copies of former Estimates for this school on file here, I proceeded to Lebret and took the matter up with the Principal and find that he has not been sending in Estimates for some time. I therefore looked into conditions and have prepared a list of their requirements.

I have inserted an item for $200.00 to extend the sewage drain pipe a distance of about 200' into the lake. At present it is emptying into a creek bottom about 120' distant from the lake and the smell is offensive and the Provincial Health Department have brought the matter to my attention, asking that it be attended to.

The Principal asks for an additional cow barn. The cow barn in use at present provides accommodation for 24 milk cows. They should be milking at least 40 cows to provide for their requirements. They have at present over 100 head of cattle and no adequate accommodation for them. In addition to the milk cows required, the school herd provides all the beef used by the institution. A barn suitable for their requirements would cost between thirty-five hundred and four thousand dollars which is a considerable sum. In looking over the situation I am of the opinion that the need could best be met placing a lean-to on each side of the present barn. This would be less expensive and in discussing the matter with the Principal, I find that it would be quite satisfactory to him. I have estimated that the cost of the lean-to would not exceed $1500.00. A great deal of the work can be done by the school carpenter.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
school carpenter.

I have also placed an item of $410.00 for a water softener in the Estimates. The water from the lake is found to be hard on the boilers and pipes. There is some ingredient in it which eats into the metal and causes corrosion. I have made inquiries and it is thought that by softening the water the corrosion would be practically eliminated.

The washing machine in use in the laundry is not large enough to take care of the large amount of washing to be done and the Principal asks to be supplied with an additional washer. This would cost approximately $150.00.

General repairs are under way in connection with the roof of the main building and in order to keep up a presentable appearance the shingles on the roof should be re-stained. The pig house and silo require painting badly and there is always a certain amount of repair work to be done. I have included an item of $300.00 for painting and $400.00 for general repairs and fencing. The fence on the west side of the boys' playground has to be rebuilt in order to protect the shrubbery. At present all that remains of the fence is the posts.

I trust you will be able to find money for the foregoing, as the items asked for are in my opinion required.

Your obedient servant,

I at once proceeded to get full details of the repairs required and an estimate of the cost and on the 12th instant wired for authority to have the boiler repaired. In the meantime the girls beds were removed into the main building and two heating stoves installed in the girls' building to keep the pipes from freezing. Watchmen were kept in the building continually throughout the night and day.
