about 6.30 a.m. the Sister in charge of the girls, in passing through the girls' building, noticed smoke coming out of a room adjoining the passage. There was no heating unit in this room and the belief is that the fire was caused through a short circuit in the lighting wires. I may say that this building has been infested with rats during the past few years and it may be quite possible that the insulation on the wires was chewed by them. The pipes from the heating stoves which had been installed did not pass through any of the rooms, but were installed in the corridors. After making full enquiry into the circumstances, it would appear to me that very full precautions had been taken to insure the safety of the building. The pupils were all up and dressed, having attended the morning service in the Chapel, and immediately upon the alarm being given the fire fighting equipment was put in operation. This consisted of hose attached to the pressure tanks and fire extinguishers. The people from the Village of Lebret, the Lay-Brothers from the Seminary across the lake, and the Staff from the Sanatorium at Fort San who brought all the fire extinguishers they could gather with them assisted in making a determined effort to save the buildings; but, in view of the rapidity with which the fire made headway and the fact that the wood in the buildings was as dry as tinder, they were unable to stop its progress and the buildings were totally destroyed. The out-buildings however were all saved and a well organized effort was made to save as much as possible. All the records were taken out of the school, as well as the boys' clothing, the bedding, and the food supplies, also some of the furnishings. The girls however only have the clothing they were wearing, as their clothing was all stored in the building where the fire started.

The boys are now comfortably housed in the Oblate Fathers' College where there is plenty of room for them. The girls and Sisters are housed in the Town Hall and the Convent. The Town Hall is quite a comfortable building. It has a large basement which can be utilized as a kitchen and dining room, the upper floor being used for sleeping accommodation. They have their mattresses, pillows, and bedding, but none of the iron bedsteads were saved. About twenty-five of the girls were taken to the File Hills School by Indian Agent Dodds and Mr. Rhodes, Principal of the School. This is a temporary arrangement. The Reverend Father informs me that he will be able to carry on with some small assistance in the way of equipment. I have your wire this morning granting me the necessary authority to purchase same. With regard to clothing for the girls, some bulk dress goods was saved as well as several of

- the sewing machines -
the sewing machines and it may only be necessary to supply some footwear and dress material. I have a small supply of military clothing here which I will send to them at once to meet immediate pressing needs.

I have long looked upon this building as a fire trap. The Principal has been fully aware of the difficulty which would be experienced should a fire break out and I am satisfied he has continually had this in mind and has taken every precaution towards prevention. Fire stations were established throughout the institution and a watchman assigned who made regular rounds. Records of his visits to the different stations were kept on file and examined each day. This, as you know, is our oldest residential school. There are two hundred and thirty-five pupils enrolled. Ninety boys are now in the Seminary and one hundred and twenty girls in the Town Hall. The present Principal, Father Leonard, has been in charge for twelve years. When he took over the management of the school it was heavily in debt, but by careful management he has succeeded in placing it on a sound financial basis. The loss of his school is a great blow to the Reverend Principal. Management of schools has been his life work and naturally he is anxious regarding what steps will be taken to have the school replaced. In the meantime, I will keep in close touch with the situation and you may be assured that every effort will be made to safeguard the comfort and health of the Indian children.

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE THOMAS G. MURPHY

With reference to your enquiry, regarding the destruction by fire of the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret, Sask., I have to say Mr. Inspector Harrison informed the department, by telegram, that the fire occurred on Saturday night of the 13th instant. The main school buildings were completely destroyed but all outbuildings were saved, also the bedding, pillows, mattresses, baby clothing, food supplies and considerable furnishings from the main building. The girls who were attending church at the time the fire broke out have only the clothing they were wearing.

At the present time, arrangements have been made for the care of the 256 pupils who were in residence - 115 boys and 141 girls. The boys are comfortably housed in the Oblate Fathers' College, across the lake from the school, where there is plenty of room for them, while the girls and the Sisters of the staff are in the town hall at Lebret and in the convent. The work of the school can be carried on and it will not be necessary to send any children home. Authority has been granted to supply heaters, a kitchen range, dishes, knives and forks - this being the only supplies to be furnished.

In reporting on the fire, the Inspector states that it was caused through a short circuit in the lighting wires and that the insulation probably had been destroyed by a rat. A watchman was on duty at the school day and night and the lamp was last seen burning after making full enquiries, it would appear that very full precautions had been taken to insure the safety of the building. There was ample fire equipment on hand, but, in view of the rapidity with which the flames made headway and the fact that the wood in the building was as dry as tinder, it was not possible to stop the progress of the fire.

Inspector Harrison states that he is keeping in close touch with the situation and that every effort will be made to safeguard the comfort and health of the Indian children.

The building was the property of the Dominion Government. It was constructed in 1905 and 1906. I would estimate the loss to be approximately $200,000, with no insurance.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing four "Requisitions for School Material" to be used in the five class-rooms and in the office. These supplies are needed to help us carry on our work as most of our class-room supplies were lost when the school was turned over.

We did not report this directly to you as Inspector Murray came to Lebret immediately or being notified and no doubt you had his report soon after. We however wish to offer a few comments on the present conditions.

The boys were transferred to the Oblate Seminary, directly across the lake from the school, where accommodation was provided them by the Oblate Fathers. Here their conditions are much better than before as the building is more modern and they have allotted us sufficient space to accommodate all our boys, so they were able to resume their class-room work with only a very slight interruption. Of course this arrangement can only be temporary as they have given us this privilege at a great inconvenience to themselves.

The girls are located in the Town Hall. Considerable alterations were necessary but they now have comfortable quarters and further improvements are being made. As the girls' building was where the fire originated none of their clothes were saved except what they were wearing at the time. This made their condition somewhat difficult at first but they have now sufficient clothing and are very comfortable. They have the old church as a substitute and will be able to resume their studies in a few days.

As most of the boys' clothing was saved and also a large part of the equipment and furniture in the main building, we are prepared to carry on our work efficiently until such time as a new school is built, which we trust will be in the near future.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. J. Leonard

REFERENCE YOUR TELEGRAM FIRST INSTANT THERE IS NO NECESSITY FOR ERECTION OF TEMPORARY BUILDING FOR GIRLS AT LEBRET STOP ALL PUPILS COMFORTABLY HOUSED FOR WINTER PRINCIPAL OF SCHOOL CONCURS IN THIS - WRITING.

Your telegram came to me as rather a surprise in view of the fact that arrangements had already been made for the comfortable housing of both the boys and girls for the winter. I at once went to Lebret and took the matter up with the Principal, Reverend Father Leonard, who informed me that he was not aware that the Church had been asking for the building in question, and in any event if the building had been necessary the foundation of the old administration building was the last place on which it should be built.

I beg to submit the following report regarding the arrangements which have been made so that you will be in possession of the facts in connection with the situation. The Village of Lebret has handed over the Town Hall for an indefinite period to the Reverend Principal for the purpose of providing accommodation for the girls. This building is seventy feet long and I would judge over forty feet wide. It has a high ceiling and there is plenty of air space. There is a basement under one end of the building which is being used as a kitchen. The Principal

has an addition ten feet wide and seventy feet long nearly completed which will be used as a dormitory to provide sleeping accommodation for the girls. As a temporary measure wooden bunks have been built along both sides of the hall, the main portion of the hall being used also as a dining and recreation room for the girls. A laboratory has been built at one end of the building which is well ventilated and clean. Pails are provided which are emptied four and five times a day, the waste being buried in a pit. Disinfectants are freely used. The old Church is being partitioned off to provide three classrooms and classes are expected to commence on Monday next. Large fire extinguishers are placed in easily accessible positions in this building. The girls are quite comfortably housed and are enjoying the experience. I am informed that they are all putting on weight, some have gained as much as ten pounds since they have been placed in these quarters. They appear very happy and presented a healthy appearance.

The boys are housed in the Oblate Fathers' Training College across the lake. This is a large modern building and provides ample and comfortable accommodation for all the boys. The classroom work was taken up within two and one half days after the fire and was practically continued uninterrupted.

All the accommodation being used will be at the disposal of the department until such time as a new building is erected. It may be necessary next summer to erect a small frame building which can be later utilized for some other purpose, for housing a number of the larger boys who work on the farm. The site on which the old school stood is the most suitable site for the new building. In order to facilitate the work of building a new school the debris left from the fire might very well be removed during the winter months. This would save a lot of valuable time in the spring if it is the intention to proceed with the erection of a new building.

I found ninety-six boys and one hundred and eight girls present. Now that arrangements for the housing of the pupils has been completed, the balance of the children who are enrolled will be sent back to the school. The Reverend Principal has been very active in making the accommodation as satisfactory as possible.

Dear Mr. Orr:

With further reference to your letter of the 30th ultimo, I am sending forward today under separate cover one copy of the blue prints of a sketch which you had prepared of the proposed new Qu'Appelle School. I regret having held this plan for such a long period, but this was due to the Church Authorities who are anxious to have the accommodation provided according to their ideas for requirements. I may inform you that the Mother Provincial of the Order of Grey nuns prepared a sketch, a copy of the blue print of which I am also forwarding.

As explained in my letter to you of the 16th instant, it was thought that your plan does not provide for adequate accommodation. The attendance of the boys varies from 103 to 120 and the girls from 123 to 145. The Sisters' plan shows an enlargement of the two wings and also an extra story over the kitchen and boiler room wings to provide for a recreation room and extra classroom. This idea is endorsed by the Reverend Principal. According to the manner in which they have divided up the main building, the Reverend Principal is not in full agreement with the plan as prepared by the Sisters;

1. The basement plan provides, in addition to the main dining room, a small dining room for the large boys, a dining room for the small boys, and in the girl's wing a dining room for the large girls and one for the small girls in addition to the Sisters' dining room, the Fathers' dining room, and the workmen's dining room. So many dining rooms I would imagine would make a lot of work and would mean a large staff. These rooms also, in my opinion, limit the space for recreation rooms. It will be noted that more space is provided for a laundry. This is in my opinion a good idea, as they require a lot of room in their laundry. I do not think that the basement plan requires further comment.

2. With regard to the ground floor, it will be noted that the Principal's rooms have been placed on the opposite side to that shown in your sketch. The boys' dormitory is also shown on this floor, as well as the reception room and classroom over the kitchen. A wider passage is also shown connecting the wing with the main building in order to provide for a stairway leading up to the chapel.

3. With regard to the first floor, in the boys' wing, which is the North wing, the Sisters' plan shows a recreation room and two classrooms. There is a doubt in my mind as to whether these two classrooms are provided with correct lighting to comply with regulations.

R. Gurney Orr, Esq.,
Architect,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
regulations. A small boys' recreation room is also provided for and the Reverend Principal is of the opinion that this is not the proper place for it. It should be in the basement, as he thinks there would be altogether too much noise from a recreation room placed on this floor. I think his point is well taken.

4. With regard to the second floor, three dormitories are provided and the plan appears to be very well made. There is a direct entrance from the girls' and Sisters' quarters to the gallery of the chapel. At the boys' side there is a stairway leading down from the corridor directly outside the exit from the dormitories. The object the Sisters have in view is to have as much separation as possible between the male and female inmates of the institution. It will be noted that several large linen closets are provided for throughout the building. It is thought that these rooms are much better for keeping the children's clothing than the individual wooden cupboard which it has been customary to provide in the dormitories. It is the intention to have shelving in these rooms divided into individual spaces for each child's outfit. I know from experience in visiting the schools the difficulty they have in keeping fastenings and doors in repair on the wooden cupboards.

I may explain again that the building will face the West. The boys' wing therefore should be on the North side of the building, as their playground is situated on that side. The Girls' playground is on the South side of the building site and this should be kept in view when preparing the plans.

With regard to the information you ask for in your letter, I will answer the questions in the same order that you place them:

1. The existing water supply is obtained from the Lake. The shore of the lake is about 225 feet from the building site, but the pipe has to be carried for some distance out onto the lake in order to get good water. This water is not good for washing purposes and corrodes the boilers badly. A water softener would correct this and would also be a great asset.

2. The fuel used in the boiler is steam coal.

3. The existing septic tank is in good condition. The rough plan which I have already sent forward to you shows the position of it in relation to the old building. With regard to the drainage, the Provincial Health Authorities have found fault with the existing system. At present the 6" tile sewage pipe discharges into a dry creek 120 feet from the shore line of the Lake. When I examined it in the fall there was a large pool of sewage gathered which gave off a very offensive smell. By extending this tile pipe a further 200 feet and placing it underground, this difficulty would be overcome.

4. Electric power is supplied by the Montreal Engineering Company. It is an alternating current supply - 120-220 volts.

5. Regarding the nature of the soil for the footings, as far as I can ascertain it is a sort of sandy gravel but quite firm.

6. The rough sketch shows the location of the old building and has already been sent forward.
Trusting that the foregoing information may be useful to you.

Yours very truly,

W. Murison,

Dear Doctor McGill:

Replying to your letter No. 114-0-5, dated the 20th instant, in which you ask for my views as to the advisability of making a start in connection with the re-building of the Gu'Appelle School, I note that there is an item of $50,000.00 in the Estimates and if money is voted by Parliament it is the intention to erect that portion of the building consisting of the rear wing.

I may say that in my opinion it would be a fine thing if the rear wing could be erected during the coming summer, as the Chapel could be used as a girls' dormitory and the laundry as a dining room. Although the girls have been as comfortable as could be expected in the Town Hall, this building is of frame construction and has been the cause of much anxiety during the cold weather on account of the fire hazard and can only be looked upon as emergent accommodation. We were very grateful to have it under the circumstances, but I feel that before another winter sets in it would be advisable if the money is forthcoming to have the rear wing of the school erected. This would provide accommodation for the girls and no doubt the Church will continue to allow the boys to reside in the missionary across the lake. I may say I have consulted the Reverend Principal regarding this matter and he is fully in accord with me in connection with my recommendation. I can understand the difficulty which the Government would have in providing the large sum required for the erection of the entire building and would be very grateful if funds can be found for the erection of the rear wing as suggested.

Yours very truly,

W. Murison,
Inspector,

Dear Doctor McGill:

Mr. Murison and I have just returned from Lebret and we are both very uneasy about the situation of the children there.

The girls are quartered in the Town Hall, a frame building, where they are sleeping in five deck tiers of bunks. Some of them have beds on top of the ceiling of the entry-way. The kitchen is in the basement and there are one or two stoves with long lines of pipe on the main sleeping floor. The place looks very dangerous from a fire standpoint. The building is flimsy and would burn in a few minutes. I should think, in the event of fire, there would be some casualties. Of course there will be no danger from the heating stoves until cold weather comes, as the cooking range in the basement looks reasonably safe.

The boys are quartered across the lake and we did not seem to find time to see them. They are safer than the girls, but I am told that their surroundings are less healthy. They sleep in a basement and have most of their living quarters there as well.

I do not know what plans are being made in regard to the replacement of the school or any part of it and should not anticipate any great trouble before you may have an opportunity to see it for yourself, but I should think the Department ought to look forward to making some rather radical changes before cold.

Memorandum.

Honourable Thomas G. Murphy,

Re: An'Appelle Indian Residential schools.

The main buildings were totally destroyed by fire on the morning of Sunday, November 13th, 1932. All outbuildings were saved, also the bedding, pillows, mattresses, boys' clothing, food supplies and considerable furnishings. The girls were attending Church at the time of the fire and only saved the clothing they were wearing.

There were 256 pupils in residence—116 boys and 141 girls.

The boys were transferred to the Oblate Seminary directly across the lake. This is a modern building with facilities for classrooms and dormitories. The girls are located in the Town Hall in the village of Lebret, 3 miles from the school site. Considerable alterations were made to this building but the dormitory accommodation and other facilities are inadequate. In the dormitories, the girls sleep in bunks in tiers of four, one above the other. They attend classes in the old school.

The sum of $50,000 is provided in the estimates for the current fiscal year to erect one unit as an extension to the proposed main building and will comprise the heating plant, chapel and dining rooms.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

On the 2nd and 4th instant, I visited the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, in company with Inspector Hurison and Dr. Simes.

As you are aware, the school buildings were totally destroyed by fire on November 13, 1932. After the fire, arrangements were made to accommodate the girls in a building used as a town hall in the village of Fort Qu'Appelle. This is a long, narrow, wooden building. An annex was erected on one side, the full length of the building. Formerly it had housed in addition to the main hall which was over-crowded, unsanitary, and a fire-trap. The girls are sleeping in bunks, 5 tiers deep, in the main building, while in the annex, sleeping in the loft, were 54 girls. All cooking is done in the basement, located under the front entrance to the school, and the food has to be carried up narrow stairs, and into the main hall. This main hall is used as a dining-room, recreation-room, and sleeping-room. The sanitary arrangements are at the most primitive stage; there are no bathing facilities, and the children wash in a wooden trough. The odour in the building, mostly of creolin used for disinfecting purposes, was nauseating.

In the event of a fire occurring, I cannot see how any of the children or the Sisters in charge could escape. There is also great danger of an epidemic from the over-crowded, unsanitary conditions. In all my experience, I have never seen a situation such as is provided for the girls.

After fully considering the situation and consulting Inspector Hurison, Father Levesque (Principal of the School); Dr. Simes, the medical officer; Dr. Ferguson, on the Qu'Appelle Sanitarium; and the Rev. Sisters, and with the sole view of preserving the life of the children, I arranged to secure a building which, when fitted up, will meet the requirements until such time as a new school building can be erected. The building I selected is of stone construction up to the top of the first story and is shiplap above. The interior of the building is finished and has never been occupied. It is a large building with an annex on the side, which has been used as an ice cream and soft drink parlour.

This building can be obtained at a nominal rental, which the Principal of the School will undertake to pay without cost to the Department. After discussing the situation with the above-named persons, who accompanied me, and in view of the urgent necessity of providing better and more sanitary accommodation for the girls, I authorized it.

- Inspector
Inspector Murison to undertake the cost of fitting up the building. It is estimated that it will cost approximately $2,000 to install hot air heating, erect partitions, and finish the interior walls with beaver board or similar material. The annex can be used as a dining hall and the main building for sleeping and living accommodation for the girls. Mr. Murison will arrange for the purchase of material in fitting up the building and a hot air furnace for heating purposes. He will also make application, from firms on the list to receive consideration. The principal will have his own carpenter and staff do as much of the work as possible. It may be necessary to engage the services of one or two outside labourers. Mr. Murison will take this matter up with Mr. Ferley, the member for the constituency.

It was necessary to take the immediate action which I did in authorizing the obtaining and fitting up of the building. Dr. Simes and the school authorities were afraid that the Provincial Authorities would condemn the present arrangements of the girls remaining in the town hall, owing to unsanitary conditions and danger of loss of life by fire. I understand that Dr. Stone and yourself visited the school during the past summer and are familiar with the situation. I hope that the action taken by myself, after inspecting the present accommodation of the girls and after consulting the parties named, will meet with your approval. It will certainly solve the situation in providing more adequate accommodation, preventing an outbreak of illness and loss of pupils' lives, until such time as a new school building is erected. If my action is approved I will pay the necessary encumbrance raised covering the expenditure to the $50,000. As you are aware, there was $50,000 provided in our Estimates for the current year towards the construction of a new building. This amount has not been used and there is therefore ample funds to fit up the building. The Inspector and the Principal will see that all work at the lowest possible cost and will see that all material and any extra labour required are obtained from proper sources. The fitting up and use of the building will greatly help the Rev. Sisters in charge of the girls and will satisfy all concerned.

The boys are housed in a large brick veneer building used as a Scholastic, the property of the church authorities, located across the lake a distance of 3 miles by road from the town hall, used at present as a residence for the girls. The fitting up and use of the building referred to will ease the mind of all concerned and meet requirements, temporarily, for the housing of the girls.

Dear Doctor McGill:

When Mr. Sutherland was here recently we together visited Lebret with a view to arriving at some means of relieving the congestion in the sleeping accommodation for the girls.

We viewed an unfinished building from the outside which appeared to be a suitable building, if completed, for our purpose. Later on I again visited Lebret and made a thorough examination of the building and came to the conclusion that it would only partially meet our requirements and would cost a considerable sum of money to put it in shape.

When at Lebret the Church Authorities offered the use of the basement of their new stone Church, if we would put it in shape for use as a dormitory. I examined this basement thoroughly. The main basement is 50 feet wide, 100 feet long, and has a 10 foot ceiling. Attached to this building and separated by a two foot thick stone wall is a boiler room in which three furnaces are situated. The central furnace is intended for use in heating the basement only. There are four windows in each side wall and in addition eight large ventilators. This basement room I think would be ideal for our purpose and would reduce the fire hazard to a minimum.

In order to put the building in shape it will be necessary to put in a cement floor and line the walls and ceiling with plaster board. A drain pipe for the sewage disposal is already installed about the middle of the building. There is an alcove at the east end in which we could install ten or eleven toilets. I am at present engaged in getting estimates of the cost of putting this building in shape. I am of the opinion that we can dig a well 20 feet deep and 6 feet in diameter which will provide a sufficient supply of water. I am also making enquiry as to whether we could -

Memorandum: The Honorable, the Superintendent General,

In reference to the offer made by the Reverend Oblate Fathers of the Manitoba Province for rebuilding the "Appelle Indian Residential School," I beg to say that it is desirable that the school be rebuilt at the earliest possible date, and it would appear that the Department would be quite justified in taking advantage of the offer made by the Reverend Fathers, providing they would agree to a change in the amount that they would allow the Department should the building be taken over at any time.

They stipulate in their offer that the Oblate Fathers would agree to transfer the ownership of the building in payment by the Department of the total amount expended in the erection of the school, less any depreciation previously paid by the Department, which in their agreement they mention as 2½% annually of the total cost of the building. In addition to this the Department should be given credit for the reduction each year of the amount of interest due to the depreciation payments. Under this arrangement the Department would have paid at the end of 25 years £610 per thousand on depreciation and £674/10 per thousand, being the amount credited annually due to the reduction in interest, and the Department would have practically paid for the building in 25 years.

If the Department pays only the interest on the investment, deducting each year the reduction in the amount due to the depreciation payments, they would have paid at the end of 25 years £650/00 per thousand on depreciation, and would have to pay a lump sum of £860/00 per thousand in order to take over the building.

I would be in favour of the scheme as first mentioned above. The Oblate Fathers would, of course, have to erect the building in strict accordance with the plans and specifications prepared by the architect of the Department, but no doubt they would be able to build the school at considerably less cost than if same was erected by the Department, owing principally to the fact that they would not be compelled as a private concern to adhere to the Department of Labour's Fair Wage Schedule.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 114-0-5, dated the 31st ultimo, with reference to authority granted to me to expend $2,000.00 in fixing up the basement of the new stone Church at Lebret for dormitory purposes for the girls. I also acknowledge receipt of your lettergram to me dated the 25th ultimo, which I received on the 29th.

I may advise you that I have conferred with Mr. E. Perley, M.P., and have explained to him the work we have in view. Mr. Perley assured me that the programme I outlined to him as to how the work was to be carried out was quite satisfactory to him.

I proceeded to Lebret on the 30th ultimo, accompanied by Mr. Harry Potts, of Potts and Miller, Plumbers of this City, and we looked over the situation and decided on the work which was considered necessary in order to give them adequate toilets, baths, and water system. We also looked over the material salvaged from the old school after the fire and find that we have a boiler suitable for a pressure tank and also sufficient 5" cast iron soil pipe for our requirements. I, at the same time, arranged for cement and material for forms from the local lumber yard at Lebret. There is only one lumber yard and, as it was necessary to push the work and they gave me a very good price, I felt that the delay, which would be incurred in getting prices and shipping in, would not be justified; and this action met with Mr. Perley's approval. The gravel required for putting in the cement floor in the basement is being hauled by the members of the Congregation and is being provided free of cost to us.

Re Proposed contract between the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs and Les Freres Oblats du Manitoba for the construction of the Indian Residential School at Lebret, Sask.

I am enclosing tentative draft of agreement in respect to the above matter. This draft has incorporated most of the clauses contained in the form of agreement submitted by the Rev. Father Plourde. The material modifications effected by the present draft appear in its clauses 5, 4 and 7.

Clause 5 has been amended to allow the Oblats Fathers, should they so determine, to proceed without delay in financing their project. The time for doing so is considered favourable and the present period for building is propitious. Besides, the Rev. Fathers by the method suggested would be placed in the position of paying forthwith all disbursements in connection with the construction of the school, saving thereby discounts on material, etc.

Clause 4 allows the Government to obtain the ownership of the school at any time by assuming the payment of any outstanding balance on the loan of bond issue contracted for the construction of the school. This allows the bonds to be issued for the full period of twenty-five years without being subject to recall, which would somewhat depress the selling price of the bonds and entail the payment of a recall premium.

Clause 7 in the form of agreement submitted by Father Plourde was not required, as the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs could not be sought in damages for any failure of Parliament to vote the monies.

MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT made this twenty-fifth day of October, One thousand nine hundred and thirty-three,

BETWEEN:

LES PERES OBLATS DU MANITOBA,
of the First Part,

AND:

HIS MAJESTY, AS REPRESENTED BY THE SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL OF INDIAN AFFAIRS,
of the Second Part.

WHEREAS the Parties hereto have had under consideration the rebuilding of the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School which was recently destroyed by fire at Lebret, in the Province of Saskatchewan, and have agreed to the stipulations and conditions hereinafter set forth:

Now this agreement witnesseth that the said Parties have covenanted and agreed, and by these presents do covenant and agree to and with each other as follows:

1o.- Les Peres Oblats du Manitoba (or and in consideration of the provisions, compensation and stipulations hereinafter set forth) shall erect at their own expense an Indian Residential School Building, having accommodation for two hundred and fifty pupils, according to plans and specifications prepared by the architect of the Department of Indian Affairs, upon the property of the Party of the Second Part, on a site to be selected by the architect of the Department of Indian Affairs adjacent to the site occupied by the school building recently destroyed by fire at Lebret; and subject however to the expenses provided hereinabove, the contract must first be approved by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, and subject to the further proviso that the building shall be erected under the supervision and to the satisfaction of the architect of the Department of Indian Affairs;

2o.- The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, in consideration of the faithful performance by Les Peres Oblats du Manitoba of the covenants and stipulations recited in the previous paragraph, agrees that when the Indian Residential School is completed it shall be operated and used solely as an Indian Residential School under the direction and management of the said Les Peres Oblats du Manitoba, subject to all the Department's Rules and Regulations governing the operation of the Department's Indian Residential Schools;

3o.- Les Peres Oblats du Manitoba shall call for tenders for the construction of the said school according to the plans and specifications prepared by the architect of the Department of Indian Affairs as hereinabove provided, and the lowest of said tenders, if reliable, shall be accepted subject, however, to the approval of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
Affairs. The Superintendent General shall pay to Les Peres Oblats du Manitoba, for a period of twenty-five years to be computed from the date of acceptance of the said tender, five per centum (5%) per annum payable semi-annually for interest charges, and two and a half per centum (2½%) per annum payable annually as part repayment on the construction cost of the said school as fixed by the said accepted tender, to which cost shall be added an amount sufficient to cover the expenses incidental to the said building, and required to provide the funds for the said construction and insurance charges during the said period of twenty-five years; the whole subject however to this condition that the total amount upon which such interest and part payments are made shall not exceed Two hundred and ten thousand dollars ($210,000.00);

4. It is also agreed that if at any time the Superintendent General should wish to obtain the ownership of the said Les Peres Oblats du Manitoba shall transfer the said ownership to him subject, however, to the Superintendent General assuming to pay to the release and discharge of Les Peres Oblats du Manitoba any outstanding balance on the loan made or bonds issued to defray the cost of the said building;

5. It is further agreed that the Department of Indian Affairs will be responsible for all major repairs to the building during the time of this agreement, subject to the same regulations as other Indian Residential Schools;

6. This agreement shall, subject to the prior taking over of the building by the Superintendent General, as above provided, remain in full force and effect until such time as the payments made under the terms of this agreement and credits above referred to aggregate the total cost of the building, as hereinabove specified;

7. Les Peres Oblats du Manitoba shall have the right to convey, transfer and make over the monies payable by His Majesty, under the present agreement, in order to secure any loan made to cover the cost of the said construction and expenses inherent thereto, subject to the conditions and limitations hereinabove recited.

In witness whereof the Parties have hereunto affixed their corporate seals as evidenced by the signatures of their proper officers.
Dear Mr. Williams:

I have received and examined the copy of the draft agreement which you submitted in connection with the building of the Indian School at Lebret, Saskatchewan.

In general it seems to me that the contract should be drawn in more precise and definite legal terms, and I would suggest that it would be desirable to submit the contract to the Department of Justice for their approval from the point of view of the sufficiency of legal form. In this connection I may say that we make a practice of submitting important contracts of this type to the Department of Justice.

The most important point in which I think the contract needs amplification is that dealing with the cost of the building. I think the contract should itemize the details which are to be included in cost, including cost of financing (details to be properly itemized), and that the cost of financing as well as the whole financing contract should be subject to approval by the Government. In this connection it appears to me unusual to capitalize insurance charges during the life of the building, and it would seem preferable to take care of this item by periodic payments.

Clause No.4 should be subject to reconsideration from the point of view of wording and possibly "The Government of the Dominion of Canada" should be substituted for "Superintendent General" where this phrase occurs in this clause.

Probably it will be necessary to provide for supervision of the cancellation of bonds as they are paid off, though this may be covered adequately.
in the financing contract, which will be subject to approval.

Yours very truly,

A. S. Williams, Esquire,

Sir:-

I enclose herewith Regina Voucher No. 4, amounting to $1054.60 in favor of Messrs. Potts and Miller, Limited, of Regina, for labour performed and material supplied in connection with the installation of toilets, baths, water system and sewage disposal system with reference to the accommodation provided for the girls of the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret.

Owing to the fact that it would have been difficult to outline specifications for the work and that it was necessary for me to accompany Mr. Potts to the school on three occasions in order to outline the work, I did not obtain competitive prices and after consulting with Mr. Perley, M.P., and explaining the situation I engaged Mr. Potts to proceed with the work on a percentage plus cost basis. No written agreement was entered into. We were able to salvage considerable material from the old building and the actual cost of the completed work is approximately $300.00 less than it was anticipated when the work was commenced.

The Church basement is now being occupied, but the work in connection with the old Church which is being converted into a kitchen, dining, and recreation room is not yet completed. Care is being taken to see that the amount authorized for this work will not be exceeded.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,

MEMORANDUM

The Honourable the Superintendent General -

Mr. Orr, Architect of the Department,
is leaving Saturday night, February 17th, for
Qu'Appelle, Sask., for the purpose of discussing
plans and arrangements in connection with the
erection of an Indian Residential school at Lebret.
He will be absent about a week.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Feb. 7, 1934.

Dr. H. W. McGill,
Deputy-Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.,

My dear Doctor McGill:

I have just discussed the problem of the proposed new Indian School at Lebret, Saskatchewan, with Mr. W. Murison, Inspector of Indian Agencies and with Doctor R. G. Ferguson, Director of the Anti-Tuberculosis League of this province and his associate Dr. Symes. I thought it well to write to you at once and set forth our views on this important project.

To begin with, let me say that I am in full sympathy with Doctor Ferguson in his endeavour to provide anti-tubercular protection for our Indian children as well as proper care for those now infected with the disease. His plan of a sanatorium at Lebret for Catholic children in conjunction with the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School and another at Mile Hills for non-Catholic Indian children seems to be quite necessary for reasons that you will easily understand. I saw tentative plans of the proposed new building for this work. They are suitable though quite modest and will not entail any great expenditure of money, about $40,000.

We have moreover discussed together the main school building and requirements for present needs. After looking over the situation from every viewpoint, it seems most advisable and even necessary to build according to the revised plan sent you by Mr. Murison in February 1935. The truth is that the Indian school population of the Qu'Appelle district has increased and this is likewise true of other districts such as that covered by the Crooked Lake and Duck Lake Schools as well as others. Hence, it is that although theoretically there might be an exchange of pupils to fill the places left by the tubercular children taken to Lebret, in practice, it will be found that the same accommodation would be necessary as heretofore in the main building. Moreover if the present revised plans were cut, the difference in cost would be relatively slight, and the result would not be satisfactory. I, therefore, most strongly recommend that the sanatorium as proposed by Dr. Ferguson be provided and that the revised plan sent you by Mr. Murison last February be adopted as a suitable main building. If this can
be done,—and I am sure it can with your kind co-operation—the double problem of sanitary protection for tubercular children and the rebuilding of the historic Indian School of Lebret will be solved to the complete satisfaction of all concerned and for the lasting benefit and welfare of our dear Indian children.

I recall with pleasure your kindness to me two years ago when I visited your office shortly after the burning of the School. I hope that you are very well, and that you may find it possible to solve the Lebret problem along the lines above indicated.

With every kind wish, I am,

Yours very devotedly,

[Signature]

Archbishop of Regina.

P.S. I am writing to the Rt. Honourable Prime Minister along these lines today.
February 12th, 1934.

Most Reverend Sir,

I am in receipt of your favour of February 7th, for which I desire to thank you. I may say that the matters dealt with in your letter will receive the sympathetic consideration of the Department.

The subject of the rebuilding of the Lebret school has given the Department much concern and I would ask Your Grace to accept my assurance that we still hope to reach a solution satisfactory to all concerned.

May I express my pleasure and appreciation of your kind reference to the incident of your visit to the Department some two years ago. I have also a very pleasant recollection of meeting Your Grace in the village of Lebret on the 2nd of July last.

Faithfully yours,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

This office has been maintained in Regina for twenty-five years except for the four years of the war when both my partner at that time, F.C. Clomesho, and myself served overseas with the C.E.F.

In Regina, this office has designed and supervised the erection of some of the most important schools and churches, together with work at St Chad's College, Nurses Home of the Regina General Hospital, and the Masonic Temple.

The Royal Architectural Institute of Canada having in mind the serious unemployment existing amongst Architects and Draughtsmen, have already approached the Government to place as much architectural work as possible with the practicing Architects throughout the Dominion.

When he asked for the ceiling I informed him that the cost would exceed the amount allowed for renovations at the school, and he stated that if the Department desired it, he would refund the amount by which the appropriation was exceeded. I expect that the value of the material returned will amount to about $60.00, which when received will mean an over-expenditure of $75.00 over the amount of the appropriation.

NEW LEBRET SCHOOL TO COST $500,000

Construction of a new superintendency and day schools at Lebret, east of Regina, will cost $500,000.

Work will be started shortly under the direction of the federal department of Indian affairs. Plans are under way by architects, following a recent visit to Lebret by a department official from Ottawa.

Construction will be part of the $40,000,000 federal public works program.

Indian day schools and other buildings at Lebret were destroyed by fire 18 months ago.

First school at Lebret was built in 1889 and figured in early history of the prairies when Father Hugonard was a pioneer missionary. The original building was burned in 1904, rebuilt, and the second structure remained in use until destruction in 1932.

The new buildings will be of fireproof construction.

Dear Sir,

The Executive of the Regina Builders Exchange have recently had a meeting to discuss the wage situation for the present year. It has come to the notice of our Members that smaller contractors, not members of our Exchange, have been paying ridiculously low wages, in some cases as low as 15 or 20¢ per hour. This has made it almost impossible for our Members to obtain any of the smaller work against such competition and as a matter of fact most of the work in the last year has been small work.

Despite these facts our Members feel that no real progress towards recovery can be made by cutting rates to a point below a living wage and owing to the length of the winter season in this Province, hourly rates are of necessity somewhat higher than in places where work can be carried on nearly all the year round.

In view of these facts our Members have decided that the rates set up by this Exchange last year are fair and reasonable and have adopted the same rates for the year 1924. We append a copy of these rates for your information.

Should these rates not meet with your approval we think it advisable, when calling for tenders on any work, that your specification clearly cover the rates to be paid as it is the intention of our Exchange to use these rates when figuring any work where no specific rates are mentioned.

Re-Q'Appelle Indian School, Letret.

We would appreciate a ruling on the height of the concrete basement foundation wall, as there would appear to be some discrepancy between the floor level as shown on the elevation and the section as shown on sheet No.12 and No.15.

Referring to my letter of Jan.15th.,1933 to Sup't General and your reply of Jan.27th.,1933.

We understand that the Contract is about to be let and would remind you of our request of Jan.15th/33 asking you that wherever possible local men be allowed to work.

Conditions are not any better than in January 1933 and we still have 60 or 70 families of Half-breeds facing the winter with little or nothing earned from Harvest-work.

You kind co-operation towards seeing that Local Labor will be employed on the excavation and reconstruction of the above mentioned School will be greatly appreciated as a Relief Measure. Dear Sirs:

I understand that tenders are being called for the construction of a new Indian School at Lebret, Saskatchewan, and that it is probable that the work will proceed immediately the contract has been awarded.

The Department of Public Health of this Province is endeavouring to control more closely the discharge of waste water into the Qu'Appelle Lakes and to see that suitable treatment is provided for such liquid wastes.

The discharge of waste liquids from the Lebret Industrial School has not been satisfactory for a number of years and it is the desire of the Department that provision be made when reconstructing this school for a new system of sewage treatment and disposal.

Of late years sewage from the school has been discharged through a septic tank and into an underground field which for a long period has been imperative and the partially treated liquid has found its way out on the ground surface through a ditch into the lake.

I would be glad if you would advise the Department as to the maximum number of pupils and staff who will be using this building and I would appreciate receiving copies of any plans which have been prepared providing for an adequate and efficient system of treatment of the sewage and of the discharge of the effluent into the lake in such a manner that no possible criticism can be made.

Mr. R. H. Murray, the Director of the Division of Sanitation of this Department, would appreciate the opportunity of discussing the subject with your representative should any of your technical staff be visiting Regina.

Yours very truly,

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill.

Re Lebret School.

The Minister is in receipt of a letter calling his attention to the fact that no provision is made in the specifications that labour and material shall be local, as far as possible, although the Department of Public Works is said to be insisting on this in connection with its work in Saskatchewan.

The Minister's correspondent represents that residents of Regina are being dismissed from their employment on work in Prince Albert Park, under the Department of Indian Affairs, on the grounds that the work in the Park is being conducted under the Public Works Department and must be given to local residents. In this he is apparently in error, as the work in the Park is being undertaken by the Department of the Interior.

It is represented that the material for the Lebret School is specified to be Canadian, and in one case at least - that of the bath-room lining - specifications call for an article similar to that produced by a Toronto firm.

It is also said that contractors are being told to tender for face brick at $25.00 per thousand, and that no brick of that kind can be had in Western Canada, except possibly from a bankrupt concern in Alberta, who may be selling its stock at bankrupt prices. Hollow tile is supplied in Saskatchewan by two firms.
The Minister's correspondent had entertained the hope that the contractor's would be instructed to use local material and local labour wherever possible, but the specifications are alleged to be wide open. It is further stated that the re-enforcing concrete is specified as "truss-contraction", and that had the specifications provided for composite construction re-enforcing as an alternative, other firms would have been afforded an opportunity to share in the work. The writer enquires as to the possibility of having the contractors instructed on all of these points.

Will you kindly let the Minister have a memorandum which will enable him to reply.

Private Secretary.
Memorandum

Doctor McGill,

With reference to the attached memorandum regarding the Lebret School, I beg to say that all the materials for this building are specified to be of Canadian manufacture. If same can be procured in Canada, there are no special materials specified for bathroom lining. I presume that the writer of the letter meant the interior finish of kitchen and scullery, which is specified to be finished in white glazed brick, similar to that manufactured by the Don Valley Brick Company of Toronto. To my knowledge the Don Valley Brick Company are the only firm in Canada manufacturing the enamelled brick suitable for this purpose. There are no bricks of this nature being manufactured in Western Canada.

The specifications provide that the contractor shall supply face brick at $25.00 per thousand. I have been informed that there are bricks manufactured in the Province of Saskatchewan suitable for this work which will not exceed the above amount.

Referring to the reinforced concrete work I am unable to give an explanation of the term "truss-contraction". The form in which the specifications were prepared for the reinforced concrete for this building make it possible for all firms manufacturing reinforcing materials to have an opportunity of submitting prices.

Architect.

Dear Sir,

A contract was awarded this week to Smith Bros. and Wilson Ltd of Regina for the building of the new Indian Residential School at Lebret.

A letter has been received from the Department of Health of the Province of Saskatchewan objecting to the discharge of waste liquids from the Lebret Indian School into the Qu'Appelle Lakes. It will, therefore, be necessary to remodel the present septic tank or construct a new one. I would ask you to instruct Mr. Gow to visit the Lebret School and make a complete survey with report and estimate for a sewage disposal system, and an adequate water supply system.

It would also be advisable for Mr. Gow to consult with the Deputy Minister of Health for Saskatchewan before he makes his survey and report.

The department has also under consideration the building of a new hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle. It is the intention to have plans prepared this winter and invite tenders early in the spring. While Mr. Gow is at Lebret it would be advisable for him to look over the site of the proposed hospital and submit his recommendations for a sewage disposal system and water supply system. If he will consult with Doctor Simes, the Department's Medical Officer at Fort Qu'Appelle he will give him the necessary information as to the site.

If Mr. Gow will apply to Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies at Winnipeg he will furnish him with a blue print copy of the plans and specifications for the School building. I may say that accommodation is provided for 250 children and a staff of approximately 25.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

re Indian Residential School, Lebret.

I have to acknowledge with thanks the receipt of your telegram of the 26th inst; by which I am temporarily appointed Supervising Architect for the above-named building.

Upon receipt of your message I immediately called upon Messrs Smith Bros of Wilson and motored to Lebret with Mr. Smith. We arrived there about noon, looked over the site, and also examined certain gravel pits from which it is intended to obtain material for concrete aggregates and sand for brickwork and plastering. There appears to be an ample supply of good quality material of this nature near at hand.

The job superintendent was present, establishing setting-out lines, and two carloads of contractor's equipment arrived whilst we were there.

On returning to Regina, I obtained a set of the plans and specifications for preliminary perusal, but must return them to the contractors, and shall be glad if you will supply me with a set for my own use on the job at your earliest convenience.

Several matters were brought up regarding the work whilst at Lebret, but not having seen the documents, except for a few minutes, I was not able to deal with them intelligently.

It is my intention to return to Lebret on Monday the 29th inst; and remain continuously on the work, so that any prints and correspondence you may have to send me, should be addressed there.

I note that you intend to be at Lebret on November 8th, and shall be pleased to have the opportunity to meet with you there and talk over in person, the management of the work.

Your obedient Servant

H. Dawson.

Dear Sir,

I beg to advise you that you have been appointed supervising architect for the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret. You will be paid for your services at the rate of 2½ percent of the cost of the building, and payments will be made to you at various times based on the amount of the progress certificates submitted for payments on the contract.

You will be expected to work continuously during all working hours during the construction of the building, in order to see that the work is carried out in a first-class manner, and strictly in accordance with the plans and specifications.

If it is not possible for you to spend all of your time on the work you will be required to employ a Clerk of Works to act in your place, under your instructions, his salary to be paid by you.

During the course of the work you should submit fortnightly addressed to the Architect of the Department a report giving full particulars as to the progress of the work. It will also be your duty to issue the necessary certificates for payments to the contractor. You will note by the specifications that the Department pays up to 90% of the value of the labour and material in the building at the time that the certificate is issued. Certificate forms for this purpose will be supplied you.

I would like to particularly point out that under no consideration will the department allow payment for any extra work over the contract price, unless the same has been authorized in writing by the Architect of the Department.

Dear Sir,

Qu'Appelle Indian School, Lebret.

I beg to submit my second fortnightly report on the progress of work at the above building.

Weather continued favourable on the whole, since my last report, though night temperatures dropped occasionally to zero, and cloudy days with cold winds during the latter part of the period, interfered with concrete work.

All the crushed rock aggregate for the job has been delivered.

All column footings and outside wall footings are now in place, and concrete walls up to 18" above grade, have been poured at the north end of the building, from column 60 to column 2. Formwork has been erected for all outside basement walls except surrounding the boiler room and a small portion of the walls of kitchen and laundry section. Column steel was set in position for all columns in outside walls of main building. The job was closed down on Friday the 23rd. inst; all unfilled forms being braced and covered up to prevent snow drifting into them, and everything left in good shape for a fast start when spring opens up.

It is the intention of the contractors to do as much work as possible during the winter, on beam and column formwork, here in Regina, to be shipped ready for erection, in order to speed up the preparation for concrete work in the spring.

Your obedient Servant

H. Dawson,

Dear Sir,

Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret.

In accordance with your instructions, I beg to submit my first fortnightly report on the progress of construction on the above-named building.

Two weeks ago, the contractors began demolition of such of the old walls as were found to interfere with their plant-lay-out, clearing away rubbish, and starting excavation for new footings trenches and basement.

Forms were made and placed, and concrete work commenced about 2-30 p.m. on Wednesday Nov. 7th. This work continued each day to Saturday Nov. 10th. The weather was clear and mild in the daytime with some frost at nights. All fresh concrete was covered up with cement sacks and canvas at the close of each day's run, and is kept covered until necessary to remove the coverings for the erection of wall forms. When work ceased at 2-30 p.m. Saturday last, there had been approximately 118 cubic yards of concrete poured, all interior column bases except three, and all wall footings except the boiler room and south end included between columns 17 and 62, being then in place.

With further reference to the foundation for column 68, discussed when you were here on the 8th inst; I enclose copy of letter sent to Messrs Smith Bros & Wilson on that day. On further investigation, however, it appears that if this column were omitted and a 24'0" span beam substituted, it would have to be 4'0" deep, which would interfere with door heights in the basement. For this reason, it has been decided to cut out a strip of the slab over the old septic tank and put in a concrete subfoundation re-inforced with five lengths of 6" steel I-beams, spanning over the walls of the tank. The concrete forming the tank appears to be very sound and hard, judging by the work being done on it by the air compressor. The steel I-beams are on the job for this work.

Father Leonard was consulted today, and he is agreeable to having the ash hoist installed in the n.w.corner of the boiler room, using the platform tree with a pit 1'-9" deep, the window in the west side of the boiler room being converted into a door for the removal of ashes. The wall footings adjoining the pit on two sides are being placed 1'-9" lower to form the sides of the pit.

Form construction for the walls is proceeding, and if weather stays good an attempt will be made to pour the curtain walls before freeze-up.

Yours very truly

H. Dawson,
Supervising Architect
Automatic Shutters for Ventura Fans

Automatic Shutters are used in connection with disc type fans as a protection to fan when not running, and to keep out wind, rain, snow and cold.

Shutters are constructed of rolled aluminum leaves attached to steel rods supported in a steel frame.

Each leaf of the shutter is edged with a felt strip tightly folded into the metal which prevents the shutter from "rattling" when fan is not in use.

The force of the air when fan is running holds the shutter open. When fan is shut off, shutter closes automatically by gravity. It is advisable to use an automatic shutter whenever the fan is installed in an outside wall. They automatically close the opening outside the fan at night or at any other time, when the fan is not in use.

re Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret.

You will have received from Messrs Smith Bros & Wilson a copy of their letter to me dated Dec. 12th, submitting quotations on various changes numbered 1 to 8, and I wish to say, in further explanation, that these were suggested when I interviewed the Sister Superior and Rev. G. Leonard, regarding the glazing of interior doors opening on to the corridors.

Change #1 is illustrated on the larger of the enclosed blue prints, and is required in order that the Engineer may have access to his room without having to pass through the Senior Boys' Dining Room.

Change #2 is also shown on the same blue print, and appears to be necessary, as the senior boys will be under control of male supervisors, and the junior boys under the care of the Sisters, and to provide more complete separation. The outside entrance, Father Leonard points out, is an advantage in the event of visiting sports teams requiring wash-room accommodation, without having to enter other parts of the building.

Change #3. The Sisters wish to convert the closing room next to the Girls' Dormitory on 1st floor into a Sisters' Bedroom, and use one of the other bedrooms as a clothing room. They wish to have an observation window in the partition between this room and the Dormitory.

Change #4. The Sisters are of opinion that two toilets are necessary, where only one is shown in the Boys' Dormitory near the centre of the building.

Change #5. They would also prefer an additional toilet on the Girls' side in place of the Slop sink now shown. This involves a change of the lay-out to obtain more convenient access to the two toilets, and this, with change #4, is shown on the small blue print enclosed.

I understand that the interior bathroom will be used by the staff, and not by the pupils. It therefore seems unnecessary to have a partition between the bath and toilet, so I have shown a re-arrangement to arrive at a simpler piping lay-out. In this connection, there is a slight difference in the concrete framing lay-out and the original plan, in the locations of columns 27 and 33, making it necessary to change the positions of the door into the staff bath room, and that into the closet adjoining the staff bedroom. As shown on the original plan, the bathroom door appears to collide with col. 33.

Change #6. A sink is asked for in the Girls' Dining Room as in the Sisters' Dining Room, to save much carrying to and fro of dishes which could then mostly be washed where in frequent use. This would be placed where it could be most conveniently attached to the existing arrangements.

Canadian-Made Stoker in Winnipeg apartment affords marked saving and even temperature burning Western Coal

"If you go into an apartment block and you see a man with a worried look on his face, you can bet your life he's the caretaker."

Such is the situation in which one Winnipeg caretaker summed up the difficulties peculiar to apartment block heating. With more than 27 years experience behind him, he knows how essential it is to maintain an even and adequate temperature.

As soon as the temperature in an apartment block is allowed to vary, the tenants complain. Some find it too cold, although they may be the ones who leave their windows open and allow storm sash to freeze so that they cannot be closed. Others find it too hot, and they complain that the caretaker fails to blame their illnesses on the blocks in which they live.

In the case of older blocks, it is extremely unnecessary to provide any form of heating control because tenants often welcome an excuse to move into another block where they expect heating will meet their wishes. The apartment block owner, however, finds that the complaints of other tenants have satisfied customers in order to operate on a profitable basis.

Tenants Well Satisfied

At the Touraine Apartments in Winnipeg where Mr. E. Sewall is in charge, the difficulty has been overcome by the installation of automatically controlled stokers. Not only is an even temperature maintained to the satisfaction of all tenants but it is being done at a saving in fuel cost alone of 30 per cent. Instead of burning 1,600 pounds of coal daily before Western Canada coal is burned entirely. In addition, Mr. Sewall is now able to spend the greater part of his time doing work in which he is interested, such as painting, cleaning, and regulating the boiler.

The Touraine is one of Winnipeg's larger downtown blocks, owned by the Great West Construction Company and located at the corner of Kennedy and Ellice. Built a number of years ago, it contains 36 two and three room suites distributed over five floors.

The Boiler Plant

The heating plant consists of one H.L.T. type boiler made by the Robb Engine Company, Amherst, N.S. It measures 48 inches by 14 feet, has 52 three inch tubes and is rated at 50 hp.

At the end of September, 1931, a Canadian Fire-King underfeed stoker, made by the Manitoba Bridge & Iron Works Limited, was installed. It is Model No. 50, having the following four features: minimum per hour consumption, 83 lbs.; maximum, 167 lbs.; and maximum, 250 lbs. It has a steam radiation capacity of 6,200 square feet and a hopper capacity of 650 lbs. Its fan capacity is 750 c.f.m., and it is equipped with static pressure control.

A 15 inch concrete pit was constructed in which the stoker was placed. This pit has concrete curbing to prevent drainage of water into it and was made sufficiently large to permit cleaning the fire box easily. The pit was necessary to obtain sufficient air in the combustion chamber.

Pressure control automatically starts and stops the stoker, entering at one pound pressure and shutting out at two and a half pounds pressure. In addition, a special automatic time switch has been installed by Mr. Sewall himself.

Time Switch in Addition to Pressure Control

The time switch which was installed at a cost of less than $10 has proven extremely valuable in this type of operation. As is customary in apartment blocks, the temperature is allowed to drop after 11 p.m. If Mr. Sewall wishes to go out for the evening, he sets the time clock to cut out at that hour or any other hour desired, and he need not concern himself about the boiler.

If, however, the temperature should drop in his absence, and the tenants require heat, the boiler will start and maintain the independent operation of the pressure control, so that the suites are kept warm.

Heat is turned off at five o'clock in the morning but even then it is not necessary for Mr. Sewall to get up. Before retiring, or any time during the day, he has merely to set the time clock for five o'clock and at that hour the next morning the stoker goes to work. When Mr. Sewall rises a few hours later he finds steam up and the entire building comfortable and heated.

During the cold winter months, clinkers are cleaned out once in 24 hours and then only 2 pailfuls are taken out.

Fuel Savings

Some idea of the savings the stoker has effected may be gained from the following annual fuel costs:

| Year | Cost |
|------|------|
| 1929-30 | $2,650.55 |
| 1930-31 | $1,912.70 |
| 1931-32 | $1,341.77 |

The saving over the previous years operation was the substantial figure of $857.05.

Mr. Sewall cannot speak too highly of his stoker equipped boiler. He spends little or no time tending the boiler and is able to devote his time to general work throughout the building. Previous to the installation of the stoker a night man was needed to fire the boiler. His services are no longer required and Mr. Sewall has realized a further important saving, bringing the total saving up to 40 per cent.

The stoker operates quietly and notwithstanding the fact that there are only seven rooms and above are occupied suites, yet on no occasion has there been a complaint against the hum of the motor.

During the winter, several Western coals were fired and Mr. Sewall says that operation has been entirely satisfactory with Sanderson Creek mine run, rumney nut peat slack, Red River Creek, Black Rock and Drumheller coals. In previous years American coal had been used exclusively.

Such is what has been accomplished in the Touraine Apartment Building. The benefits have been extended to the entire satisfaction of all tenants with coal from Western Canada rather than the United States and at least 40 per cent below that of previous years. Mr. Sewall has no worries in his boiler room; his work is handled and reduced and his time is now devoted to work and maintenance in other parts of the block.

WHETHER it is a business block, a school, an apartment or a hospital, almost every building presents its own particular problems. Boilers are very often called on to deliver more steam than they have been designed to supply. Fuel costs change as new sources of supply are developed. The most experienced engineers find that their equipment is not producing steam as economically as the most modern plants in the country.

One of the major problems which has faced the Western Canada coal industry for years is the fact that many of the business blocks, hotels and apartments in the West were constructed with boilers built in the East where American practice was principally used. With their small grate areas and low settings, these boilers were not suited for the efficient burning of Western coal.

In recent years, many of these plants have been improved. Settings have been raised, grates have been changed, stokers have been installed, or forced draft systems have been added.

Spencer Magazine Type Heater Equipped With Stoker

Changes of this nature have greatly reduced heating costs at the Westmoreland Apartments, Winnipeg. In December, 1932, a Canadian Fire-King Automatic Pressure Control Stoker by the Manitoba Bridge & Iron Works Limited was installed. The boiler is a Spencer Magazine Type Heater, No. 10-4, rated by the manufacturer at 100 h.p., with standard radiators.

This type boiler is equipped with water tubes in each side of the fire-box down to the level of the grate. The grate slope upward toward the rear at an angle of approximately 45 degrees where they are supported by an internal water-leg, which brings the boiler return back to the front header of the boiler.

Historically, it has been considered impracticable to stoke this type boiler, because of the high temperature flames impinging on the water tubes and water-leg. Canadian-Made Stoker Cuts Fuel Costs

Medical Arts Building in Winnipeg finds coal is most economical and satisfactory fuel

Substantial savings in fuel costs have been made at the Medical Arts Building in Winnipeg as a result of its two boilers being equipped with underfeed stokers. Canadian coal is being burned instead of American coal as before, the boilers are being operated at higher efficiencies and the entire installation has met with the satisfaction of the management.

The Medical Arts Building presents certain heating problems peculiar to itself. Its entire space is occupied by physicians and their families, approximately 180, therefore, essential that adequate and uniform temperatures are maintained irrespective of weather conditions.

The building was erected in 1923 and was originally four stories and basement. Three floors had three more stories were added although no alterations were made to the boiler plant. This brought actual radiation up to 8,500 square feet. With the opening of the additional stories, walls were extended and heat efficiency improved although high-grade American coal was fired. Furthermore, the building is not fitted with storm windows which, on cold and windy days, creates a heavy demand for steam.

Hot Water Makes Heavy Demands

Maintaining an adequate supply of hot water also makes heavy demands on the boilers. One hundred and thirty doctors, who occupy the building, sometimes use as much as 500 gallons in an hour. There are two hot water tanks each of 1,000-gallon capacity and are heated from an average temperature of 40 degrees to 160 degrees.

By itself at the rear of the building is a warehouse measuring 26x34 feet. It is constructed of tile and stucco and although a considerable heating, it has been unusually high ceiling. This building is also heated by the Medical Arts plant and requires a considerable volume of steam especially when the doors are open or in the winter when stock is being loaded or unloaded. However, since the stokers were installed last September all problems have been overcome and the boilers that were somewhat inadequate prior to the installation have been able to meet any demands placed upon them.

The boilers used are the Vulcan type, rectangular type made by the Vulcan Iron Works Limited. They are 48 inches in diameter, 14 feet long, have 52 three-inch diameter tubes and are each rated at 40 h.p. They are on a twin brick setting and each have a radiation of 3,200 square feet.

Canadian Fire-King Stokers

The two automatic underfeed stokers are No. 50 Canadian Fire-Kings made in Winnipeg by the Manitoba Bridge & Iron Works Limited. Each has a steam radiation capacity of 6,250 square feet and are capable of feeding per hour as follows: First, feet 85 lbs. of coal; second, feet, 170 lbs.; and third, feed, 250 lbs.

Each stoker has a fan capacity of 750 cubic feet per minute at two-inch static pressure.

Special control provides for a combination pressure control and low water shut-off. The pressure control automatically starts and stops these stokers at boiler pressure while the low water shut-off cuts off the stoker if water in the boilers happens to fall below the minimum level as required by Government regulations.

In order to obtain sufficient height and combustion space, the stokers were installed in a 15-inch pit.

Only Western Canada Coal Used

Since the installation of the stokers nothing other than Western Canada coal has been burned although under the old hand-drum system only high-grade imported American coal could be used to obtain satisfactory results. A great deal of
experimenting has been done since the stokers were put in to determine what Western coals would yield the best results taking into consideration special factors surrounding the plant. Several Western coals have been used with satisfactory results at prevailing prices. An approximate analysis of a nut pea slack that has shown very good results is as follows:
