Despite all the experimentation with coal ranging in cost up to $9.50 per ton, an actual saving of $546 has been made for the period from October 1 to February 29, as compared with last year. Figures of course, cover only entire periods during which the stokers were in operation and are the latest available figures. Figures submitted by Mr. J. L. Hewitt, manager of the Medical Arts Building, to the board of directors show that the saving over the five-months' period a year ago had been $2,512. Corresponding figures submitted to the board of directors showed that fuel costs during the last five months when the two stokers were in operation had been $1,966. It is expected that the plant will show even more substantial savings now that experimental work has been completed.

This heat, even on coldest days, heat has been maintained at the same uniform temperature under all conditions. This, as already explained, is absolutely essential in a building where patients are being examined who, in many cases are required to entirely disrobe.

The stokers running on first feed have proven fully capable of heating the building in normal winter weather, the length of time they were run out varying. In fact, however, it was found necessary during the month of February, they were operated on second feed. At no time have they been operated in high speed.

An adequate supply of water at 160 degrees F. has been maintained since the stokers were installed although it was always difficult to do so under the old hand-firing system.

When warehouse doors were left open for the time the plant was shut down, it became necessary for a fireman to stand over the boilers in order to keep the building's temperature from dropping. Now, the stokers are put in second feed while loading and unloading materials in the warehouses and in this way temperature is maintained without extra effort. The engineer and firemen now spend only a small part of their time in the boiler room and are able to spend considerable time attending to other matters in the building and in taking care of offices.

The two boilers have been operated at 150 per cent of their rating and have yielded an efficiency of 70 per cent.

Frank S. Coffey, engineer in charge of the Medical Arts Building, is more than satisfied with the operation of the two stokers. Not only have they made possible the economies in the heating plant but a notable decrease in heating costs but they have also made possible the displacement of a considerable tonnage of American coal by coal from Western Canada's mines.

On opening the boilers there is usually a thin film of sediment, which is easily washed out with a hose. After this the plates are brushed and the inside of the drum given a thin coating of Graphite Red Lead and Boiled Oil. This is to prevent a possibility of corrosion which is liable to occur in any boiler where the principal load is a heating load, and the boiler is fed with the returns from the heating system.

2. We had no Refinite Water Softener in the old plant. The boilers in this plant were taken out of service for cleaning every two or three weeks. They usually had a moderately heavy coating of scale, which had to be chipped out where accessible. The tubes could not be cleaned properly and there was a heavy scale in places. When the new power plant was built a water softener was installed at the same time.

3. The old boilers were discarded. They were so badly corroded in places that they were considered unsafe for further use.

4. We do not experience any difficulty in foaming or priming.

5. We have never replaced any boiler tubes or fittings in the new plant except some small valves attached to the water column. This is a good record considering the boilers have been in service eight years. We frequently had to replace boiler tubes in the old plants.

6. It is difficult to answer this question as the saving would depend upon actual condition of boilers before installing a water softener. Boiler scale is very impervious to heat transmission, and a comparatively thin coating of scale will reduce boiler efficiency to a great extent. Tests have been made showing that 1/16 inch average thickness of scale will reduce boiler efficiency from 10 to 12%, but for a number of reasons, which I need not enter into, the results of tests of this kind vary considerably. REFINITE MINERAL THE STANDARD OF COMPARISON

The essential element on which depends the success or failure of any water softening plant is the kind of mineral used.

The minerals available for water softeners are limited to three kinds. They are: Refinite, Green Sand, and the artificial or synthetic minerals. Since we are the exclusive owners of deposits and patents covering Refinite, all other manufacturers are limited to a choice of one of the other kinds. Actual comparison proves that no mineral yet discovered or manufactured has given over a period of years the capacity and economical results which Refinite users have obtained.

Green Sand, which comes from New Jersey, contains about 25% iron, which in time has a corrosive action. Many firms find it necessary to remove Green Sand after two or three years use. This zeolite has a much smaller capacity than Refinite.

Synthetic, or manufactured mineral does not run uniform in quality, and being made from chemicals it disintegrates in water slowly and loses its capacity for softening water.

Most large companies and institutions know that synthetic or manufactured mineral is not suitable for plants of industrial size. They also know that synthetic mineral cannot give the proper results in the softening of very hard water.

Refinite mineral is not a manufactured product. It is a flinty, porous clay which is insoluble in water. In its original state it is classed as a natural zeolite. No chemicals whatever are added to nature's formula.

The raw or natural mineral is very hard, and must be blasted loose. The process of baking it is similar to that of baking bricks. Refinite is our registered name for the finished product.

One of the severest tests for zeolites is to pass hot water through them. Refinite is the only zeolite that will stand this test.

PRELIMINARY REPORT ON SEWAGE DISPOSAL AT LEBRET INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

INTRODUCTORY:

The site of the new Indian Residential School at Lebret, Saskatchewan, is in close proximity to Lebret lake, an expansion of Qu'Appelle river and one of the chain of lakes known as Fishing lakes. This chain of lakes, nestling in the deep rugged valley of the Qu'Appelle has attracted a number of summer cottagers and undoubtedly will attract more. Accordingly, the Department of Health of the Province of Saskatchewan desires to prevent, insofar as is possible, the pollution of the waters of these lakes and quite naturally desires that the sewage disposal system at the new school be one that will not give grounds for complaint.

The water from Lebret lake is not free from pollution and during the present dry cycle the water becomes quite stagnant and gives forth rather an unpleasant odor. However, this lake was the source of water supply for the old school and of necessity will be the source of water supply for the new school. It is proposed to sink a well within 20 to 25 feet of the waters' edge and connect the same by pipe with the pump house. Chlorination of the water supply will be necessary but it is anticipated that due to the sandy nature of the soil, there will be a sufficient quantity of seepage into the well to meet the school's requirements and that filtration will be unnecessary. It is proposed to install a water softener. All installations in connection with the water supply will be concentrated in the pump house addition.

The sewage disposal system at the old Indian School at Lebret consisted of a septic tank and disposal bed. The septic tank is much too small for the requirements of the
school and the disposal bed presumably ceased to be efficient years ago. It is not intended, therefore, to make use of any part of the old system.

In connection with the sewage disposal systems of the Indian Residential Schools that have received the attention of this office, a septic tank, either with or without a disposal bed has been the usual installation. We proposed to construct a septic tank and disposal bed in connection with the new school at Lebret. However, in discussing the matter with Mr. R. H. Murray, Director of Sanitation, Department of Health of the Province of Saskatchewan, he was definitely opposed to such a proposed method of sewage disposal and suggested the use of sprinkling filters, the system in use at the Provincial Sanitarium near Fort Qu'Appelle.

Sprinkling filters are well adapted for use in warm climates but unless well heated lose much of their efficiency in cold climates. Such a system is not suited for Indian Residential Schools for as a general rule the sewage disposal systems at these institutions do not receive proper attention and sprinkling filters require continuous attention for efficiency of results. I have not examined the system in use at the Sanitarium near Fort Qu'Appelle, but have no doubt that it is quite efficient, as is claimed by Mr. Murray, for that institution is well maintained and has a competent engineering and supervising staff whose duty it is to attend to such matters.

In connection with the Lebret School, we have designed a septic tank and sewage disposal bed that will meet the requirements of the institution and also, we think, render the effluent less harmful than the present lake water. We realize, however, that we will have difficulty in convincing Mr. Murray of such efficiency of results.
Accordingly, we have prepared a design for a sewage disposal system by means of chlorination. This system is in use at the Ninette Sanitarium in Manitoba. It was installed in 1931 and is said to be very efficient. The Ninette Sanitarium is located on the shores of Pelican lake, a beautiful body of water lying amidst the scenic beauty of the Pembina Valley. Pelican lake is a summer resort and many cottages border its shores and the Manitoba Government are just as anxious as the Saskatchewan Government that pollution of such lakes be not permitted.

The Ninette Sanitarium for Consumptives is a Manitoba Government institution. The Manitoba Government are also installing this system at the new Provincial Gaol near Headingley, and the effluent is discharged into the Assiniboine river.

The situation is as follows: The Director of Sanitation, Department of Health at Regina, takes strong exception to our suggestion to construct a septic tank and disposal bed at the Lebret School, but suggests a system of sprinkling filters. Because of the heavy initial cost of installation and also operation, we do not approve of his suggestion. In submitting a third proposal, providing for the installation of a system of sewage disposal in use at Government Institutions in Manitoba and strongly endorsed by the Department of Health officials of the Manitoba Government, we hope that Mr. Murray will approve of the same and thus avoid any conflict of opinion over the matter.

It is not my intention in this preliminary report to go fully into the matter of the design of the two alternative systems for sewage disposal, nor into the subject of estimated costs. However, in the paragraphs following, the salient points in the design of each system...
are outlined and the plans, accompanying this report, show considerable of the detail.

SEPTIC TANK AND DISPOSAL BED:

The design of the septic tank and disposal bed, of necessity, had to conform to the limited difference in elevation available between the outlet from the school and the high water elevation of Lebret lake. Thus a shallow septic tank, in close proximity to the school was necessary, with a fairly long connecting line to the disposal bed. We desired to locate the disposal bed so that the completed surface would conform to the natural contour of the grounds and also so as to be away from tree growth.

The septic tank as shown on the accompanying plan, consists of the usual settling and syphon chambers and is to be constructed of reinforced concrete, the concrete baffle beans being designed to support the overhead structures. Provision is made for three manholes, one of which is to provide access for periodic removal of solid matter.

The settling basin is designed for a theoretical retention period of 24 hours for 10,000 gallons or double the anticipated average daily water consumption in the Institution. The syphon chamber is fitted with one 5" Anthes syphon and is designed to discharge 2,500 gallons twice each 24 hours.

In drawing your attention to the plan showing details of septic tank, I would like to point out that if it is finally decided to utilize a septic tank with a disposal bed, full details will be shown of the construction details, including reinforcing required etc. It might also be pointed out that since the accompanying plan was prepared, alterations in design have been decided upon to ensure more even distribution in the settling basin, to permit a freer entry of air to the tank and to substitute a weir for the 6" pipe opening between settling chamber and syphon chamber.

Details of the proposed disposal bed are not being forwarded. The proposed bed will be 125' x 200' and will contain 6,272 lineal feet of field tile or 23 lineal feet for each inmate of the Institution. Crushed rock, gravel and sand will be used in the building up of the bed in order to ensure efficiency of results.

Rain water from the roof and drainage from the boiler room and the pump room will not be passed through either the septic tank or disposal bed, but will be outletted into the small creek as illustrated on the accompanying contour plan of the site.

No provision is being made for installation of any grease trap between the building and the septic tank as it is assumed that grease traps are a part of the plumbing installation covered by the general contract.

**CHLORINATING SYSTEM OF SEWAGE TREATMENT:**

This system consists of the application of chlorine to the sewage before entering the main chamber which chamber corresponds to the settling chamber of a septic tank and has a designed retention period of 24 hours, also a further application of chlorine to the effluent prior to passing into the outlet pipe.

The accompanying plan showing "Details of Chlorinating Plant", shows fairly clearly the main features of the construction necessary. The tank constructed of reinforced concrete is rather similar to the ordinary septic tank and is sometimes erroneously referred to as a septic tank. The tank is divided into three chambers, which for convenience we will refer to as "Inlet Chlorinating Chamber", "Main Chamber" and "Outlet Chlorinating Chamber". The 6" sewer pipe from the school discharges into the inlet chlorinating chamber, the dimensions of which are 5' - 0" by 2' - 6", with the bottom elevation of inlet and outlet pipe 2' - 0" from the bottom of the chamber. The upper
portion of the chamber is baffled to ensure even distribution and the lower portion is fitted with a coarse screen which serves the same purpose as the screen in the manhole at the entrance to the septic tank. A manhole provides access to the chamber and permits cleaning of the screen when necessary. Two 6" outlet pipes connect with the two sections of the main chamber.

The main chamber corresponds to the settling chamber of a septic tank and as designed has outside dimensions of 19' - 0" x 23' - 0". This main tank is divided into two separate chambers each with inside dimensions of 8' - 0" by 20' - 0" and a mean depth of approximately 6' - 11". The floor slopes slightly from either end to a sludge trough at the centre. Each chamber has been designed for a 24 hour retention period for 5,000 gallons and it is planned to have only one chamber in operation at one time so as to permit frequent removal of sludge. This sludge removal will be made by means of a sludge pump emptying into a suitable tank that can be placed readily on a waggon. Access to either chamber is provided by a common manhole in the centre of the tank and giving ready access for the removal of sludge. The chambers are baffled to ensure even distribution, also retention and the reinforced baffles are designed so as to carry the roof and to provide a 6" air space below the roof. This air space is for insulation purposes.

The outlet chlorinating chamber as designed is 6' - 6" x 4' - 0" inside dimensions and 4' 6" in height below the inner manhole cover. The 6" pipe from the main chamber permits discharge onto a 4" layer of properly sized crushed rock resting on a coarse screen which rests on an iron grill whose edges are embedded in the concrete walls of the chamber. The space below the screen is in the second chlorinating chamber and is of sufficient dimensions to ensure a retention period of at least 15 minutes between
discharges into the effluent pipe. A manhole provides access to this chamber and permits flushing and cleaning of the crushed rock and if necessary its replacement.

A small shelter to house the chlorinator completes the layout. This shelter could be built anywhere on the roof, but preferably where shown on the plan. Galvanized piping 1-1/8" diameter connects the chlorinator with the two chlorinating chambers and provides protection for the rubber tubing carrying the chlorine.

The initial application of chlorine takes place in the inlet chamber, chlorine being applied continuously at a specified rate unless a fully automatic chlorinator is installed, in which case chlorine would be only applied and in such quantities as required by the inflowing sewage. In the main chamber the process of chlorination continues, the chlorine penetrating the solid matters, rendering them odorless and harmless. It is possible some septic action also takes place in this tank, but it is in no sense a septic tank since septic action is retarded by the application of chlorine. There is free flow from the main chamber through the 6" outflow pipe onto the crushed rock bed in the outflow chlorinating chamber. The purpose of this crushed rock layer is to separate remaining solids from the effluent and prevent them passing into the lake where their presence would be unsightly, although harmless. Naturally this rock bed requires occasional cleaning. An overflow pipe is provided to care for outflow in case the crushed rock bed becomes clogged and an air vent is also to be installed. Chlorine is also applied to the effluent below the rock screen, the application being continuous unless a fully automatic chlorinator is installed.
ESTIMATES OF COST:

No estimates have as yet been prepared of the costs of either of the two methods of sewage treatment outlined above. It is probable that the cost of construction of the chlorinating tank would be slightly more than the construction of the septic tank. Should soil conditions not prove favourable, the disposal bed to be used in connection with the septic tank will probably entail an expenditure of approximately $2,500. to $3,000., whereas the cost of the chlorinating machine installed could probably be carried out for $1,250. Should it be necessary to provide an outlet into deep water from the chlorinating tank, this would prove expensive. We hope to avoid the necessity for this. It is probable, therefore, that the cost of the septic tank installation would be $1,750 more than the other.

A comparison of operation costs however are decidedly unfavourable to the chlorinating system. Little or no operation costs are involved in the case of the septic tank, other than the necessity of periodic removal of sludge. The daily cost of chlorine for the chlorinating system would probably be not less than 60 cents or about $230.00 yearly.

REMARKS:

The writer, at the present time, is not prepared to state which system of sewage treatment would prove to be the most efficient at the Lebret School. We are quite confident that the septic tank and disposal bed that we have designed will prove very efficient and will result in an effluent comparatively free from bacteria and less dangerous than the water of Lebret lake. On the other hand we are not confident that the treatment of the sewage by chlorination as proposed, will be as easily operated or that the results obtained will be as satisfactory. Notwithstanding the efficiency of results claimed on behalf of the installation
at Ninette Sanitarium, such literature as we have secured relating to the subject has not convinced us as to the efficiency of this method of sewage treatment.

In view of the fact that the Director of Sanitation of the Department of Health of the Province of Saskatchewan has expressed his disapproval of the proposed septic tank installation and inasmuch as it is our desire to secure approval of the Saskatchewan authorities for whatever sewage disposal system is to be installed, we have brought to your attention this proposal to treat the sewage by chlorination. This treatment is advocated by officials of the Department of Health of the Province of Manitoba and meets with their complete approval. Under such circumstances it might reasonably be expected that such endorseration would ensure the approval of the Saskatchewan officials. Whether such approval can be secured will only be ascertained by submitting the proposals to the proper officials at Regina. I would recommend that this be done without delay. If such approval is not forthcoming then it would be for the Department of Indian Affairs to decide whether we should proceed with the design of a sprinkling filter system of sewage treatment or to over-ride the objections of the Saskatchewan Department of Health and proceed with the construction of a septic tank and sewage disposal bed as outlined in this report.

D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your visit to this office on the 28th instant, I wish to confirm the discussion which we had on the matter of water supply and sewage disposal for the new Indian Residential School at Lebret.

Water Supply.

I understand that it is proposed to sink a well close to the lake shore at a point due west of the school and that water will filter through from the lake into the well and be pumped for use in the school.

There will be no direct connection from the lake to the well and all water consumed will be subject to natural filtration before entering the well.

Further, the water will be continuously treated by liquid chlorine.

It may be necessary to have a direct connection from the lake through a separate force main for fire protection purposes, but if this is provided separate pumps and supply mains will be used and there will be no cross connections between the emergency supply for fire purposes and the domestic supply for washing and consumption by the pupils and staff.

It should be pointed out that the location of this well should be as far removed as possible from any sewage disposal bed which is contemplated and the Department would like to see this well located even further to the north than the site shown on your plan, say, at a distance of at least 400 feet from the nearest point of the disposal bed.

Sewage Disposal.

Two schemes were discussed in connection with sewage disposal, preliminary plans for which were submitted. Scheme (a) shows a chlorination plant at the south end of the school building with a six inch effluent pipe discharging into the dry creek bed some 200 feet from the lake shore. Scheme (b) provides for a septic tank situated immediately south of the school with an underground disposal bed constructed of 4 inch field tile with no effluent pipe leading into the lake.

In both schemes the roof water and other clear water from the school is conveyed by a 6 inch pipe to the ditch about 150 feet east of the school and discharged into the creek bed.

So far as this 6 inch pipe for clear water is concerned this is satisfactory to the Department, provided that at no time any waste water which is at all offensive is
discharged into the creek and that the effluent is free from laundry and other wastes.

Regarding Scheme (a), the proposal seems to be to retain the sewage in an underground tank and chlorinate before and after retention.

The intention is to prevent any septic action in this tank and precipitate the solids, the latter being removed from the tank at frequent intervals, the chlorinated effluent being discharged into the lake.

The Department is of the opinion that the quantity of chlorine necessary to treat the sewage in this manner would be very excessive; in fact it is doubtful if the school authorities would be prepared to maintain the dose required; the effluent would be unsatisfactory and would not be suitable for discharge as proposed. Even if sufficient chlorine were used the effluent might be discharged into a river which had a very large volume of flow but it would not avoid a nuisance in a quiescent lake.

Regarding Scheme (b), the writer expressed the opinion to you when I met you at the site of the school last fall that an underground disposal bed would not prove satisfactory under the special circumstances at Lebret and I wish to repeat that view and place it on record. The level of the disposal bed will, of necessity, be just above the level of the lake and unless there is tile there can be little or no drainage of the effluent into the ground below the bed. If the ground above the tiles is prepared artificially with sand or gravel it will undoubtedly absorb a certain amount of waste liquid but this will gradually become water-logged and although there may be a limited amount of evaporation and lateral absorption it will only be a matter of time until the bed becomes completely saturated and the liquid finds its way to the surface and overflows into the lake.

Apparently this view is not held by your Department and you feel that at least an experiment should be made to see if this disposal bed will not function efficiently.

I am directed to say that this Department has no objection to the disposal bed in itself and if there is no effluent discharged into the lake we will be quite satisfied, but if at any time it is found that this bed has become water-logged and that the effluent is reaching the lake through a direct channel the Department will require that the effluent be temporarily pumped from the septic tank and conveyed by wagon to some approved point of disposal on the land and a system of filtration immediately installed as originally recommended by this Department.

Regarding the design of the septic tank, several details were discussed with you and I understand that the suggestions made will be incorporated in the final plans which are submitted for the approval of the Minister of Public Health before construction work starts.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) R. H. Murray,
Director,
Division of Sanitation.

Winnipeg, Manitoba. D. B. Gow,
March 12, 1935. Acting District Chief Engineer.
REPORT
ON
PROPOSED WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM
FOR
QU'APPHELLE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
AT
LEBRET, SASKATCHEWAN.

INTRODUCTORY:

The site of the new Indian Residential School at Lebret is in close proximity to Lebret Lake, an expansion of the Qu'Appelle river and one of the chain of lakes known as Fishing Lakes. The valley of the Qu'Appelle is quite deep with rugged hills rising abruptly from the flats adjoining the river and river expansions.

In general, after the spring freshets have passed, the volume of flow in this river is small and during the present cycle of dry years the flow in late summer is negligible and the water in the small river expansions becomes stagnant. The water being mostly surface, run-off is not excessively hard, but is more or less contaminated and is not considered safe, untreated, for drinking and cooking purposes.

The old Indian Residential School, located on the same site as the new school, obtained its water supply from Lebret lake. The water supply for drinking and kitchen use was pumped from a well, situated under the building, while water for other purposes was pumped through a suction main extending out into the lake. The water supply in the well was undoubtedly seepage from the lake, but being more than 250 feet away from the lake, seepage was slow and the water supply from this source was rather limited. The water main from the lake provided an ample supply for sanitary purposes, but this water at times contains an excessive amount of organic matter and if utilized unfiltered would impair the efficiency of chlorinating and water softening equipment.
surface of which will be 2' - 0" below the pump house floor, necessitating three steps of stairway. Two windows, one at either end are provided for; the minimum width of opening to be 4' - 4" to permit of the entry of equipment if necessary.

II. - Intake.

It is proposed that none of the water supply be taken directly from Lebret Lake, but that a well be sunk in close proximity to the high water mark and used as the intake. The soil is apparently sandy and should this sandy soil persist to a depth of 4 or 5 feet below low water level, there would be a steady flow of seepage into the well. The water would be freed from suspended matter, algae growth, etc., thus eliminating any necessity for the installation of a filter in the school.

The questions of definite location, size and type of construction of the intake have received consideration but final decision must await the results of tests that can only be carried out after the spring break-up. If at all possible it is desired to avoid the extension of the suction main out into the deep water of the lake.

III. - Suction Main.

It is recommended that the suction main between the pump and intake consist of 4" galvanized pipe and fitted with 4" foot valve in the intake. Pending final location of the intake, a definite location cannot be shown for the suction main, but Plate No. 3 shows the proposed location from the pump house to the west main wall of the building and this portion of the line must be at least 7' - 0" under-
ground to prevent frost danger to that portion of the line not located under the school building.

IV. - Pumping System.

It is noted that the school building, while of fire-proof construction, is to be fitted with stand-pipes and fire hose on every floor. Due to the type of construction, any fire that broke out would in all probability be confined to a limited area so that the measure of fire protection to be afforded can be limited to the water requirements of one line of fire hose.

It is proposed to install a 5,000 gallon per hour (wine measure) self-oiling typhoon pump mounted on the same frame and V-belt driven by a 7½ H.P. motor. This pumping equipment will provide a measure of fire protection, probably sufficient for the fire-proof nature of the structure. A much smaller pump and motor would suffice for supplying the ordinary water requirements of the school.

The capacity of the pumping plant is more or less important because of difference in initial cost and also because of the cost of operation. At Lebret, I understand there is a substantial connected load charge for each horse-power installed in addition to the cost of power used.

V. - Pressure Tank and Pressure System.

The pressure tank will be of the usual dimensions 4' - 0" diameter and 16' long and designed to be operated at maximum allowable pressure of 100 pounds. It will be mounted on concrete saddles and be placed along the west wall of the pump house. A small motor driven air compressor will be installed to maintain an adequate air pressure within the
pressure tank which will ordinarily be operated within a pressure range of 40 and 60 pounds. The action of this air compressor will not be automatic but the water gauge to be installed on the pressure tank will indicate when operation of the air compressor is required. Automatic starting and stopping of the motor-driven water pump will be controlled by the installation of an automatic pressure switch. The usual safety devices will be installed to prevent excessive pressure in the pressure tank in the event of failure of the pressure switch or lack of proper superintendence.

It is intended that the ordinary water supply for the Institution will all pass through the pressure tank, but for fire protection we are proposing to provide an auxiliary 2" pipe line from the discharge pipe between pump and tank to the standpipe system in the school; the pressure tank being by-passed by means of a gate valve. This will permit a continuous operation of the pump and a pressure of 100 pounds on the fire hose in case of fire.

VI. - Chlorination.

Tests made of the water from Lebret lake reveals sufficient contamination to render it unsafe for human consumption, so that treatment becomes necessary. It is proposed, therefore, to install a semi-automatic type of chlorinating machine using chlorine gas. All water used in the school will, it is proposed, be chlorinated.

Consideration has been given to the type of chlorinator to be installed and it is recommended that a Wallace and Tierman machine be installed. While
the initial cost of machines of this make are considerably greater than other types, yet the efficiency of their machines and the servicing of the machines after installation, are considerations that are very important in connection with Indian schools.

The chlorinator will be connected with the water system on the suction side of the water pump so that chlorination will proceed while the pump is in operation. The supply of chlorine to the chlorinator comes from a chlorine cylinder in which the chlorine is liquified by pressure. It is proposed to install on the outlet connection between cylinder and chlorinator, an automatic device, electrically operated whereby the supply of chlorine gas from the cylinder is shut off immediately the pump stops pumping. This automatic control of the chlorine feed is a decided improvement over the types of chlorinators this office has previously installed. In previous installations there is a continuous passage of chlorine gas from cylinder to chlorinator and when the water pump was not in operation this chlorine gas is wasted and provision must be made for supplying water to absorb it and to get rid of the resultant highly chlorinated liquid, since this liquid will quickly eat away any metal piping. Since the water pump is usually in operation only 10% of the time, there is a great wastage of chlorine.

As a precautionary measure, however, it is proposed to include in our estimates the cost of the laying of a 1" C.I. pipe line from chlorinator to the storm water glazed pipe line beyond the south wall of the building. Through this 1" line will be passed
a ½" rubber tubing to carry away any drainage from the chlorinator. Should further inquiry and information reveal that this precautionary measure is not required, then the pipe line need not be proceeded with.

VII. - Water Softening.

The Provincial Laboratory of the Department of Public Health, Province of Saskatchewan, in reporting on a sample of water taken from Lebret Lake in February, stated that it was 29.4 grains hard, that it contained a high mineral salt content but was suitable for use as a drinking water.

This water cannot be considered a very hard water but the main constituents comprising these 29.4 grains of hardness are such as to cause very hard boiler scale and similar trouble to that experienced at the Birtle Indian Residential School where within two or three years the high pressure steam boiler and hot water heater were burned out. It is recommended, therefore, that a water softener be installed at this Institution.

It is suggested that softened water be limited to the following services in the building:

1. Steam heating system,
2. High pressure steam boiler system,
3. Hot Water Supply boiler system,
4. Limited supply of cold water to laundry and kitchen.

It is impossible to estimate accurately what will be the daily average use of water in this school for purposes which it is suggested that softened water be supplied. On laundry days the use of such might run as high as 3,000 gallons, while the average use...
will probably exceed 1,500 gallons. It is proposed, therefore, to install a water softener that will provide 1,000 gallons of water with zero hardness per hour and with at least 6,000 gallons between regenerations. The water softener should consist of a double unit, utilizing the Zeolite method of water softening.

The installation of a water softener will necessitate one change in the ordinary water supply piping in the school and some additional piping. The only change in the ordinary water supply piping in the school, as covered by the general contract, will be to connect the supply line to the boiler room to the water supply pipe from the water softener and not to the main 2" water supply pipe from the pressure tank. The additional piping required is a 1½" feed line from the supply main to the water softener, and a 1" feed line from the water softener from which shall be taken the soft water supply to the boiler room and the auxiliary cold soft water supply to the kitchen and laundry.

VIII. - Pump House Drainage.

To provide drainage from the pump house it is proposed to provide for a floor drain in the pump house and connect the same by means of a 3" cast iron drain pipe to the drain in the boiler room. Drainage from the pump house will consist of leakage from the pump, occasional flushing of pressure tank, backwash from the water softener and floor flushing waste.

Provision is also being made in the estimates for discharging possible drainage from the chlorinator through a ½" rubber tube within a 1½" iron pipe line.
from the chlorinator to the 6" glazed tile storm water drain at the south wall of the school. The location of this proposed line is shown on Plate No. 3 that accompanies this report. This pipe line is to be laid without sharp bends except below the boiler room floor, at which bend a removable cover in the floor permits access to the sharp turn shown there.

Waste from the chlorinator is highly chlorinated and will destroy metal piping rapidly so must be passed through rubber tubing, the piping being for protection only.

REPORT ON PROPOSED SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM, FOR QU'APPELLE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, AT LEBRET, SASKATCHEWAN.

INTRODUCTORY:

The sewage disposal system in use at the old Indian Residential School at Lebret consisted of septic tank and disposal bed. In recent years the disposal bed was enlarged and a pipe line was laid out into deep water to carry off the effluent, but there were many complaints about the ineffectiveness of the system. An examination of the site led to the conclusion that the septic tank was too small to meet the requirements of the new school and that the location of the disposal bed was not satisfactory. Accordingly, it was decided not to use any portion of the existing system in connection with the sewage disposal system for the new school, now under construction.

The new Indian School at Lebret has been designed to accommodate 250 children and a staff of approximately 25. The average daily use of water in the school, will it is estimated, be 5,000 gallons and the sewage disposal system as designed for this school and outlined below, is based upon the estimated use of water and the school population.

SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM:

General.

The general contract for the erection of the school provides for the complete drainage of the building, of all foul water and sewage and also for the collection and carrying of the storm water drainage to the outside of the building. This report, therefore, deals with the disposal of the sewage and storm water.
from the points where the contractor leads the 6" sewer and the 6" drain pipe to the outer wall of the building. Lebret Lake and other expansions of the Qu'Appelle River below are now being used by summer campers and of necessity the sewage disposal and drainage systems at the new school must be such that there be no offensive discharge into Lebret Lake.

Accordingly, there can be no discharge of kitchen and laundry waste directly into the lake; it must be passed through the sewage disposal system, undesirable as such a course must be. Since the roof drainage, pump room and boiler room drainage contain nothing of an offensive nature, it is proposed to pass such drainage more or less directly to the lake.

The sanitary system can be divided into the two following divisions:

(a) Storm Water and Boiler Room Drainage,
(b) Sewage Disposal System.

These two divisions will be dealt with separately.

Storm Water and Boiler Room Drainage:

Plate No. 1 shows the proposed location of the drain pipe from the school to its outlet into the small creek to the south-east of the school. Plate No. 2 shows locations of auxiliary drains under the floor of the building, location of manhole, just outside the building and elevations of the storm water drain as it leaves the school. Plate No. 4 shows a detail of the manhole providing access to the connection between the 6" C.I. drain pipe and the 6" glazed drain pipe. The storm water drain from the school will be about 225 feet in length.

The storm water drain must also carry the
combined drainage from the pump room and the boiler room and also any drainage from the chlorinator.

To provide drainage from the pump room, a short length of drain is required to connect the floor drains in the pump house to the floor drains in the boiler room - location of this drain being shown on Plate No. 3.

There is a certain wastage of chlorine through the chlorinator and as even a very weak solution of chlorine may be very destructive of metal pipe, it may be necessary to lay a 1½" cast iron pipe line from the chlorinator in the pump room to connect with the storm water drain at the manhole outside the building. A 2" rubber tubing inserted within the 1½" pipe line will carry the waste chlorine. Plate No. 3 shows the location of this auxiliary drain.

Sewage Disposal System.

The proposed sewage disposal system will consist of the usual septic tank and disposal bed. Plate No. 1 shows the location of the septic tank and disposal bed in relation to the school site. Plate No. 3 shows the profile of the proposed sewage disposal system with reference to school grade and the water level of Lebret Lake. A concrete manhole is shown a short distance from the school giving access to the connections between the cast iron drains and the glazed pipe lines carrying the sewage and the storm wastes. The provision of this manhole is suggested because of the possibility of the blocking of the sewer, either under the school building or between the building and the septic tank. This manhole will be made air tight to prevent escaping offensive odors so near an entrance to the building.

The design of the septic tank and disposal...
bed of necessity, had to conform to the very limited difference in elevation between the outlet from the school and the high water level of Lebret Lake. Thus a shallow septic tank in rather close proximity to the school became necessary, with a fairly long connecting line to the disposal bed. It was desired to locate the disposal bed so that the completed surface would, insofar as possible, conform to the natural contour of the ground and also be away from tree growth.

Septic Tank.

Plate No. 5 shows the general layout and details of the proposed septic tank. It consists of the usual settling and siphon chambers, constructed of reinforced concrete and with the baffle beams designed to support the roof and earth cover. Elevations, dimensions and reinforcing details are shown on Plate No. 5 so need not be specifically referred to here.

A manhole provides access to the small chamber, 3' - 0" x 3' - 6" outside dimensions, into which the 6" sewer discharges just prior to entering the septic tank. This small chamber is fitted with a coarse screen through which the sewage must pass before being discharged into the settling basin of the tank. The purpose of this screen is to prevent the passage into the tank of articles of clothing, boots, etc., and the manhole permits of access for periodic cleaning of this screen.

The settling basin is designed for a theoretical retention of 10,000 gallons for 24 hours or double the anticipated average daily water usage in the school. Access to the settling chamber for
sludge removal purposes is provided by two manholes, one at either end of the chamber. The second manhole has been provided at the request of the Director of Sanitation, Department of Public Health of the Province of Saskatchewan, but it is in our opinion unnecessary since there is direct passage of air between the settling chamber and the manhole over the syphon chamber. From the intake or screen chamber the sewage will discharge through a 6" pipe against a 2" x 10" plank, supported by stirrups from the plank cover; this plank acting as a disperser and aiding in distributing the sewage across the width of the tank.

The syphon chamber is to be fitted with one 5" anthes syphon and is designed to discharge approximately 2,500 gallons twice every twenty-four hours. Access to this chamber is to be provided through a manhole located immediately above the syphon.

From the syphon chamber the effluent is discharged through a 6" glazed tile drain to the disposal bed. On the plan we have made provision for an air vent from this drain and also an overflow opening between the syphon chamber and this air vent.

Disposal Bed.

Plate No. 1 shows the proposed location of the disposal bed with reference to the school location, septic tank and the natural ground features. Plate No. 6 shows the general plan, sections and some details of the disposal bed. All elevations given are to the same datum as the school grade.

The disposal bed, as designed, is to be 200' x 128' and will contain 6,240 lineal feet of 4" field tile or about 23 lineal feet for each inmate.
of the school. The success or failure of the sewage disposal system at this Institution will depend very largely upon the efficiency of the disposal bed and the extent to which it prevents any direct passage of the effluent into Lebret Lake. The failure of disposal beds to function properly is usually due to unsuitable soil conditions, overloading and to careless laying of the distribution and feeder lines.

As will be noted from the detailed drawings, we have gone rather to the extreme in guarding against failure from such causes.

Only a casual examination has been made of the soil conditions at the proposed location of the disposal bed and the bed as designed is based upon the assumption that unfavourable conditions exist. Detailed examination of soil conditions may reveal more favourable conditions and permit of some modification in design that will tend to diminish the cost of construction.

The disposal bed will be entirely in excavation, as is shown by sections marked, A, B, C and D on Plate No. 6. Both the distribution line and feeder lines are to be laid perfectly level, the bottom elevation of the distributor line being 87.5 and the feeder line only slightly higher. The distribution line will connect directly with the discharge line from the septic tank and extends across the middle of the bed with Y connections every two feet alternately to the right and left to the 4" feeder lines, as is shown on the detail drawing.

In preparation for the laying of the feeder line field tile, it is proposed to excavate trenches 18" wide and 6" deep, the bottom elevation of this trench
to be 87.4. The field tile will be laid in this trench with bottom elevation approximately 87.6 and in a bed of crushed rock or washed gravel, completely filling the trench. The purpose of the crushed rock or gravel is for the dual purpose of preventing uneven settlement of the tile and to materially increase the distribution speed of the effluent from the distributor line. If the nature of the excavated material is found to be more porous than we anticipate, the width of this trench will be reduced to 12". All joints between tile will be covered with tar paper to prevent entrance of soil into the tile. An 18" layer of sandy clay or loam will comprise the upper portion of the bed - this material being hauled to the site if necessary. An air vent from the last feeder line will also be provided at the location shown on the plan.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of March 25th, re giving permission to use intermediate grade reinforcing steel for the Lebret Indian School. This job, as you know, was designed for hard grade steel and I do not think a change should be authorized. The tensile requirements for hard grade steel are much higher than for the intermediate grade, and, in my opinion, it is, by far, the best grade for building work.

When the committee was writing the City of Toronto concrete building by-law, they seriously considered leaving out the intermediate grade entirely and it was only after strong representations had been made by the manufacturers that intermediate grade was inserted. This by-law gives intermediate grade a working stress of 18,000 lbs. per square inch, which is the same as structural grade (low carbon steel). Hard grade or rail steel bars are allowed a working stress of 20,000 lbs. per square inch.

There are a few building codes that give both intermediate grade and hard grade bars the same working stress of 20,000 lbs. per square inch. This, however, is not consistent with the tensile requirements of the two steels which are given in the same codes. These invariably recognize that hard grade steel is much better.

In the Lebret job, the change should not be permitted unless the area of steel in each beam, joist, slab or column is increased by at least 5%. This, in several instances, will crowd the steel in the member, i.e., the bars will be too close together to permit the concrete to pass between them satisfactorily and the bond between the concrete and the steel will be affected. This, of course, will weaken the member. It is possible that to overcome this crowding, the sub-contractor will place the steel in two layers. This should

CONCRETE FOR PERMANENCE
not be permitted in any beam which has been designed with one layer of steel as this will seriously affect its strength. This condition can only be overcome by redesigning the member affected.

In view of all the foregoing factors, I would recommend that the sub-contractors be required to live up to the specifications. Hard grade steel is readily available in the West, but, as it is a better steel, it is naturally somewhat more expensive - about $2.00 per ton. This is probably the reason for asking for the change. You will note, however, that while this steel is about 5% more expensive, you use about 5% less. The sub-contractor in asking for permission to change undoubtedly figures on using the same tonnage which, of course, is to his advantage but to the disadvantage of the building.

If I can give you any further information on this subject, please do not hesitate to write me.

I wish to acknowledge the receipt today, of a set of plans for the Qu'Appelle Hospital. I will get to work on these at once and will bring the plans, etc., down to Ottawa in about ten days. I trust this will be satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Orr:

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant with reference to the mechanical stoker to be supplied with the heating system at the Lebret School; the contract for which has been let to the Vulcan Iron Works of Winnipeg.

On the afternoon of April 6th, Mr. Ross of this office and the writer, visited the Vulcan Iron Works and saw a stoker somewhat similar to that to be installed at Lebret, in operation and also discussed the situation with Mr. Anderson, Sales Manager. As explained to us by Mr. Anderson, the situation is somewhat as follows:

The Vulcan Iron Works have received the order for the boilers and propose to equip these boilers with an underfeed mechanical stoker - the Canadian rights to which they have secured recently from an American concern. The Department of Indian Affairs have approved of the proposed type of mechanical stoker but have stipulated that it must be made in Canada. Accordingly, Mr. Anderson was concerned mostly in demonstrating that the mechanical stoker, or ones similar, are being made in the shops of the Vulcan Iron Works in Winnipeg.

They had an underfeed mechanical stoker set up in the plant supplying Souris coal to a boiler with capacity somewhat smaller than that of the boilers to be installed at Lebret. We were informed that the Souris coal appeared to be a somewhat better grade than was being utilized in their own heating system near by. The underfeed mechanical stoker appeared to operate very efficiently and both the stoker and the fan were being operated from the one motor, which was of 2 H.P. capacity. However, the motors to be installed in connection with the installation at Lebret will be 3 H.P.

As pointed out above, Mr. Anderson was rather insistent that we be satisfied that the Vulcan Iron Works were actually making these stokers in their own plants. Accordingly, we were taken around the various shops to see the making of the patterns, the casting of moulds and also the finished castings for parts of the stokers or ones of similar design. I am quite sure that your stipulation as to the origin of manufacture is being strictly adhered to.

Saskatchewan lignite coal is now extensively used in Winnipeg for heating homes, apartment blocks, large

R. G. Orr, Esq.,
Architect,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
institutions and etc. Some short time ago the Dominion Bridge Company installed several underfeed mechanical stokers in connection with the heating systems of several apartment blocks but these proved unsatisfactory when burning lignite coal. I am credibly informed that there are no underfeed mechanical stokers in operation in Winnipeg at the present time burning lignite coal satisfactorily. However, there are many overfeed stokers in operation giving highly efficient results with the same fuel. Probably the most efficient of these units is at the Agricultural College. It might be pointed out, however, that all these heating units appear to be of considerable more capacity than the boilers which it is proposed to install at Lebret. Mr. Anderson, when questioned on this subject, admitted that underfeed mechanical stokers in Winnipeg using lignite coal had proved unsatisfactory, but explained that much of the trouble was due to the use of improper grates.

The Vulcan Iron Works, as you state, have acquired the Canadian rights for the manufacture of both overfeed and underfeed mechanical stokers. It is their intention to recommend the underfeed stoker for small sized units and the overfeed stoker for units of large capacity. Mr. Anderson pointed out that the Vulcan Iron Works are guaranteeing satisfactory service from the underfeed mechanical stokers being supplied to Lebret for one year; that similar stokers are uniformly efficient in the northern part of Minnesota and Dakota in furnaces limited that they are far economical to operate, are quieter and require less attention than would the overfeed mechanical stoker.

With such a guarantee, it will be the responsibility of the Vulcan Iron Works if satisfactory service from the heating system is not secured at Lebret.

Qu'Appelle Indian School, Lebret, Sask.

Dear Sirs—

We understand that delivery of the boilers, for the above building, would be required about the middle of this month. As the writer had to go to Regina, he called on Messrs. Potts and Miller regarding the contract, and at the interview found that the General Contractor has changed his plans a little, and they do not want the boilers to go into the boiler-room until after the forms have been removed, so delivery will not be required for at least another month.

We might say this was not known by us until after the writer's interview on April 11th, and we had already wired you as per attached copy.

In our discussion with Messrs. Potts and Miller regarding this installation, they pointed out that as the school was in such an isolated position there might be times in the winter when, due to storms, the power supply would be cut off and this would count as an objection against the underfeed stoker. We believe the point raised merits consideration, but the question of power supply is an important factor with an overfeed installation which requires two motors for each boiler; one to drive the stoker and one to furnish forced draft under the grates. If the current was shut off, a small fire could be carried on the grates but hardly sufficient for the requirements. As you are probably aware, non-sifting grates, of our own manufacture and those supplied by other firms such as the Hulson and the Pyramid types, only have about 20 percent air space as compared with 45 to 50 percent on grates burning fuel with natural draft, so if the forced draft supply under the grates is cut off there will be very little coal burned.

It was also mentioned that, if the Department carried a supply of wood, it would be easier to burn wood than coal if an emergency, as mentioned above, had to be taken care of. It is, however, our belief that a safer arrangement would be to provide the stoker with an additional "V" belt and in case the power was shut off the stoker could be driven with an auxiliary gasoline engine. We would be glad to furnish the complete drive, including the two pulleys and the "V" belt, if this arrangement meets with your approval, and is considered necessary.

We enclose two blueprints of the boiler room layout, together with the specifications of the boiler and stoker equipment and two copies of our catalogues illustrating the stoker. Will you please examine these and return one copy to us, approved or corrected.

In connection with the controls we may say that we are supplying a combination unit, pressure control and low water cut off. The pressure control being called for in your specification, but the low water cut off is being supplied in place of a draft control. This type of control is usually furnished in the case of hand fired installations, but does not appear necessary in the case of a stoker fired unit.

While shipment of the boilers will not be required for another month, as stated above, we would like to ship the stokers with the boilers, so as to save freight. This does not leave us any too much time to complete the stokers and we would therefore like to have your approval as promptly as possible.

If any changes are found necessary would you kindly advise us by wire, which would save at least a couple of days.

Dear Sir:

In the new school, which is under construction, there is no provision made for a direct outside entrance to the Senior boys' playroom. This will be very inconvenient; the Senior boys will have to use the same entrance as the Junior boys and pass through their playground while coming to and from their own playroom. It will be very confusing especially to the Sisters in charge of the Junior boys, and it will be difficult to entirely prevent the older ones from jesting the small ones, which means that much of the good results of having them separated will be lost.

There are also several picnics on the school grounds during the summer, I might mention the Civil Servants annual picnic in particular. The men will use the senior boys' playroom for a dressing room when going for a bath in the lake, (this is a privilege we have always given them) and they will also use the boys' toilets. This will be very disturbing to the small boys and a great inconvenience to the Sisters in charge if they have to go through the small boys' playground on the East side of said building to reach the lake. The same would be true of visiting hockey and baseball teams who would use the senior boys' playroom as a dressing room.

I am asking you as a special favor to have a door put in the North side of the Senior boys' recreation room, or in the East end of the building. If your objection was on account of the extra expense I would be willing to pay the extra cost out of our per capita grant, as I do not think it would amount to very much.

Dear Mr. Orr,

Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret.

I beg to submit my fourth fortnightly report on the construction of the above building for the period ending May 4th, as follows:

Basement wall forms have been stripped and damp-proofing applied all around the building.

Concrete work was placed in all columns and beams and on ground floor slab of main building, and formwork constructed for columns, beams and part of slab of kitchen and laundry wing.

Fuel room walls and roof slab have been placed, and preparation made for the addition of the pump room, according to the revised plans approved by yourself and Mr. D.B. Gow.

Some other forms were removed from under ground floor slab at the north end of the building, and the soffits smoothed and cement filled where required.

Work was interrupted on Wednesday and Thursday May 1st, 2nd, by wet weather.

Column and beam forms were being made up for the first floor and are now well ahead of job requirements.

A certain amount of work has been done in pulling down old rubble walls along the west front of the building down to foundation level, and backfilling, this being done to keep the labourers employed when not needed on other parts of the work.

The use of removable steel pan forms appears to involve a good deal of extra carpenters' work and other labour necessary to make a slightly job of the exposed concrete, and together with the rental and freight charges to and from distant shipping points, seems to offset largely the saving effected on lath, plastering, and permanent steel pan forms.

I mention this in case you are contemplating their use on any other work under your control.

Enclosed please find two photos taken on April 20 and two taken on the 4th inst: indicating to some extent the progress made. A complete view of the building in one picture is hardly possible at present, owing to surrounding obstructions.

Memorandum - The Honourable the Superintendent General.

With reference to the water supply and sewage disposal systems for the new Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret, Sask., Mr. D. B. Gow, of the Dominion Water Power Branch, Winnipeg, was asked to make a survey and report with recommendations for the proposed systems.

This report has been received, and it is recommended that the water for this building be taken from the Lebret Lake by means of a well sunk in near proximity to the high water mark of the Lake. The water will seep through from the lake to the well and from this it can be pumped to the school. The installation of this system includes a pump house, intake, suction main, pumping system, pressure tank and pressure system chlorination and water softening. Mr. Gow's estimate of the cost is $7,495.25.

The sewage disposal system will consist of the usual septic tank and disposal bed. The design of the septic tank and disposal bed of necessity has to conform to the very limited difference in elevation between the outlet from the school and the high water level of the Lake. Thus a shallow septic tank in close proximity to the school becomes necessary. The system as designed has the approval of the Director of Sanitation of the Department of Public Health of the Province of Saskatchewan. The estimated cost is $7,046.00.

Mr. Gow states that these estimates are based upon the assumption that the work will be entrusted to Smith Bros. and Wilson, General Contractors for the school. If any other arrangements are made a considerable increase in the estimate of the cost should be made.

Will you please advise if Mr. Gow may be instructed to have this work carried out by the Contractors for the school?

Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School,

I beg to submit my sixth fortnightly report on the progress of this building for the period ending Saturday June 1st.

The main activities during this period have centred on the concrete work of the structural framing and floors, the first floor slab of the main building being completed on May 24th, the ceiling slab and outside stairway of Indian Room on the 26th and the two main stairways from the ground floor to the first floor on the same date.

On Monday, the 27th, progress was interfered with by steady rain, and the only work that could be done was where, under shelter, labourers could be removing steel florestyle from under concrete slabs, digging trenches for plumbers, and plumbers on interior pipe lines.

On the 28th, concrete floor was laid and finished in the fuel room and part in the boiler room to receive boilers, and on the 29th the concrete was placed in the columns, beams and roof slab over the chapel.

Preparations were made on the 30th and 31st for starting to pour concrete at the north end of the second floor slab but on Saturday June 1st heavy rain fell all day and no outside work could be done.

At the request of Messrs Smith Bros & Wilson I enclose copies of two letters being part of the correspondence between them and the Truscon Steel Company relating to the unsatisfactory results of the use of removable steel florestyle.

I wish to say that the florestyle are very uneven at the edges and in many cases cannot be made to fit snugly at the joints, with the result that when removed, roughnesses varying as much as an inch or more in depth are left on the ceilings under the thinner portion of the slab. These can be smoothed off to some extent by the use of a pneumatic tool, and the contractors have expressed their willingness to do their best in this way to reduce the irregularities.

Another objectionable feature is the discoloured appearance of the concrete caused by rust and oil stains off the florestyle.

No doubt this will bleach out to some extent as the concrete dries, but I fear there will be an unpleasant contrast between the exposed concrete ceilings and the white plastered walls, possibly involving the need of a sprayed finish of cement paint, Dureseal, or similar material.

All reinforcing steel has been delivered, all window frames, sash weights and a shipment of wall tile. Face brick is under
shipment and I understand that the contractors intend to start brickwork about the 10th inst.

The steamfitter also states that the heating boilers will be here on the same date.

Your obedient Servant

H. Dawson,
Supervising Architect, Lebret School.

Dear Sir:

I regret very much that you are having trouble with the removable pans at the Qu'Appelle school job. This condition has arisen simply because the Truscon Steel Company have not lived up to the specifications nor to decent construction practice. You have undoubtedly noticed in Mr. John's letter where he says many pans were a "ghastly mess" and that they might possibly just get by for a rough warehouse job, "if there was no inspection".

As for the Truscon Steel Company's comment that these type were being used for a purpose for which they were never intended" that is nothing but so many words. I would note that in 1927, the Truscon Steel Company provided pans for the Star Building in Toronto and their pans were refused on the job as being in disgraceful shape. They then put a metal mould on the job and straightened and trued the pans till they passed inspection. This resulted in a very presentable job which I would be glad to show you any time in Toronto. It has been my experience that the Truscon Steel Company will not do any straightening or truing up of pans unless they are forced to.

I would like to mention one other job - The Robert Simpson Company's customers parking garage - built last year in Toronto. On this job the Pedlar People provided the pans and an exceptionally fine job was obtained. This can also be seen any time. The Pedlar People, through Mr. Dawson, a structural engineer of Toronto, submitted a price for supplying this same set of pans to Smith Bros. & Wilson. Had their tender been accepted, I am satisfied that none of this trouble would have developed as they always true their pans up after every job and so keep them in shape.

As to the solution of the trouble, I would suggest that Mr. Dawson refuse to let them use any more pans until they comply with the specifications, which distinctly state, under Metal Forms, paragraph 2, that - "All metal forms shall be true to catalogue shape on delivery at the job and shall be oiled before using. They shall be accurately trued up on a metal mould, cleaned and oiled before re-use. No distorted or damaged metal forms shall be used on the work at any time."

CONCRETE FOR PERMANENCE
Mr. R.G. Orr

Toronto, June 12th, 1935.

If this clause is lived up to, you will obtain a job you will be proud of.

In regard to oil and rust stains, would say that the latter would be entirely avoided if the pans were clean, as required by the specifications. I have never had any rust stains from pans on any job which I have done in the past, as rusty pans were not accepted. Oil stains will bleach out entirely if clean oil is used properly. Clean mineral oil should always be used and applied lightly. There should not be any free oil on the surface of the metal. The purpose of the oil, of course, is to prevent the concrete sticking to the metal and the thinnest film will do this and will cause no stain. If, however, a small pool of oil is left in a dent in a pan, the concrete will undoubtedly be stained and the stain will show for a considerable time.

I think Smith Bros. & Wilson might have used more care in accepting bad pans last fall. They could have obtained a decent set or had the present set properly trued up during the Winter and so avoided all the present trouble.

I would like to note, in conclusion, that this type of construction, i.e., no plastered ceiling, is not a freak or a new idea as the Truscon Steel Company imply, but is a fairly common procedure. I have already noted two examples in Toronto and there are many others in all parts of both Canada and the United States. In Boston, many schools have concrete joist ceilings, exposed where two-way joists were used. The pans in this case were square domes and it is much more difficult to get straight joists with this type than with the one-way type.

The whole question boils down to the fact, that to get a good job, good materials, good pans and good construction methods are necessary.

Yours very truly,

CANADA CEMENT COMPANY LIMITED.

Dear Mr. Dawson,

I have your report of June 6th with reference to the progress of the Qu'Appelle School, and am very much surprised that the Contractors accepted the pans for the concrete as supplied by the Truscon Steel Co.

They shall be accurately trued up on a metal mould, cleaned and oiled before re-use. No distorted or damaged metal forms shall be used on the work at any time".

From inquiries I have made I have been advised that on one large building erected in Toronto the pans provided by the Truscon Steel Company were refused on account of being in a disgraceful shape. They then put in a metal mould on the job and straightened and trued up the pans until they passed inspection. The result was a very presentable job and quite satisfactory.

With reference to the oil and rust stains I would say that the latter would be entirely avoided if the pans were cleaned as required by the specifications. Oil stains will bleach out entirely if clean oil is used properly. Clean mineral oil should always be used and applied lightly. There should not be any free oil on the surface of the metal.

It would appear that Smith Bros. and Wilson should have used more care in accepting these pans, and they should be instructed that until they are properly trued up, in accordance with the specifications, they are not to be used further on the job, and this must be done to your entire satisfaction. This type of construction is in fairly common practice at the present time, and there are many examples in different parts of Canada with the open joists which have proven very economical and satisfactory. In order to get good results however it is absolutely necessary that good materials, good pans, and good construction methods be employed.

Sir:

I have for attention your letter of the 18th instant with reference to the Qu'Appelle Indian School at Lebret and enclosing a copy of a letter from the Department of Indian Affairs relating to the same subject.

Referring to the third paragraph of your letter, you state:

"The actual basis on which the work would be undertaken would be proven cost plus 10% and the written offer which you are to obtain from Smith Brothers and Wilson should contain an undertaking to carry out the work on that basis".

I would like to have it made quite clear whether or not the contractor is to be allowed 10% profit on the cost of the materials and equipment. Personally, I consider that the contractor is entitled to 10% profit on the cost of the building materials required but not on the cost of such equipment as Chlorinator, Chlorinator Cylinders, Automatic control for the chlorinator, Water Softener, Pressure Tank, Air Compressor, Pressure Switch and Pumping Machinery.

While it is true in our estimates of cost submitted with the reports on the Proposed Water Supply and Sewage Disposal systems we figured 10% contractors' profit on such equipment, yet I believe the contractors' profit on such equipment should be limited to the cost of handling, installing and incidental fittings. The contractor is unable to purchase such equipment to better advantage than the Government and it is preferable that such equipment be ordered through the Government Purchasing Agents or others acting for them. It is only fair, however, that the contractor should be allowed 10% profit on the cost of all materials for the sewage disposal system.

I would appreciate the Department's view on this subject at the earliest convenience. As soon as the above information is received, arrangements will be made to have the rain water drain laid out and also to have the contractor's estimate of the cost of the water supply and sewage disposal systems.

Your obedient servant,

Cylinder—Shall be constructed of 31/2 mesh, .090-inch galvanized woven wire, rolled after being woven so that the intersections are interlocked. Cylinder heads shall be of spun galvanized steel, fitted to galvanized steel transmitter. Galvanized steel door hinged solidly to the woven wire to the cylinder head, to which they shall be securely riveted. Two inch metal ribs four inches in length shall be riveted to the woven wire and cylinder heads.

The galvanized steel cylinder door shall be of the hinged type, with perforations. Door shall have two latches. A galvanized steel reinforcing rib shall be riveted and soldered to the door sheet between the latches. A hook shall be provided for hanging the door.

Frame—The upper sections of both end frames shall be of cast iron, lined with galvanized steel sheets, and bolted together at the horizontal center line of the cylinder. The lower sections shall be bolted to the frame stand, which shall consist of heavy steel angles securely welded. The angles shall form the supports for the fan bearings and driving mechanism. The lower frame sections shall support the housing for the heating units.

Housing—The outer shell or housing shall be constructed of galvanized steel, rigidly attached to the upper and lower frame sections. Shall be of close fitting construction, to prevent leakage of air and heat. Housing shall be fitted with a sliding galvanized steel door.

Steam Heating Unit—The heating unit designed to operate on 100 pounds steam pressure shall be located in a galvanized steel housing at the upper rear of the tumbler. The heating unit shall be of the fin type and of ample capacity to supply sufficient heat to maintain the air entering the heater unit and then through the cylinders shall be heated while passing between the fins and over the pipes of the heating unit, and shall then be drawn through the cylinder by means of a fan located below the cylinder.

Gas Heating Unit—The heating unit shall be located in a galvanized steel housing at the upper rear of the tumbler. The heating unit shall consist of two 2-inch pipes extending the entire length of the housing. These pipes shall be plugged at one end and shall have two rows of 1/8-inch nipples one inch long, and be mounted about 11/2 inches apart the entire length of the two pipes.

At the other end of each 2-inch pipe shall be attached a gas and air mixing chamber for the purpose of obtaining the proper gas and air mixture. A large gas valve shall be connected to these mixing chambers for regulating the gas to be consumed.
