A pilot light shall extend from the main gas line to the burning chamber. Located within the housing or burning chamber shall be a sheet metal baffle plate fitted with a series of small fins. The air shall enter the housing through the screened top and shall pass between the baffle plate fins and be heated before being drawn through the cylinder by the fans. The baffle plate shall also prevent the air from passing into the gas flue. The heating unit shall be adjustable for various degrees of heat and shall be of ample capacity to insure proper heating of the tumbler.

Electric Heating Unit.—The heating unit shall be located in a galvanized steel housing at the upper rear of the tumbler. The unit shall consist of a frame inside which shall be incorporated electric heaters of proper capacity, arranged so that maximum heat radiation is obtained.

The heating unit shall be self-contained and easily removable. The air shall enter through the screened top of the housing, shall pass over the heating elements and shall then be drawn through the clothes by means of fans located below the cylinder.

The heaters shall be energized through a magnetic switch which shall be actuated by the closing of the shell door and interlocked so that the fan must be running while the heaters are in circuit. Opening the shell door shall de-energize the heater.

Fans.—There shall be one fan assembly on the 36 x 36 inch machine, and two on the 36 x 36 inch machine. Each fan unit shall consist of two cast aluminum paddle-wheel type fans, placed back to back in a galvanized steel housing. Galvanized steel clutches shall be attached to each side of the casing, and to the front bottom shelf above each fan assembly shall be 1/2 inches in diameter and 7/8 inches wide, and mounted on a through shaft mounted in self-aligning ball bearings, and shall be "V" belt driven.

Bearings.—The cylinder and fan bearings shall be of the self-aligning ball-bearing type. The intermediate bearing shall be plain.

Brake—Motor Drive.—Shall be of the manually operated type, located on the left hand end of the tumbler. The braking mechanism and the outer case door shall be interlocked with a switch in such a manner that all electrical circuits shall be automatically shut off when the brake shall be applied when the outer case door is open.

The motor shall be controlled by a fused link connected on the back of the machine and connected through a rack to the brake lever. The cylinder and fan function together at all times. When the brake is applied the brake shoe shall be brought into contact with the groove of the cylinder sheave by action of the counterweight brake shoe lever. The brake lever shall be used for stopping the brake from being applied when the tub door is closed. Opening the shell door shall break the motor circuit, apply the brake, and stop the fan and cylinder. The brake lever shall also be used for spotting the cylinder.

The brake handle and outer case door shall be interlocked so that whenever the case door is opened the shifting of the drive belt from the tight pulley to the loose pulley, while the case door is opened, will cause the brake to be applied automatically.

When the brake is applied the brake shoe shall be brought into contact with the cylinder sheave by action of a counterweight brake shoe lever. The brake shall not be applied when the tub door is closed. Opening the tub door shall shift the drive belt from the tight to the loose pulley and shall apply the brake and stop the machine. The brake lever shall also be used for spotting the cylinder.

Guards.—The cylinder and fan driving mechanism and "V" belts shall be enclosed in sheet metal guards to comply with safety codes.

Drive-Motor.—A single motor shall be mounted on a bracket which shall be bolted to the rear framework at the left hand end of the machine. A compound sheave on the motor shaft shall drive the fan and cylinder. A sheave wheel located on the left hand end of the shaft shall be connected to a compound motor sheave by a single "V" belt. A single "V" belt from the compound motor sheave shall drive the intermediate compound motor sheave wheel mounted on an oil bell tightener bracket on the left hand frame. The cylinder sheave shall be driven by a single "V" belt from the small sheave wheel of intermediate compound motor sheave wheel. The take-up for the "V" belt from the motor to the intermediate sheave shall be adjusted by moving the motor on the motor bracket.

Drive-Belt.—A jack-shaft support bracket shall be fastened to the left hand steel angle frame at the rear of the machine. The jack-shaft shall be provided with a tight and loose pulley. A sheave on the jack-shaft shall drive the fan sheave wheel. A second sheave on the jack-shaft shall also be provided with a sheave to drive the intermediate compound sheave bracket and upright support arms for the jack-shaft shall be adjustable for "V" belt take up.

Electrical Equipment.—The electrical equipment shall conform to applicable sections of standards of the National Electric Manufacturers' Association.

All wiring between electrical units mounted on the machine shall be furnished installed in accordance with the National Electrical Code.

Motor.—A single motor shall be furnished for driving both the cylinder and fan. The motor shall be ball-bearing, gear-reduction type, of ample capacity and such characteristics to operate the tumbler under continuous, full-load operating conditions, without motor temperature rise exceeding 40 C. rise above 40 C. ambient temperature.

Dear Mr. Orr,

Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret.

Enclosed please find a list of equipment in the old laundry building here, also three cuts of machines which the Sister Superior asked me to forward to you, and which she thinks would be necessary.

The old machinery is all belt-driven from the shafts enumerated in my list, and the power taken from the 10 h.p. motor. Whilst none of this equipment appears to have been in use since the former school building was burnt down, I am informed that it was in use up to that time.

The washer and the extractor appear to be in good condition.

In considering the equipping of the new laundry it would seem advisable to provide for individual motor drive for the several machines, in view of the high cost of electric service in this locality. If individual motors were used, it is likely that the present machines would need some alteration to adapt them for that purpose, and an inspection of them by a machinery expert would be advisable.

When installing a large machine like the Two Roll Flat Work Ironer, it may be necessary to ship it in sections and assemble it inside the laundry as the net size of the laundry doorway opening is 4'-11" x 6'-5", allowing for 5'-0" wide by 6'-6" high doors. The height is restricted by the depth of the re-inforced concrete beam supporting the concrete roof slab.

The old ironer and drying racks are in need of some repairs, and the steam boiler would need re-tubing before it could be used, but, having a new steam boiler in the building, I apprehend that this old one would not be put into service.

Your obedient Servant

H. Dawson,

Dear Mr. Orr,

Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School,
Lebret, Sask.

I beg to submit herewith my eighth fortnightly report on the progress of this building for the period ending Saturday June 29.

On Monday the 17th, six bricklayers started on the outside walls at the north end of the building, and this work has proceeded continuously throughout the period under review. Six more bricklayers were added to the crew on the 26th, and when work ceased at noon on the 29th, the outside walls had been raised to the ground floor level, all around the main building, except that part between the girls' entrance and the connecting passage to the kitchen wing. The north wall of the kitchen and scullery was also brought up to the same level.

The south section of the roof slab over the main building was placed on Wednesday the 16th, and concrete floor in the north end of the main basement, comprising boys' wash rooms and recreation rooms on the 22nd.

The concrete walls of extension for pump room were poured on the 25th, and the roof slab on the 26th. A first coat of bracc waterproofing was applied to the top of this slab on the 28th.

The plumbers completed their roughing-in below the basement floor from the centre to the south end of the main building, and the work was inspected when under smoke test on June 21st, by Mr. Halek, the Health Officer in this district for the Provincial Government. The work was passed, trenches filled in, and the south end of basement, comprising girls' wash rooms, recreation rooms and junior recreation room, levelled up in preparation for under-filling and concrete work.

The steamfitters have set the heating and high pressure boilers in place, steam mains and return lines in basement are fixed, except where the latter have to be placed under floor, and a number of steam risers roughly set in position from basement to first floor.

Electricians are well ahead of the other trades, in regard to the placing of conduit, outlets and panel boxes.

Three carloads of stone trim have been delivered, which are practically the complete requirements.

Six carloads of face brick, four carloads of hollow tile, and three carloads of common brick have been delivered.

The sheet metal and roofing contractor has brought all
the metal-clad doors for the stairways, and the frames for the ventilating registers to the building.

Cement finishers are working on the concrete ceilings with air-compressor chiecls, and trowelling up where necessary, the rough joints left by removal of metal forms.

No time has been lost during this period by weather, which has, in a general way, been fine and summer-like.

Your obedient Servant

H. Benson,

Dear Mr. Orr:

Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School
Lebret, Sask.

Regarding the rooms which are to have terrazzo floors there is some misunderstanding of the requirements on which I find it necessary to ask for your interpretation.

The notation headed "Floor Finishes" on Basement Plan, Sheet #3, calls for terrazzo in the Kitchen and Girls' Recreation Rooms, but makes no mention of the Scullery or Junior Recreation. The Contractors have apparently estimated on the basis of these two rooms having cement floors, but the Sister Superior informs me that she requested they should be terrazzo.

When the contractors figured on the use of red quarry tile in the kitchen and scullery, I was under the impression that it was to replace terrazzo in both places, which caused me to agree with the suggestion of a terrazzo cove in place of the glazed brick cove specified, at a saving of $44.00 over glazed brick Terrazzo cove, combined with glazed brick and a cement floor, does not seem appropriate, and the difficulty might be met by providing terrazzo in the scullery which would then suitably match the kitchen in all respects. I shall be glad to know if you favour this idea.

Whether the Junior Recreation Room should be terrazzo or cement finish is a matter of interpretation of the plans and specification, and under Clause 16, Page 9, your decision should rule.

Referring to the cement floor finish, as specified on Page 19, the mixture called for is one part of Portland cement, two parts of fine aggregate, and two parts of pea gravel graded between ¼" and 3/8" in size, and not over 4½ Imp. gallons of water per sack of cement.
This is a 1:4 proportion, whereas the C. E. S. A. standard specification recommends "the mix shall not be leaner than 1 part Portland cement and 3 parts of aggregate," where the top surface is subject to wear. I call this to your attention because the contractors inform me that the mix you specify was used at Lestock School and was not very successful.

They wish to get the basement floors laid shortly, to allow bricklayers to erect tile partitions thereon, and for the same reason are anxious to know when the chlorinator drain, and suction pipe under the main building can be laid, in connection with the water supply system.

Your obedient servant,

H. Dawson,
Supervising Architect, Lebret School

Dear Mr. Orr,

Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School,

I beg to submit herewith my ninth fortnightly report on the progress of construction here up to Saturday the 13th inst. Dominion Day being a public holiday, there was no activity until Tuesday the 2nd inst. when the bricklayers crew was increased to twelve men, and four more were added on the 8th. This part of the work has progressed without interruption, the outside walls being carried up as uniformly as possible all around.

The stone copings of laundry parapet wall were set on the 11th and on the boiler room walls on the 12th. The chapel walls and Indian room were completed up to the roof beams. The boiler stack was carried up to the level of the chapel roof slab, and the walls of main building from ground floor up to first floor beams, around the north half of the building, and up to sill level for the remaining part of this floor, by the 13th inst.

Stonework of the main entrance was erected up to the arch springing, and the arch stones set in place.

Window frames were placed by the carpenters ready for the bricklayers to build in, all around the ground floor walls, where not built above sill level. They also set a number of rough bucks for door frames in the basement, and formed the wood roof over the laundry.

Necessary steelwork of fire escapes has been built into place as the brickwork proceeded.

Concrete floors have been laid in the basement of the main building, with the exception of a strip left out for excavation of water main trench, and cement topping has been laid thereon where other finishes are not needed.

Cement finishers have completed work on concrete ceilings of ground floor, and about fifty per cent of similar work done on the first floor ceiling, following up air chisel operators smoothing off rough places left by removal of forms.

The plasterer brought his equipment to the job on the 12th and a carload of hardwall plaster was delivered on the same date. A start on the plaster work will be made as soon as tile partition work in basement can be erected for him to work on, a car of 4" tile having been delivered here today.

Mr. D.B.Gow visited the site on Wednesday and Thursday, 10th and 11th, staking out location of septic tank and disposal field, and making trial borings for location of intake, and of subsoil conditions on the disposal field. Sir:

The writer, accompanied by Mr. T. H. Burt of this office, was at the Lebret Indian School job on July 10th and 11th. The location for the septic tank was staked out as was also the east side of the location for the disposal bed. Several borings were driven on the location of the proposed site of the disposal bed and a boring was also taken near the water's edge to determine whether or not water could be obtained in suitable quantities by means of a well.

The boring upon the well site was driven from elevation 89 as shown on the plans, to elevation 80 and it was determined that an ample supply of water could be obtained by means of a well to be driven from contour 93. Instructions will be forwarded to the Supervising Architect with respect to the location and type of well which is to be constructed.

Seven borings taken on the site of the proposed disposal bed reveal soil conditions decidedly more favourable than was anticipated. In consequence it is considered that it will be necessary to use any other materials except those available on the site. It is not proposed to use crushed rock nor is it proposed to haul any sandy loam for the top covering as these materials are available at the location of the proposed site for the disposal bed.

It is quite probable that our estimate for the construction of the well will not be exceeded by the cost of actual construction, and our estimates for the construction of the disposal bed are considerably in excess of what it is anticipated the actual cost will now be. A little later we will forward you a plan showing the location of borings taken and also showing the nature of soil conditions as they were found to be.

I might point out that we also took borings at the site of the proposed new hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle so as to be in a position to proceed with plans and estimates for the water supply and sewage disposal systems that will be required at that Institution.

Dear Mr. Orr,

Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School,
Lebret, Sask.

I beg to submit herewith my tenth fortnightly report on the progress of this building for the period ending Saturday, the 27th inst.

During this period the bricklayers have carried the outside walls of main building up to the second floor level, except the portion surrounding the girls' wing south of the girls' stair, and this part was up to sill level when work ceased on the 27th.

The walls of the Chapel and Indian Room were finished, also the boiler chimney, and the stone copings placed. Stonework at the centre of the west front was set up to the second floor.

Tile partitions have been erected in the basement of the main building, and about half of the gypsum block partitions on the ground floor, one car-load being used. This part of the work is now waiting a further shipment of blocks, en route from Winnipeg.

Cement floor finish has been laid in the south half of the main building on the ground floor, and in one class room at the north end.

The rain water drain has been completed from the building to the watercourse in accordance with Mr. D.B. Gow's plan, two manholes have been constructed and domestic sewer laid and covered from the building to a point near the location of the proposed septic tank.

The plasterers have been working on the basement walls and partitions of the main building, and the boys' washrooms and recreation rooms have received the finishing coat.

All the formwork up to the roof level has been taken down and air compressor operators have followed up with smoothing form joints and finishers patching the concrete as necessary.

Wall brackets and landing frames for the fire escapes were set and built in as the brickwork proceeded, up to the second floor level.

Materials for asphalt roofing are on the site, and all roof areas at lower levels than that of the main building are practically ready for the roofer to work on.

Plumbers and steamfitters have continued roughing in for heating, drainage and water lines, and are now up to the second floor with the bulk of their risers and stacks.
The electrician has all wiring pulled for the ground floor lighting and a considerable part of the basement.

No delay has been experienced through bad weather, but it has been very hot and humid, with noon temperatures rising to 90 and 95 deg. F on several days.

I enclose a small folder of photos of the building, taken about the 19th inst:

Mr. W.H. Busby representing Stanley Brock Limited, visited the building on Monday the 22nd, inspected the contents of the old laundry, and the laundry in the new building. I supplied him with a pencil plan to enable his firm to make a lay-cut, and he had an interview with the Sister Superior with regard to the probable requirements.

Your obedient Servant

H. Dawson,

Dear Mr. Orr,

Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School.

I beg to submit herewith my eleventh fortnightly report on the progress of construction here for the period ending on Saturday August 10th.

The bricklayers completed the outside walls practically up to the roof slab, and made a start on the parapet walls at the north end of the building, bringing up about 200 lineal feet to coping level. They also built the gypsum block partitions enclosing the sacristy, finished the ground floor partitions and about half the partitions on the first floor.

The plastering in the basement of the main building is almost completed, also the south half of the ground floor, and the north half about ready for the putty coat. No plastering has yet been done in the laundry, or the chapel, or above the ground floor.

The 4" suction main having been installed where it passes under the building, that part of the basement which had been left open was filled in, watered, tamped, and the concrete floor laid so that the cement finish could be continued in the basement.

Cement finish has been completed on all the ground floor where called for, and in the first floor dormitories at the south end of the building.

The chlorinator drain and pump room floor drain have been installed, with the necessary access chambers in the former, and the trenches filled in, so that the kitchen and laundry floors can be laid and finished. Urinal fixtures have been placed in the boys' wash-rooms, and the floors made ready for the terrazzo finish. As these fixtures are located near one of the column footings it was found necessary to raise them on a step to avoid cutting into the footings for drain connections. An extra order has been given to the contractors for the additional concrete, and the terrazzo riser to match the terrazzo floor, to meet this condition.

The radiators have been delivered and the steamfitters have got some of them set in place in the basement.

The roofing contractor has laid and gravelled the roofs over the boiler room, chapel, laundry, Indian Room, south-east class room, sun room and rear entrances.

The carpenters have set grounds for blackboards in the class rooms, window frames and rough backs for walls and partitions in advance of the bricklayers and fitted and hung sash in all the basement windows.

The electricians have installed the heavy feed cables, switches, panels and control boxes where called for and are

Dear Mr. Orr,

Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School,
Lebret, Sask.

I beg to submit herewith my fifteenth fortnightly report on the progress of this building for the period ending Saturday October 5th.

One plasterer and his labourer are still on the job, to patch and make good after other trades.
The carpenters have finished all trim and hung all doors on the ground, first and second floors, and are doing similar work in the basement.
Painters are following up the carpenters as fast as the trim is in place.
The plumbers are connecting up the fixtures on the first and second floors and have the steel toilet partitions here.
The electrical work is ready for attaching the lighting fixtures. The wiring was inspected and passed by an inspector of the Saskatchewan Power Commission on Sept 27th.
The laying of field tile in the sewage disposal field was completed on the same date. The surplus subsoil was scraped off and the top-soil for the garden re-placed over about half the area treated.
The walls of the boiler room and pump room have been whitewashed and the concrete base for the pump and air compressor put in place.
I have today a letter from the general contractors, requesting that the Department supply sufficient coal and the necessary electric power to enable the heating system to be tested, in accordance with clause 38, page 95 of the Specification.
I made allusion to this in my letter to you of Sept. 25.
The weather continues fine for construction work, but keen night frosts are being experienced.

Your obedient Servant

H. Dawson,
Supervising Architect, Lebret School.

Dear Mr. Orr,

Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School,
Lebret, Sask.

Regarding the exposed concrete joists and ceilings here, the contractors have made an acceptable job of smoothing and trowelling with cement, but the lightness and general appearance would be much improved if these surfaces were given a white finish. This is particularly true of the chapel which is an important part of the institution, the staff rooms, and of some rooms in the basement, where the windows are a long distance from the opposite inside walls, and where an increased reflected light would be valuable.

I have obtained from Smith Bros & Wilson the enclosed estimate for applying two coats of Brandram-Henderson Sun-Flex on all the concrete ceilings except that of the boiler room, amounting to $2,922.00. Whilst this seems a large amount, it is on the basis of the moderate price of 30¢ per square yard of surface, and I believe the Department would be well advised to have the work done at the present time if possible, as it would give a permanent finish that would not need renewal or redecoration for several years.

I shall be glad to hear from you on this matter as soon as may be convenient.

Your obedient Servant

H. Dawson,
Supervising Architect, Lebret School.

Sir:

Enclosed you will please find four copies of the statement of account of Messrs. Smith Brothers and Alison Limited, Regina, covering the cost of work done and materials supplied in connection with the installation of the water supply and sewage disposal systems at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret, Saskatchewan.

There are also enclosed, in duplicate, copies of the letter from the Contractors submitting this statement to Mr. Dawson, Supervising Architect for the Department of Indian Affairs. Mr. Dawson's letter forwarding the statement to this office I would request that the three copies of the statement with the original signature of Mr. Dawson be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs together with one copy of the correspondence transmitting the statement.

You will note that the cost of the installation of the water supply and sewage disposal systems amounts to $8,248.85. The original estimated cost covering this work, as prepared in this office, was $10,472.37. However, at that time we assumed that very adverse conditions would be experienced in connection with the construction of the disposal bed. At a later date test borings taken revealed very favourable conditions and accordingly the cost of the disposal bed was greatly reduced. The estimated cost, as submitted in August by the Contractors, covering this work was $9,629.85 which statement was prepared after the results of borings had been given to them showing favourable conditions at the site of the disposal bed.

I would draw to your attention the fact that while this work was carried out under the direction of this office, yet the supervision of the work of the Contractor was in charge of Mr. Dawson, Supervising Architect, and an employee of the Department of Indian Affairs. Consequently this office does not take any responsibility whatever for the account as submitted by Messrs. Smith Brothers and Alison Limited. Mr. Dawson, Supervising Architect, has approved of the statement of account as submitted. It is possible that the Department of Indian Affairs might request that this office procure its approval of the statement of account. If so it will be necessary for an official from this office to proceed to Regina and examine the time sheets, pay rolls, original invoices and cost data of the Contractors.

I would suggest that the Department of Indian Affairs be asked to give immediate attention to the matter.

AGREEMENT made this day of A.D. 1935

BETWEEN:

FATHER G. LEONARD C.M., I.,
Principal of the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret, hereinafter called "The Principal"

OF THE FIRST PART

- and -

MONTREAL ENGINEERING COMPANY LIMITED
being a Company incorporated by Letters Patent and having its Head Office in the City of Montreal hereinafter called "The Company"

OF THE SECOND PART

WHEREAS the Principal is engaged in the operation of the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret, Saskatchewan.

WHEREAS The Company is engaged in the operation of electrical generating plants, transmission lines and distribution systems in the Province of Saskatchewan.

AND WHEREAS The Principal is desirous of purchasing electrical energy and power from the Company hereinafter provided.

NOW THEREFORE THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH:

1. AGREEMENT TO BUY AND SELL

The Company shall sell to the Principal and the said Principal shall purchase from the Company electric power and energy subject to the terms and conditions hereinafter set forth.

2. COMMENCEMENT OF SUPPLY

The Company shall commence the supply of electric power and energy hereunder to the Principal under the terms of this Contract on the First day of December 1935.
TERM OF CONTRACT

This Agreement shall continue in full force and effect for a period of five years from the commencement of this Agreement hereunder, and in the absence of either party giving to the other six months notice in writing of its intention to terminate this Agreement at the end of five years, then this Agreement shall continue in full force and effect from year to year thereafter, subject to cancellation at the end of any yearly period on six months notice in writing.

4. POINT OF DELIVERY

The Point of delivery of such electrical energy shall be at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret, Saskatchewan.

5. SUB-STATION AND SWITCHING EQUIPMENT

The Company shall maintain at its own cost and expense the necessary sub-station transformers, fuses and other protective equipment at the point of delivery referred to in Clause 4.

6. METERING EQUIPMENT

The Company shall provide and maintain suitable metering equipment for measuring the maximum Kilowatts of demand and the energy consumed in Kilowatt Hours.

7. VOLTAGE AND FREQUENCY

The electric power and energy to be supplied hereunder, shall be furnished in the form of three phase, sixty cycle alternating current to deliver a normal pressure of approximately Two Hundred and Thirty (230) volts, with grounded neutral provision for One Hundred and Fifteen (115) volts single phase for lighting and heating circuits, and shall not be subject to fluctuations of voltage or of frequency of sufficient extent to prevent the rendering of reasonable and efficient service.
SERVICE CHARGE

In respect to the maximum demand for billing purposes for electric energy used for lighting, the principal shall pay to the Company during the term of this Agreement a monthly service charge of $1.00 per month per Kilowatt of demand established during that month, which in any case shall not be less than Fifty Percent (50%) of the maximum demand once established.

In respect to the demand for billing purposes for electric energy used for power purposes the Principal shall pay to the Company One ($1.00) dollar per month per horsepower of name plate rating of electric motor installation.

ENERGY CHARGE

In respect to the electric energy supplied, the Principal shall (in addition to the Service Charge) pay to the Company for such energy at the following net rates.

For the first One Hundred (100) Kilowatt Hours per month per Kilowatt of demand registered on the lighting meter, Five (5¢) cents per kilowatt hour. All over One Hundred (100) Kilowatt Hours per month per Kilowatt of demand, Three and one-third (3-1/3¢) cents per Kilowatt Hour.

For the first One Hundred (100) Kilowatt Hours per Horsepower of motor installation, Five (5¢) cents per Kilowatt Hour. All over One Hundred (100) Kilowatt Hours per Horsepower of motor installation, Three and one-third (3-1/3¢) cents per Kilowatt Hour.

CONTINUITY OF SERVICE

The Company shall cause to be taken all usual precautions to guard against interruptions in the supply of electric power and energy to the Principal and shall cause to be terminated such interruptions with all possible dispatch. If interruptions are necessary or unavoidable for repairs, overhauling, or inspection of equipment or for improving or adding to its
equipment, the Company shall give reasonable notice to the said Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret.

11. **LIABILITY**

The Company shall in no case be liable or responsible for accident, loss or damage to persons and property resulting, arising or accruing in any way from action, effect, or use of electric power or energy after the same shall have been supplied to the Principal at the point of delivery.

12. **TESTING METERS**

The meters installed in the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret shall at all times be kept in good working order and shall be tested from time to time to test their accuracy. If at any time the Principal is not satisfied as to the accuracy of the said metering equipment he may upon giving Ten (10) days notice to the Company have the said metering equipment tested or calibrated by a competent person delegated so to do by the Department of Trade and Commerce of the Dominion of Canada. If such test or calibration shows that such metering equipment is in error by more than two (2%) percent then such metering equipment shall forthwith be corrected or replaced by one that is accurate. If the inaccuracy of the metering equipment as shown by such test demanded by the Principal is found to be such that the quantity of power delivered as recorded by it is in error by more than two (2%) percent then the Company shall bear the cost of the test; but if the error is found to be less than two (2%) percent then the Principal shall bear the cost of such test. The bills for power supplied during the three calendar months preceding such test shall be corrected in the proportion of the error of the metering equipment provided such error exceeds the aforesaid limit of two (2%) percent and such correction shall be accepted by the Principal and Company as settlement in full to that date of all claims on account of inaccuracy of metering equipment.
PAYMENT OF ACCOUNTS

The Company shall render its account to the Principal in accordance with provisions of this agreement within the first five (5) days of each calendar month for the electrical energy and power supplied during the previous month and the Principal agrees to make payment of the same within ten (10) days of the rendering of each such account. All payments are to be made at the Regina Office of the Company. The Company may, on giving five (5) days written notice to the Principal and without prejudice to any of its other legal remedies, cut off the supply of electrical energy and power to the Principal in the event of any amount due for electrical energy and power under the provisions of this agreement remaining unpaid after the same shall have become due under this agreement.

14. ACT OF GOD

If at any time during the continuance of this agreement the operation of the works of either party hereto is suspended or curtailed owing to war, rebellion, Act of God, or other cause beyond the control of such party, or strikes, differences with workmen or like causes, the party whose operations are so suspended or curtailed, shall not be liable to the other party under this agreement until the cause of such suspension or curtailment has been removed, PROVIDED that each of the parties hereto shall take all reasonable precautions and adopt all reasonable measures to prevent or remove the cause of such suspension or curtailment.

15. TAXATION

In the event that the existing taxation, for which the Company is liable, be increased, or that any new charges or taxes be imposed on the Company by an Act of the Parliament of Canada or the Legislature of the Province of Saskatchewan, or by any Government Department, either Dominion or Provincial, or by any taxing authority whatsoever, the foregoing rates at option of the Company, may be increased commensurately.
16. ARBITRATION

If at any time during the continuance of this Agreement or after the termination thereof, any dispute, difference, or question arises between the parties hereto as to the construction, meaning or effect of this Agreement or anything herein contained, or as to the performance or fulfillment of any of the terms, provisions or conditions in this Agreement contained, then in such case, every such dispute, difference or question shall be submitted to arbitration, one arbitrator to be appointed by each of the parties, and the two so appointed to select a third, the decision of the majority of such arbitrators to be binding upon both parties, and the parties hereto hereby agree to take such steps as may be necessary to give effect to the finding of such arbitrators.

17. SUCCESSORS AND ASSIGNS

This Agreement and everything herein contained shall ensue to the benefit of and be binding upon the parties hereto, their and each of their respective successors and assigns.

Dear Sir;

I have today been in touch with Mr Murrison of the Dept of Indian Affairs of this City, re, the installation of Electrical equipment for the Lebret Indian Industrial School, and, the Hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle, and as a result have been advised to get in touch with you with the view to securing the specifications relative to the refrigeration requirements of these two buildings.

I might say that I am representing the "Modern Electric and Refrigeration Service" in this City, and have the exclusive Provincial agency for the Copeland Commercial Refrigeration Co, a company of outstanding merit in this particular phase of Electrical service, and who have a range of equipment suitable to meet the demand of the largest institutions.

As for my personal experience in this line, it was my privilege to be the first in this province, as well among the first Three in Canada to qualify, as a result of having received Factory training with, the General Motors Corporation in their Refrigeration Factory at Dayton Ohio U.S.A., eight years ago, since then I have had the privilege to install the first units of this description in the province, and among some of these installations are the Fort Sanatorium, the old Indian Industrial School at Lebret (now burned down) the Parliament buildings in Regina and the Mental Hospital at Weyburn Sask having installed the latter this last Fall.

Should you require further references I would be only too pleased to submit
a few names from among Regina's most prominent business men.

I would be very pleased to hear from you and to have the opportunity of submitting for your approval a tender on this equipment; if necessary I could have my tender accompanied by a certified cheque to cover half the amount of the tender.

Trusting you will be able to send me the specifications covering these two jobs at your earliest convenience, and thanking you in anticipation.

Yours Sincerely;

Modern Electric and Refrigeration Service.

Writing".

Principal, selected the site mentioned in my telegram, some two years ago, and it is situated where the best farming land on the reserve lies. There is a level piece of table land in close proximity to a lively spring, and with excellent drainage from school site away from the river valley. The Inspector estimates that the school site would be approximately 50 feet higher than the spring, and it would be an easy matter to have a storage reservoir at the spring and pump water to the school buildings. Dear Sir,

I beg to inform you that the location for our new school has been done and the surrender by the Indians of one mile square or one section has been made to the school.

Now I presume that it is the intention of the Department that fencing and breaking of a certain part of the land be done right away this summer and that the Department will reimburse the cost of the outlay. For the fencing of that section either Mr. Turner or myself could see to it. We could employ some of the Indians to do the fencing as there are some amongst them that have done the same already and with satisfaction. We have all the posts on hand ready to be used. As for the breaking I believe that we should break the surrender in less than 75 acres and it can easily be done as the most part of the land is open except a few bushes here and there. We could easily get Indians to do the work either by using a tractor or horses. The breaking should be done not later than the beginning of June.

I humbly submit that the Honourable Deputy makes his intention known about these two questions either to Mr. Turner or to me at his earliest convenience.

Dear Sirs,

In answer to your letter of the 7th which was received today asking information re claims of Brown and Hudson as to change of site of the R.C. Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, I will give you my opinion on the several items in the order as they appear in your letter.

ITEM NO. 1. Building and furnishing camp. $1,200.

In the first place the specifications call for the school to be erected on the Onion Lake Indian Reserve, and that the bidders were supposed to visit the site of the proposed work and make up for themselves as to the existing conditions. The buildings referred to as bunk house, cook house, office for the company, also office for the Inspector did not cost them $200.00 altogether and then they got a fair price for them when they were through with them and in my opinion it would have cost them far more if they had rented buildings.

ITEM NO. 2. Mailing water. $1,200.

There is a lake about 200 yards from where the school site is and a fine spring about 150 yards from the building, and if Mr. Hudson had taken the interest in the work he should have done he could have put up a small gasoline engine and a pump at the spring and could have supplied all the water required for the work and also for drinking purposes. This spring is at present supplying all the water required for the school, and as for Mr. Turner saying that the water was right at the site he was correct. And in all my conversation with Mr. Turner he never mentioned any other site than the one where the school is located, and the water is far better.

ITEM NO. 3. Difference in cost of gravel. $1,200.

All the gravel used in the building did not cost them more than $1.25 per yard as most of it was procured within a mile of the job and when the pit run out they hauled from another pit from which they paid $1.25 per yard for hauling and 20 cents to the owner. The reason the Government had to pay $1.75 for gravel was on account of most of the teams were out harvesting. Mr. Hudson put their trucks at hauling gravel and they made eight trips per day with each truck from the farthest pit.

ITEM No. 4. Mailing lumber and camp supplies.

The price charged for hauling lumber from Onion Lake was $3.00 per thousand, and the amount of lumber they received from Onion Lake was approximately 30,000 feet but the balance of 125,000 feet lumber nearly about 90,000 feet they saved money on the hauling as the new school is about 7 miles closer to the Railway than the old school site, and the above applies to the Camp Supplies.

Referring to the change of site they never mentioned anything to me about it till about the time the contract should have been completed and in talking with the Agent Mr. Turner at Onion Lake and also the authorities at the St. Anthony's School they told me that they had never considered having the school erected at the old site in Onion Lake.

There are some conditions that existed in the handling of the work in connection with the erection of the school which was anything but good management, and I feel sorry for Mr. Brown as any loss which has occurred through the way the work was handled will have to be borne by him, but of course it was his own fault as he should have known the man he was sending there to handle the work.

I hope that the above explanation may be of assistance to you in deciding re the claim referred to, and in reference to the first clause of your letter of regret in having to trouble me in regard to the particulars, I am only too pleased to give you any assistance possible in getting the matter

Dear Sir:

Attention - Mr. R. G. Orr:

It was with considerable surprise that I learned yesterday from your telegram - re water shortage at the Lebret School - that the building had not been occupied all winter. Since the school has not been in operation the disposal bed has not been kept open and of course the ground over the same is completely frozen. Even a partial operation of the school would not have prevented this freezing. Under such circumstances to put the system into operation at this time is only inviting trouble and we would not be at all surprised to hear that the sewage has now backed up into the Institution.

The sewage disposal system complete will take about 20,000 gallons after which, if the disposal bed is not open, the sewage must back up into the building.

Yours truly,

D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.

I have today received the following letter from Mr. Gow with reference to the sewage disposal system; he is quite right in his contention, and I would ask you therefore to keep a close watch and exercise care.

R. Gurney Orr.

Dear Dr. McGill:

You have already been acquainted, I am sure, with the fact that the Lebret School has been officially opened and that all the children are now in attendance.

Last December when I had occasion to take up with you the matter of compensation to the Reverend Oblate Fathers of the Lebret Scholasticate and Seminary, you suggested that the fairest way to proceed was to charge a nominal rent for the time the boys were housed in the Seminary. We then agreed that the sum of $100.00 per month could be considered, if not in the light of full compensation, at least as sufficient remuneration to enable the Oblate Fathers to repair that portion of the building occupied by the boys of the School.

You will no doubt recall that the old Lebret School was destroyed on or about November 13 and that the boys were immediately received by the Oblate Fathers in their Seminary. It was on the 25th of March 1936, I understand, that the new School was occupied. The children, therefore, lived at the Scholasticate for a little more than forty months. I am enclosing an Invoice in triplicate dated March 19th for $4000. which will cover the 40 months of occupancy at the rate of $100. per month.

As the Oblate Fathers have to proceed forthwith with the repairs to their Seminary, your kind attention to this matter will be greatly appreciated.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Orr:

I have for attention your letter of March 16th with reference to the water supply at the Lebret Indian School and note that you consider the only solution to the problem is the extension of the intake out into the lake.

It is unfortunate indeed that the well has failed to yield adequate supply of water but I am inclined to believe that the supply will increase with the thawing out of the ground so that there will be no immediate need of the extension of the intake. In my opinion the extending of the intake out into the open water of the lake should only be undertaken as a last resort. The lake is quite open and bottom appears muddy and moderate winds cause the water to become quite dirty. Furthermore there is undesirable algae growth and the water takes on an offensive odor. It would be undesirable to install a filter-ling plant and the algae growth in the water would then seriously interfere with the operation of the filter and also of the chlorinating machine. The water supply would always be objectionable from this source. Again the laying of an intake out into any such body of water, to be laid so as to be safe from frost penetration, is usually very expensive and very frequently is accompanied by much grief. We had our own experience at the Geraldine Jeffery Indian School at Kenora and I am also of the opinion that the intake at the R. C. Indian School at Kenora is broken at one or more connection thus giving cause to the complaints that sand is being pumped at the present time. There was also the experience of the Oblate fathers in extending the water main at the school near Winnpegosis. The writer has been watching fairly closely the efforts of the Town of Kenora in extending an intake out into the Lake of the Woods. Their initial attempt last summer, under the direction of Winnipeg Engineers, resulted in the line breaking at two or three places and it was decided to postpone the laying of the line until it could be lowered from the ice. New pipe was purchased and an effort was made to lower the pipe from the ice. It now lies at the bottom of the lake in several pieces and it has been decided to attempt to lay the line again under open water conditions. As you are aware, it was because of such conditions in the lake water and also on account of the difficulty of laying pipe lines out into deep water that we were willing to take considerable chances on the surface well proposition at Lebret.

Before deciding to extend the intake out into the lake, I think it would be advisable to explore further the possibility of securing an adequate water supply to a well by seepage from the lake - this to be done by means of borings taken at different points in the vicinity of the intakes etc. It might also be advisable to give consideration to the drilling of a deep artesian well. These borings can be taken as soon as the frost is out of the ground and inquiries can be made regarding the possibilities of an artesian well and the probable cost of the same.

Yours truly,

H. Gurney Orr, Esq.,
Architect, Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

D. H. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.

The Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, conducted under the auspices of the Oblate Order and located at Lebret, Sask., was totally destroyed by fire November 13th, 1932. It was necessary to provide immediate accommodation for the male pupils and the male members of the staff. Arrangements were made with the Oblate Order for the rental of their seminary at Lebret. This building is located on the opposite side of the lake from the site of the school and was the only available building suitable for the purpose. The Department agreed with the Oblate Order to pay them a nominal rental at the rate of $100 per month during the period the seminary was occupied by the boys and staff of the school.

A new residential school has been completed, to replace the building destroyed by fire, and was occupied on March 25th, 1936. Funds to provide for the payment of the rental for a period of 40 months - November 13th, 1932, to March 25th, 1936 - at $100 per month, are available in our Estimates for the current fiscal year.

Sir:

I have for attention your letter of July 7th with reference to the inadequate water supply at the Qu'Appelle Indian School at Lebret, Sask. However, on that date Mr. W. H. Wallace of this office and myself were at Lebret investigating the situation.

The present source of water supply for the school is a well 6' diameter, sunk to elevation 80.9 at a spot about 150' from Lebret Lake, the present water level of which is approximately 85.0. Previous to digging the well, borings were taken and these indicated favourable conditions for steady seepage from the lake. The quantity of water secured from the well, while considerable, was insufficient for the school's needs last November a trench was excavated from the well for 95 feet toward the water's edge; the depth of the trench being reported to be the same as the bottom of the well. This trench was filled with gravel for a depth of 4' from the bottom. This expedient increased the water supply but severe winter conditions curtailed the seepage into the well to an extent that caused a severe water shortage at frequent intervals during the winter.

It is essential that an adequate supply of water be available for the operation of this school. However, from the very first it has been our objective to secure an adequate water supply without resorting to direct pumping from Lebret lake. Extending an intake out to a sufficient depth of water presents many difficulties and involves a large expenditure of money. Again the lake water frequently gets stirred up and becomes dirty, algae growth is extensive and the water itself becomes warm and gives off an offensive odor.

We have given consideration to the laying of a gravity main from 6' depth of water to the well, also to laying a pumping main from the present main in the well to a 6' depth of water. We have also given consideration to the sinking of a well 150 to 200 feet at the school, to the deepening of the present well and also to the excavation of an additional well. We had Messrs. Smith Brown & Wilson prepare us an estimate of the cost of pumping directly from the lake and also the cost of drilling a well 150 feet. Their letter is attached.

We are of the opinion that had the trench been extended last November to the water's edge and to a depth level with the bottom of the well and back filled with gravel and clay on top that a sufficient supply of water would have been obtained. Therefore we consider that the trench be extended to the water's edge and be put down to elevation 80.0, be back-filled to a depth of 5 feet from the bottom with gravel and covered with clay or loam. Backfilling is important in order to prevent frost.

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Re: Lebret Indian School.

Reference Lebret water supply, we have estimated to do the following work:

1. Excavate from existing well to lake approximately 160 lin. ft. and connect pipe line to present 4" water line and backfill same.

2. Excavate lake bottom out from shore 175 lin. ft. to depth below water of 6 feet.

3. Lay 4" AntheaCast Iron water pipe from well to a point in the lake totalling 335 lin. ft., with Intake Fitting and Valve at the end.

4. Install additional Intake Screen over the intake and stone mound approximately 10' x 10'.

5. Drive 3" plank sheet piles both sides of pipe line from edge of water to a point 175 feet out into the lake with 6" x 6" walings and 1" iron tie rods. These two rows of sheet piles to be 10 feet between and the whole crib filled with rock from the shore to a point 175 feet out.

6. Cover the remaining 200 feet of pipe beyond the crib with rock 4 feet by 2 feet as a protective cover.

7. Connect present line in well so that well water is valved off from the suction line but can be opened up if required.

The above we estimate would cost $6,580.00.

We also estimate to drill well 150 feet deep through bottom of present well and install 150 feet of 8" casing including necessary shoe at bottom of casing for the sum of $450.00.

We have no assurance that this well would increase the water supply sufficiently nor have we any guarantee that water will rise to the present well level. So if the well is drilled it will probably be necessary to install a deep well pump to lift the water to the present well and provide power continuously for this purpose. It may also be advisable to install a small pump house over the well to house the equipment.

If you think some of the items we have enumerated are not necessary or can be cut down in quantity we would be pleased to do the work on the same cost plus basis as the other work has been done.

Sir:

On July 7th Mr. W. H. Wallace and the writer visited the Qu'Appelle Indian School and accompanied by the engineer made an examination of the water supply and sewage disposal systems. The principal of the school was away in Winnipeg and due to the summer vacation, the institution was pretty much shut down. The question of water supply is dealt with in another letter and this letter will serve to draw to the attention of the Department of Indian Affairs some conditions at the school that demand attention.

Originally our plans called for one single sewer line from the building to septic tank and a single storm water drain and while both were to be laid in the same trench as far as possible, yet there was to be no possible way of the contents of either escaping to the other. The Resident Architect authorized the contractors to insert in both lines in the manholes two Y's thus exposing the contents of the Y's. Unfortunately the Y's were not provided with screw plugs. Consequently some time after the system was put into operation the screen at the entrance to the septic tank became clogged with old clothes, boots, etc., not being cleaned periodically, and the sewerage backed up to the nearest manhole where it overflowed through the open Y's into the storm drain. The outlet of the storm drain was blocked, probably frozen, but the line became plugged with sewerage. The sewerage then backed up into the septic tank and when the blockage was broken through the open Y's and eventually the blockage was discovered in the school. The sewage even backed up through the 1/2" pipe housing the 3" chlorinator drainage tubing, filling the two inspection chambers. The screen to the septic tank was cleaned but nothing has been done towards opening up the storm water drain, cleaning the filth from the manholes and from the inspection openings along the chlorinator drain. All storm water now passes through the septic tank and disposal bed.

Examination of the pump room showed it to be dirty, untidy and the floor cluttered up with tools, paint cans, bags of salt and debris. The windows, ordinary and storm, were thoroughly sealed and no ventilation allowed. The machinery shows neglect.

The Saskatchewan Department of Health reported the water supply unsafe for drinking without treatment, so a chlorinating machine was installed. The Company making the installation set it in operation and instructed the engineer. It was then shut off and has not been in operation. Upon being closely questioned the Engineer offered several explanations, such as the Company promised to send silver nipples and extra hose but did not, the chlorinator used too much water etc.

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power and
Hydrometric Bureau, OTTAWA.

Company provided the extra silver nipples and 100 feet of extra hose free of cost and the wastage of water is not excessive. That no epidemic of typhoid was experienced amongst the Indian children speaks well for their hardihood, for the staff drink water hauled from a well in the village, the water from which is not contaminated.

A water softener was installed primarily to eliminate the rapid corrosion due to hard water usually experienced with the heating system, high pressure steam boiler and the water heater. Unsoftened water is used entirely in the water heater, although we intended it was to be entirely soft water. The Engineer explained he had been told to shut off the soft water as too frequent regenerating of the softeners was being experienced. Apparently the water softener is being inefficiently operated.

The unfortunate consequences of having unqualified inexperienced and insufficient engineers in some of the Indian Schools are very evident at Lebret. It is not the fault of the individual as he probably knows little or nothing about the machinery installation and is required to do much outdoor work as well.

The School is now mostly empty and affords the opportunity of carrying out the following necessary work and having instructions issued so that difficulties will not be experienced later.

(1) The Chlorinating Machine must be in operation continuously and if there is a District Medical Superintendent, he should visit the school weekly to see that chlorination is effective. A second cylinder of chlorine should be supplied the school.

(2) The storm water drain must be cleared, even though it be necessary to dig down to it. The outlet should be lowered and protected from freezing so readily.

(3) The two manholes on the sewer line must be thoroughly cleaned and flushed. The Y's must be provided with screwed plugs and the plugs put in place. Covers are worthless as has been experienced.

(4) The chlorinating drainage line must be flushed out and the inspection chambers cleaned.

Instructions should be issued the Principal that softened water exclusively must be used in the heating system and hot water heaters and that a 95% softened water supply must be used in the high pressure steam boiler. If these instructions are not complied with, the soft water piping to laundry and kitchen should be removed.

(6) The Principal of the School should be instructed that the screen in front of the entrance to the septic tank requires frequent cleaning and that the septic tank should be cleaned at least annually.
The equipment of the school and its operation should be in charge of a qualified and competent engineer whose time would be fully devoted to operation and maintenance.

The cleaning up of the storm sewer, the manholes and chlorinator drain is very urgent and important and should not be entrusted to the School Management. It should not be necessary to engage a plumbing firm. Mr. Wright who was Superintendent for Messrs. Smith Brothers & Wilson on the Hospital Job at Fort Qu'Appelle, is unengaged at present, resides at Fort Qu'Appelle and with the aid of two or three men could quickly put things in first-class condition.

Possibly the Indian Inspector at Regina could undertake to arrange for and see that the work outlined above is carried out. Periodic inspection of this school will be advisable and unless a good reliable engineer is placed on the job, trouble may be expected with the operation of much of the equipment installed.

In closing I might mention another objectionable feature noted at the school, although it is possibly outside the scope of our activity at the School. The constant dripping of the condensation on the uncovered cold water pipes throughout the basement, in class-rooms, etc., is ruining the floors, the linoleum, etc., and is very objectionable. Covering of these pipes is worthy of attention.

Your obedient servant,

D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.

Ottawa, July 28th, 1936.

Reverend Sir,-

The Department is much concerned with a report recently received regarding the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. I desire to direct your personal attention to the following:-

(1) Sewer line from building to septic tank and storm water drain:-

It has been found that the screen at the entrance to the septic tank has been allowed to become clogged with old clothes, boots, etc. As a result, the sewerage backed up to the nearest manhole, where it overflowed into the storm drain. Nothing has been done towards opening up the storm water drain nor cleaning the filth from the manholes and from the inspection openings along the chlorinator drain.

To overcome this, the Department requires that the screen in front of the entrance to the septic tank be cleaned at least once a week and the septic tank cleaned at least annually. The storm drain must also be cleared and the two manholes on the sewer line must be thoroughly cleaned and flushed.

(2) Pump room:-

Examination of this room showed it to be dirty and the floor cluttered up with tools, paint cans, etc. The windows were thoroughly sealed and no ventilation allowed and the machinery showed neglect.

The Department expects that all unnecessary articles in this room be removed at once and the room itself, as well as the machinery, should be kept in the very best possible condition.

Chlorinating machine:-

The water is unsafe for drinking without treatment and,

Rev. M. de Bretagne, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Qu'Appelle Indian Res. School,
Lebret, Sask.
to overcome this, a chlorinating machine was installed. It is found that the machine has not been kept in operation and, as a result, the children have been drinking impure water. If this condition is allowed to continue, an outbreak of typhoid is almost inevitable.

The chlorinating machine must be kept in operation continuously and the Department is issuing instructions to the Medical Superintendent, Dr. Simes, to examine the water periodically in order to ascertain if it is safe for drinking purposes. The chlorinating drainage line should be flushed out and the inspection chambers cleaned.

(4) Water softener:

A water softener was installed primarily to eliminate the rapid corrosion due to hard water usually experienced with a high pressure heating system. It is found that unsoftened water is used wholly in the water heater, although it is intended that soft water should be used entirely.

The Department must insist that softened water be used exclusively in the heating system and hot water heaters and that a 95% softened water supply must be used in the high pressure steam boiler. Unless this is done, the heating system will be ruined within a short time.

The Department trusts that you will give the above matters your personal attention. You should assure yourself that the engineer is fully competent to handle the machinery that has been installed in the Qu'Appelle School. The Department cannot hold itself responsible for damage done to the system if such damage is caused by carelessness or incompetence of the engineer.

I may add that immediate steps are being taken to provide an adequate water supply at the Qu'Appelle School.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes.

The Honorable the Superintendent General,

It has developed at the new Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School that the water supply as at present installed is inadequate to meet the requirements of the Institution. Mr. Gow, District Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch at Winnipeg, under whose supervision this portion of the work was carried out, has recommended that the trench connecting the well be extended to the lake. Dear Sir,

Re: Yours 114-0-5 - 17th ins.

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of same as well as the one dated July 28th and wish to bring to your information that I much regret not to have given any answer to your first letter, but probably when you would have listened to my explanations you will understand the difficulties we have presently to face with.

As you probably know, I am just recently appointed Principal of this School, and before being capable of forming any judgment on the capacity of my staff, I needed a little time. Moreover by the sharp answers given to our Engineer by the author of the report you received, I thought to have a certain right to think that it was prudent before speaking on behalf or against him to see if no exaggeration had crept in.

Some days before receiving your letter I had the pleasure of having the welcome visit of the Secretary, Mr McKenzie himself, who benevolently asked me what I figure would be better for the water question. And by this very fact, I thought that his kind promise of helping me would, at his return, dispose the Department on my favor. Because, I have to say here, that I saw a certain connection between the shortage of water supply and certain reproaches made for instance on account of not using the chlorinating machine, what said our engineer would cause loss of chlorine gas when the pump would operate with automatic start and an empty well.....

On the time being Mr Rose was sent by Mr Gow to give us more water. His work is nearly completed but cannot give any satisfaction. It consists in digging a little further the shore of the lake that is very shallow and will have a lower level in the coming winter. It will freeze again and does not give the required amount of water any way. Mr Rose claims that he cannot do more, for such are the instructions he received.

In the presence of this fact I have to conclude
that a serious step should be taken to give us the most necessary supply of such a large institution and this as soon as possible.

But may I suggest before consulting my own provincial religious authority that probably Brother Gauthier would supervise and direct such a work at a far lower cost and with the same efficiency as any contractor. The Department appointed him in Camperville some years ago where he laid a 3000 ft pipe. Here it is required an extension of a few only, the pump being installed already, I do not think possible that the price of material required and the cost of work would amount so much. But of course I do not take the responsibility of this advice if the intention of the Department is different.

To the second item mentioned in yours July 28th, I beg to inform you that instructions were given the Engineer about the sewer line. Here again he partly accused the contractor who obliged him to let some holes opened the storm drain being frozen.

I gave instructions about the required order of a pump room, of the chlorinating machine with the restriction of the engineer's above mentioned remark.

About the water softener, the two remarks of our Engineer are that he mentioned to the Inspector that a third tank be added as well as a gauge in a way that he might use softened water in the water heater and be able to follow the density of his water.

As a conclusion I wish to assure the Department that I intend to do in new charge the same effort that I have done in Fort Frances for the betterment of the School. I have lost much time since I am here for the sake of recruiting and this not in neglecting the building itself. At my own expenses I have covered all non painted floors with varnish specially made for preventing cement dust so noxious to the lungs. I wish to do more inside and outside to cooperate with the Department for improving this beautiful School. Today not to postpone my answer I have answered from my bed where I lay sick.

About the engineer I have to say that I would see in the very near future what to do and if necessary to provide for another.

Yours truly,

Rev. M de Bretagne O.M.I.
Principal.
Sir:

Re: Water Supply - Qu'Appelle Indian School.

Mr. J. T. Rose has returned from Lebret after carrying out further work in connection with the water supply.

It was definitely determined that the seepage into the present well is not from the lake and that the soil conditions along the lake shore in that vicinity are such that there can be no infiltration into a well from the lake itself. Such seepage as occurs is evidently from springs arising in the hills. This seepage is insufficient for the needs of the school.

It is unfortunate that these conditions were not previously determined. Borings taken early in 1935 in the vicinity of the well showed no clay but gravel, sand and quicksand with the water at the same level as the lake. Borings attempted at the shore line were impossible because of the coarse nature of gravel encountered.

Please refer to our letter of April 2nd last to Mr. R. Gurney Orr, in connection with the water supply. It would now appear that as a last resort we must extend the intake out into the lake. Soundings have been taken and it was found that the lake bottom is very even and that an intake line approximately 550 feet in length will be required from the connection at the present well.

Please refer also to the estimate of cost supplied by Messrs. Smith Brothers & Wilson covering the laying of an intake from the well 535 feet into the lake. Their estimate covers pretty much what would be involved in extending the intake, but the depth of water obtainable 535 feet from the well at present lake level would not exceed 5.0 feet. At 600 feet from the well the depth of water is 6.0 feet and 650 feet from the well the depth of water is 7.5 feet. It would not be feasible to extend the pipe line to secure 7.5 ft. depth of water as lake elevations lower than the present can be expected. We do not consider covering of the pipe line beyond the cribwork essential.

We consider that Smith Brothers & Wilson Limited estimated cost is probably excessive, even if the line is extended to 950 feet. The pipe line is quite exposed at this point and there is a long wind sweep from the west with the result ice piles up on the shore. Protection must be provided against this condition. We can, however, prepare detailed drawings of the layout required.

The water situation at the school is acute and an augmented supply is essential this Autumn. We do not consider this lake a satisfactory source of water supply but there is no reason-

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau,
Ottawa, Ontario.
able alternative except a deep artesian well and such a source is in unlimited quantity. We investigated a spring a mile away but consider the quantity of water available from it inadequate and the expense involved in piping same excessive. The Director, Sanitary Division of the Department of Health, Saskatchewan, informed the writer over a year ago that he would not approve of and would object to the scheme pumping directly from the lake.

Should the Department of Indian Affairs decide to proceed with the placing of this intake it should be authorized and laid at once before freezing weather interferes.

Our draughtsman is away in Northern Manitoba at present so we are unable to prepare detailed plans of what is essential in connection with the intake. However, we will endeavour to have same available for construction purposes when the work is authorized.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Your letter of September 1st enclosing copies of two letters from the Department of Indian Affairs re work at Indian Schools is acknowledged. The writer of the letter did not correctly interpret the contents of the two letters received from the Department of Indian Affairs and accordingly the letter is very confusing. The two letters from the Department of Indian Affairs relate to distinctly separate projects.

It is noted that the Department of Indian Affairs authorizes the extension of the water intake out into the lake at Lebret, Saskatchewan and advises that previous instructions contained in their letter of August 24th should be followed with reference to the employment of labor.

We are now preparing working drawings covering what is necessary for the carrying out of this work. However, I wish to point out that the laying of this intake involves unwatering work, cribwork construction, driving sheet piling, laying pipe, etc. Heavy equipment is necessary and men of experience must direct the work. Accordingly the work should be carried out by a good firm, such as Smith Brothers & Wilson Limited on a cost plus profit basis, and we will make reasonable allowance for usual equipment. This office will undertake to furnish the working plans, arrange with a contracting firm to carry out the work, maintain a representative on the job to check labor and material costs, to see that the work is done in accordance with the plans and to test the intake for leaks upon completion.

The preparing of working drawings will take some days and we will accordingly continue with their preparation and will await definite instructions from the Department of Indian Affairs as to what reputable firm or firms in Regina we shall contact and also shall await information as to the financing of the work.

This work should be under way by the middle of this month so that an early reply would be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.

Dear Mr. Johnston:

In connection with the water intake construction at Lebret, Saskatchewan, we were advised by Mr. J. A. McCowan of Summerberry that Lebret is not in his constituency. Accordingly, I consulted Mr. Jackson, Private Secretary to our Minister, who at the time was occupying his office in the Dominion Public Building, opposite ours on the fifth floor. He instructed us to get in touch with the Honourable Mr. Gardiner's Secretary in Regina and be guided by his recommendation as to the contractor to employ.

Mr. J. R. Paget, General Contractor of Winnipeg and Regina was recommended to us as a result of a visit to Regina by Mr. J. T. Rose. We contacted Mr. Paget and discussed our design for intake with him and his Superintendent in Winnipeg. Both these gentlemen are quite familiar with conditions at Lebret and consider our proposed layout and protection on the right bank not sufficiently strong to withstand the ice pressure conditions that would be experienced at that point. I believe that the firm of J. R. Paget are specially equipped to construct the intake expeditiously and also I appreciate their objection to our proposed layout as we have repeatedly been warned about the ice pressure at the proposed intake location.

Mr. Paget stated that while this job was a comparatively small one, nevertheless it was one that required special knowledge of conditions and also special supervision and he furthermore stated that he had been requested by influential parties at Regina to take this job and carry it through to a successful conclusion. However, Mr. Paget refuses to have anything to do with the contract on a cost plus basis, stating that 10% on the cost of material and labor would not yield a sufficient return to warrant his firm bothering with the contract and furthermore that on such a contract from the Government there were demands at Regina that under no circumstances could considerably the contractor's net profit. Mr. Paget was asked if he would do the job on a straight contract basis and reported that he would and he submitted a price of $6,841.00. This amount covers the placing of the intake and the heavier protection proposed by himself; the details of which have all been decided upon. The proposed construction will insure a first-class job.

The intake as now proposed is approximately double the length and much more stable type of construction than that quoted upon by Messrs. Smith Brothers & Wilson of Regina, some weeks ago; their price being $6,520.00. We are firmly of the opinion that the J. R. Paget Company should be given the contract at his stated price. For reasons that must be fairly obvious this office cannot undertake to carry out this job ourselves, although we might be tempted to do so were it not so late and freezing weather will soon be with us.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith, in quadruplicate, the account of J. R. Paget, General Contractor, covering the cost of the construction of the water supply intake at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret, Saskatchewan. The account is for $6,540.00 and is in accordance with arrangements made last September with Mr. Paget and with the approval of the Department of Indian Affairs.

The work was carried out in accordance with the details shown on a plan recently forwarded you. Mr. J. T. Rose of this staff was present on the work during the construction to safeguard the interests of the Department and I am assured by him that a satisfactory job has been done. There remains, however, to be placed about 70 yards of rock on the top of the earth filling - only about 30 yards being placed to date. It is difficult to locate a suitable supply of rock at the present time; the ground being covered with deep snow and it would be more convenient to complete this portion of the work in the spring. We have arranged with Mr. Paget, therefore, that the sum of $100.00 is to be retained by the Department of Indian Affairs until such time as this protective layer of rock is placed. I might say that the cost of supplying and laying this rock has been let by contract for $1.00 per yard.

There is also enclosed a letter, dated January 19th, from the Chairman of the Women's Compensation Board of the Province of Saskatchewan, authorizing me to make such settlement with Mr. J. R. Paget for any monies due him with respect to Lebret Indian School Contract up to the date of the 19th of January. I would point out that all work covered by the contract, with the exception of the 70 yards of rock, was completed before the end of December so that the letter from the Compensation Board is full authority to make full settlement.

We have no written agreement with Mr. Paget covering the carrying out of this work and no specifications were drawn up. Accordingly, we are unable to furnish such data and I would ask that a cheque for $6,540.00 be issued to Mr. Paget covering full payment, less $100.00 for the carrying out of this work, as arranged.

Your obedient servant,

D. B. Gow,
District Chief Engineer.

Enclosure.
