February 19, 1937.

Sir:

I have for attention your letter of the 17th instant with further reference to the account of J. R. Paget, covering the construction of the water intake at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School at Lebret, Saskatchewan. As requested, we are enclosing a copy of Mr. Paget's letter of September 25th.

At the time Mr. Paget submitted this letter, we considered that his offer was subject to an interpretation different from that which he had in mind, with respect to his reference to Sales Tax. However, we were not able to contact Mr. Paget prior to writing our letter of September 26th to you in which we stated that Mr. Paget offered to do the work for $6,640.00, which included an item of $109 for rip-rap. We were quite aware that Mr. Paget's estimate of $110.00 to cover Sales Tax was quite unrealistic and we were also quite sure that what Mr. Paget had in mind when he offered $6,531.00 was based upon the assumption that he would not have to pay Sales Tax. However, knowing that the Contractor would have to pay Sales Tax, whatever it was, we proceeded on the assumption that the offer would stand at $6,531.00.

In January Mr. Paget submitted an account for $6,750.00 as per his letter of September 25th. It was pointed out to him, however, that from a legal interpretation of his offer of September 25th, he was only entitled to $6,530.00 but as we had interpreted his offer at $6,640.00 and had received approval from Ottawa for that amount, we would approve an account for that amount only. Mr. Paget finally consented to this arrangement.

The writer must admit that the arrangements made with respect to this contract, while regular, were rather loose, but would point out that our design covering construction had to be entirely changed after consultation with Mr. Paget and his Construction Superintendent, and as we were anxious to get the work underway, we authorized him to proceed without detailed drawings. We did, however, have very definite arrangements with Mr. Paget covering the work that had to be done, the quality of materials to be used and the degree of supervision that would be provided. An engineer from this staff was kept continuously on the job and I must say that the work done and the material supplied were in every way satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

District Chief Engineer.

Ottawa, May 20, 1937.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 15th instant, the Department has provided, in the current year's appropriation, the following amounts for the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School:

Material: painting outside buildings - shops, bakery, garage, barn, shed - $575.

Repairs: Shoe shop and employees' home - 250.

Miscellaneous Repairs: - 300.

Total -$1,125.

At the time of the preparation of the Estimates last Fall, a request was received for inclusion of the above items in our appropriation. However, if you consider there is other work more necessary, some of the above items could be omitted and the work recommended by you could be done. It should be understood, however, that the total, namely, $1,125., cannot be exceeded as this is the full amount that can be allowed for repairs and improvements at this school during the present fiscal year.

You might visit this school at your convenience and consult the Reverend Principal and report to the Department the best manner in which you consider the amount mentioned above should be expended. Your recommendations will receive prompt consideration.

MEMORANDUM:

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

In the appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year an amount of $1125.00 was provided for repairs and equipment required at the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret, Saskatchewan (Electoral District of Melville).

For your information I attach copy of letter sent to Dr. T. E. Robertson, Inspector of Indian Agencies, on May 20th. As no reply had been received from Dr. Robertson, another letter was written to him on August 7th. A copy of this letter is also attached. A copy of his reply, dated August 10th, explains what action he took in the matter.

We are also in receipt of an account for $1125.00 covering the cost of fencing purchased from the Frost Steel and Wire Company, Limited, Hamilton, Canada.

You will notice from the correspondence attached to this memorandum that no specific authority was given to purchase the fencing. Apparently, both Dr. Robertson and the Principal believed that the fencing material was required this year.

Under the circumstances I would appreciate receiving the Minister's approval for paying the account.

Director.
MEMORANDUM

September 3, 1937.

Dr. H.W. McGill,

I note from your memorandum of the last instant that fencing required for the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret, Saskatchewan, was purchased direct, without authority from Ottawa.

As the order has already been placed and the goods delivered, there is little we can do but approve the payment of the account. However, Dr. Robertson should be cautioned to not let anything of this nature occur again.

Acting Deputy Minister.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I am enclosing a copy of the list of building materials necessary for the repairs to the building which will be used as a training center in Domestic Economics for the older girls of the Lebret school.

You may remember that this project has received the approbation of Mr. Hoey and it is with the idea of carrying out Mr. Hoey's suggestions and desires in this field of education that this building is being repaired and transformed into a small home such as the Indians may hope to have when they are back on their respective reserves.

Part of the materials mentioned in this list will also be used for necessary repairs and improvements to the school's chicken house. When Mr. Hoey last visited this school he emphasized the necessity of the girls being trained in the care and management of poultry. The chicken house that had been used up to a few years ago was a very old building and unfit for its purpose. With the materials provided in the enclosed list the building will be put in first class condition.

The above list has already been forwarded to Mr. Robertson, your Inspector for Saskatchewan. I understand that he approves of it. My purpose in writing the present letter is to urge upon you the necessity of immediate action so that these repairs will be completed before the children come back in September.

Yours very truly,

JOP:LS

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Dear Sir: Re: your letter #114-0-5 Aug. 25.

I beg to inform you that, in answer to the above mentioned letter, the building material concerned therein was not only for the repairing of the building to be used as a training center in Domestic Science, because I pointed out to Reverend Father Plourde that we needed to fix the Chicken Coop, an old building which I showed you. We also need to improve the ventilation of the Cow Stable for the health of the Dairy Cows and to avoid to us every year some expense to fix the sidings that puff out and every winter are spoiled by the condensation of the stable which is too poorly isolated; to fix as well the hired men's quarters that are in very bad condition and so cold that they cannot be used in the winter time.

So I did not think that the amount of $943.20 for which your authority was asked in Father Plourde's letter was too high. If your desire is that most of those expenses for which estimates were given last fall for the present fiscal year be postponed, I am ready to obey your orders or suggestions, but I had understood that you wished to see us train the children in the care of poultry raising.

Moreover, I had already taken on my own current money the expenses incurred by the moving and the necessary improvements of the slaughter house.
For this as well as for the other improvements or repairs that I am constantly making, I did not claim any reimbursement. My policy is to ask help from your Department only to assist me to carry on these expenses with a little share taken by each of us.

Consequently, I followed your suggestion and reviewed the list of materials sent to you, and propose that you authorize us for an expenditure of the amount which you think suitable to help us, for instance; the sum of $95.00 for the chicken coop; $95.00 for the training center in Domestic Science; another $95.00 for the hired men's rooms and the balance for these repairs will be afforded by me.

We will leave the work at the stable for another year as well as the engineer's home.

I expect that this plan will receive from you your kind consideration, and that I will be able to improve our needs without taxing too much the amount of $1000.00 that the Department has appropriated for the current year.

Yours very truly,

M. de Bretagne,
C.M.I.,

Dear Sir:

On my recent visit to the Lebret School, the Principal drew my attention to the condition of the dough mixer. It is in very bad shape, the dough coming out through the crevices and worn-out points. The machine is not worth repairing—in fact it is impossible to repair it.

The Principal informed me that he placed a dough mixer in the 1938-39 Estimates and he asks me to make my best effort to secure one for him, as in addition to its leaking, the rust detaches itself and gets mixed up in with the dough.

If funds are available, I would recommend that this be supplied.

An estimate on dough mixer is attached. This estimate has been furnished by the Fletcher Manufacturing Company, 877 Dundas Street, Toronto 8, Canada. The machine described would answer this purpose.

I would also draw your attention to the fact that the mixer suggested has a motor attached. This would do away with using a gas engine in a room close to fire and thus reduce the fire hazard.

Rev. Father M. de Bretagne, Principal of the Lebret Indian Industrial School has requested me to write you again regarding the dough mixer which he included in his requisitions for 1939-40.

In this connection I wish to state that the dough mixer which is now in use in the Lebret school is the one which went through the fire when the old school was destroyed. I am informed that it was damaged beyond repair. It was only with great difficulty that it was used up to the present time. It should also be stated that the mixer had been in use for over 20 years when the school was destroyed by fire. Father de Bretagne has asked several firms to repair this mixer and none of them were willing to undertake the job.

Dear Sir,

I am sorry to hear from the Department that the General Electric Co is claiming the payment of an account due by the School. Be sure that I will settle immediately that question with that Company.

After reception of your letter I have checked the files and found that when I was in France last winter a bulb for Tungar lamp had been ordered and was never paid.
